PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows: That we urge you to oppose the Australian Bill of Rights Bill because:
We get no legally enforceable rights under the Bill

The Bill does not guarantee vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property and not be deprived of it without just compensation and the right of choice between Government and non-Government schools.
The Bill gives Canberra extra powers to change our Federal system by the back door with a constitutional referendum.
The Bill gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should vote against the Bill of Rights, support Opposition amendments and seek a genuine public debate and a referendum on the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights and Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Bill of Rights will have the power to override and negate our Common Law within five years of its enactment.

2. Because the Bill of Rights is based on an International Covenant this will take the control of our country out of the hands of the people and their democratically elected representatives, giving the power to those outside Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
1. That the Senate rejects the Australian Bill of Rights and all cognate Bills.
2. That as our representatives, you protect our Australian Heritage and Christian culture and values, both in the Education System, and through the Media.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that.

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.
2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack.
This makes Watsonia a potentials nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The `joint U.S.-Australian' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the ``Joint Australian-U.S.'' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CARRICK; CHILDS; GIETZELT; MCINTOSH; PUPLICK; RICHARDSON
PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 15 October.
Clauses 15 to 17-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the Committee stage of the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986 to place on record what I believe to be a necessary contribution in the form of an opinion of the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties with particular relation to the relevance of this whole amending Bill to areas of public concern demonstrated recently by what has been called the Army land grab. As honourable senators will know, the Committee of this-
—Order, Senator Mason. We are considering clauses 15 to 17. Is this relevant to those clauses?

—I believe it is relevant. All the areas of this amending Bill are relevant to this point. In the opinion of Mr Tim Robertson, the Secretary of the Council for Civil Liberties-and I agree with him-this is a very important public matter and should be put to the Committee. I would crave the indulgence of the Committee to that extent, but I accept your ruling on that, Mr Chairman.
—You may proceed, Senator Mason, but I would like you to link your comments to clauses 15, 16 and 17 in some way.

—I think the obvious link is obfuscation. In other words, the purpose of these amendments is to continue the Government conspiracy to obfuscate the process of gaining freedom of information. This is simply and obviously demonstrated by every aspect of this Bill. This Bill is designed to hand over to public servants the means of refusing honest citizens theirrequests. Mr Robertson says in his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Every department whose filing system is in disarray can now refuse almost every FOI request if this Bill goes through.
He goes on-I think this is worth quoting:
The purpose of the amendments before the Senate is to make absolutely certain that the Act can never again be used to enable the people to defeat a major Government project.
That is a serious statement to be made by the Secretary of the Council for Civil Liberties and especially by a person of the stature of Mr Tim Robertson who, as we all know, is a leading barrister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I believe that not only your indulgence but that of the Committee as a whole is being tested by Senator Mason at this stage. The only obfuscation is in the nexus between what he is saying and the clauses that we are now dealing with. I believe that he ought to be ruled out of order.
—I have not been able to see any connection, Senator Mason. Your speech might be quite appropriate at the third reading stage, but it is not appropriate to clauses 15, 16 and 17.
—I accept your ruling, Mr Chairman. I will make the speech at the third reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 17 refers to the application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. As Senator Gareth Evans said in rebuttal last night in the debate, people could, of course, go to the AAT if they had trouble getting the information and a range of other matters. I remind the Committee that this Government has, in fact, put a $200 charge on the operations of the AAT, which effectively rules out that operation if the original charge in the internal review that will go on here will cost $20 and $40. It is hardly likely that people will go to the AAT and charge themselves $200.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 18 agreed to.
Clauses 19 to 22-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 23 and 24-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be opposing clauses 23 and 24. These consequential amendments relate to charges. I also foreshadow that we will be opposing new regulation 5 in clause 25 and the Schedule to the regulations, clause 27. I will not canvass the arguments that were put extensively last night. However, I want to raise with Senator Puplick, who is leading for the Opposition, that the amendment he moved last night-that is, the amendment to multi-document searches which we supported and which was carried-also involves considerable costs. It seems that if one is trying to distinguish, as Senator Puplick did, between parts of Budget Bills which are not Budget Bills and parts of Budget Bills which are Budget Bills, I am not sure how that whole thing eventually stands up. The costs were there and the costs are here. Again, I appeal to the Opposition to oppose with its vote these two clauses. I believe that the types of charges we see put on here and the types of reasons Senator Puplick gave in the Opposition's view about these, ought lead one to oppose these particular clauses and the other ones I mentioned which deal with charges.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clauses stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 25.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 25, leave out proposed new Regulation 5.
I do not think there is any need to rehash the argument regarding the application fees of $30 and $40 in terms of the internal review.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a couple of things which relate not only to clause 25 but to the whole of Part III which is now quaintly known in the jargon around the place as the Barney Cooney repeal Bill. The purpose of amending regulations by Acts on this occasion has been largely to mount the subterfuge-it is a subterfuge; there is no doubt about that-of dealing by means of substantive legislation with amendments to regulations dealing with fees. Yesterday, as you will recall, Mr Chairman, you made some detailed comments on the question of tacking, that is, of the Government putting into legislation certain financial provisions as though by dealing with them as Budget legislation a method had been found by the Government of getting its legislation through, whereas if it had proceeded in the normal fashion, that is, by introducing amending regulations, that would not have been achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to put a couple of points on the record which arise from the very preliminary reading I have been able to give in the last hour or so to some of the statistics in the report of the interdepartmental committee to which the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) referred yesterday. Once again the interdepartmental committee indicates the bogus nature of previous cost estimates regarding freedom of information. At the heart of the Government's now saying that it must have the capacity to increase charges is that the cost of freedom of information has blown out enormously. On page 10 of the IDC report the point is made that the Department of Finance advised the IDC that it ought to be working on the basis of 50 per cent to 75 per cent to be added for on-costs, rather than the 88 per cent which has been used in previous reports.

It is interesting to note that on pages 17 and 18 of the IDC report, on the basis of a survey undertaken by the Department of Finance on the average search and retrieval time for chargeable requests, the requests are broken down into four categories. The first category is `personal', which is the sort of request an individual might make to the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Veterans' Affairs or the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for information about his own case. Another category is `personnel', which is the access to personnel records and files held by departments about Commonwealth employees' business and policy.

It amazes me that the IDC report goes on to say that the steps involved in each search and retrieval are typically `consultation with applicant over scope of request where necessary, identification of files and documents, collection of files, examinations of files, copying of documents and recording what has been examined and copies'. In terms of the section marked `personnel', that is said to take on average 12 hours. If a person goes to the department and says, `I would like to have a look at my own personnel records', how can the survey possibly state that the average time for processing that request is 12 hours? It seems to me to be absolutely mind-blowing. I cannot imagine the sort of `consultation' required. On the `identification of files and documents'-for heaven's sake, how long does it take to identify a file of an employee of a department in a particular department? As to the `collection of files', we may be told that a file cannot be got up from registry to wherever it has to be examined in other than a couple of hours. I can believe that, because during the Estimates hearings, the Department of Education actually told us that the time taken to get a file on new recruitments up from the registry to the officer checking the advertisements that were to go in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette for appointment of a new officer was a day. Apparently this is the sort of charge that we are talking about here. For `Examinations of files, copying of documents and recording what has been examined', I just cannot believe that the average time taken in the Commonwealth bureaucracy for assessment of personnel files on that basis is 12 hours. If it is, it is an absolute disgrace.

The other point that I seek to draw attention to is that on page 5 of appendix G the Government is a little bit exposed by its IDC report, because under the heading `Effect of charging on request volume' it reads:
The more a fee structure is oriented towards cost recovery, the more likely it is to reduce the number of requests.

Presumably that is the intention of the legislation-to reduce the number of requests. All of the comments made by Senator Gareth Evans and others about dealing with this legislation on the basis that it is not an attempt to restrict access or discourage people from using freedom of information is, I think, very largely blown out of the water by the comment in the interdepartmental committee report, `The more a fee structure is oriented towards cost recovery, the more likely it is to reduce the number of requests'.

Reading through the IDC report-it has some 200-odd pages and we have had it in our hands for only a few minutes-one finds some very disturbing elements in it. In the tables, particularly those starting on appendix A7, one can really see the extent to which freedom of information statistics and freedom of information costs are very largely distorted if one looks at the burden which the Australian Taxation Office has as one of the principal subjects of requests being made. For instance, one should look at the number of requests that are policy requests. We were told yesterday that policy requests are both the most time consuming-according to the statistics here they take an average of 56 hours to deal with-and the most costly in terms of the actual work, the review and everything else that goes with it. I accept that to be perfectly correct. Of the 2,364 policy requests received in 1984-85, 683 of those were directed towards the Tax Office. Interestingly enough, the next highest-this certainly came as a surprise to me-were the 239 requests directed to the Department of Aviation. I found it surprising that that was where the impact of policy requests should be. The third highest was the Attorney-General's Department, which got 176. I am not sure exactly what sort of policy requests they were but I presume they go to matters such as law enforcement, advisings and things of that nature. The statistics for access staff years show that again the Australian Taxation Office has the highest number of requests in terms of personnel requests, for personal records-19.5 staff years. The figure for the Department of Defence is a little hard to work out because it has aggregated personal and personnel requests. Again the Taxation Office is by far the highest in terms of personnel. It is overwhelmingly the highest in terms of business requests, taking 10.9 staff years out of the total for the whole of the bureaucracy of 23.17. The Taxation Office has one of the highest figures for policy matters.

As the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has a chance to examine the interdepartmental committee report I believe it will be necessary to try to work out whether the applications made to the Taxation Office have so poisoned the overall statistics as to be providing an excuse, because of the volume and the cost of those requests to the Taxation Office, for a Public Service-wide clampdown, even though costs have been generated in only one or two small areas.

I finally come back to the point which I have made previously on behalf of the Opposition. We have indicated that despite the fact that we do not like these increases in fees, the revenue-raising measures directly contained in Part III are seen by us as a part of the Government's Budget arrangements and on that basis the direct imposition of charges in this fashion should not be resisted by the Opposition. However, I make the point again that it is not only undesirable but slightly dishonest for the Government to mix up these revenue-raising matters with the rest of the Bill in this tacking arrangement which was certainly not what was intended under the Constitution in terms of the way in which legislation should be put together. Two pieces of legislation are being dealt with in this one Bill in this fashion. In fact the title of the Bill reads:
An Act to amend the Freedom of Information Act 1982 and the Freedom of Information (Charges) Regulations, and for related purposes.

That clearly indicates the Government's intent in the matter. As I have said, this is the Barney Cooney repeal Bill because it is an attempt to avoid the scrutiny of regulations that Senator Cooney's Committee, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, would otherwise have given had these changes been introduced as regulations on their own. This chamber will have to pay some attention to the principle that if the Standing Committee is going to have its status and authority subverted by amendments to regulations being made in Acts rather than in other regulations, as the Committee exercises its authority to scrutinise and report, governments will be more and more tempted to avoid the scrutiny of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee by making amendments to regulations within substantive Acts. I think the Senate as a whole has to be cautious on that. This is certainly not the only occasion when that has happened. It has happened in numerous Acts. This year they were the Taxation Laws Amendment Act (No. 2) and the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act. In 1985 the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Act 1982 was treated in the same fashion. Nevertheless, I do not believe this is a desirable practice and it is something which the Senate as a whole will have to pay attention to, otherwise governments will be tempted to use this device more and more for purposes which in that respect I do not think are entirely proper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — There are three matters that require some comment. The first is Senator Puplick's concern, which he has just reiterated, about the amendment of the charges regulations by way of the legislation rather than amending regulations. It is a rather odd turning of basic principles on their head that we have just heard from Senator Puplick. The traditional concern of the Parliament has been that its rights not be subverted by significant and substantive matters being dealt with by way of regulation. Senator Puplick is now expressing a concern to the exact contrary, that the Parliament's rights are somehow being subverted by virtue of a regulatory change being made in the substantive Act rather than by way of the subordinate legislation mechanism. For all the status and dignity of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, one would not have thought it had the same status and dignity as the Senate chamber itself. We have done the Senate the courtesy of enabling it to consider these measures in the chamber-the Parliament as a whole-because they are clearly of importance and significance. The fact that we have bypassed the Regulations and Ordinances Committee in the process I would have thought is a mere bagatelle rather than something that justifies indignation of the order that we have just heard. Moreover, this was an opportunity for the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills to look at these issues, if not in this instance the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I cannot see that it deserves the implicit censure that Senator Puplick has offered in his approach to this particular matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government put these provisions in the Bill for a number of reasons-certainly to emphasise the character of these measures as measures of not only Budget relevance but Budget significance. What this is all about is an exercise in cost saving and in cost recovery. The particular finance provisions are not merely incidental to what this legislation is all about; they are central to it. The measures are properly seen and construed as a single package and it is for those reasons that they have been put forward and brought into the Parliament in this way. The course adopted has the further advantage of greater speed and simplicity, which might be thought to commend itself to honourable senators, even if not to Senator Puplick.

A second matter that deserves reply is Senator Puplick's disbelief of the times specified in the interdepartmental committee report for certain processing. He expressed particular incredulity about the 12 hours allegedly taken on average by departments for what he said was the search for and retrieval of personnel documents. Senator Puplick need to read a little more carefully paragraph 4.2.5 of the interdepartmental committee report on page 17 where he will see that the 12 hours that is there identified as an average for personnel documents, along with a number of other figures, was a figure relating not just to search and retrieval but also to the decision-making time involved in assessing the documentation by reference to all the categories of exemption and so on that it is permissible for agencies to apply. It is not mere search and retrieval; it is the whole processing that is there being referred to. In any event, it ought to be noted that even though some things do tend to take longer in the Public Service than any one without direct experience of running it, or being in it, would believe possible-it ought to be acknowledged, I repeat-some personnel documents can be rather hard to locate.

The Department of Social Security is one of the biggest departments in terms of the number of personnel and has one of the biggest target areas for freedom of information access requests. In that Department there is a long tradition of people being moved around from one regional or branch office to another in different parts of the country, leaving a trail of personnel records littered behind them in a number of different physical locations. The mere task of assembling that material can be quite a significant and substantial one. The situation is similar, of course, in the Department of Defence, where physical mobility is a very common and recurring phenomenon. I make those points only in passing. I think it is important to appreciate that the figures, when properly understood, in the form in which they have been put forward, do not really give rise to the kind of reaction that Senator Puplick had.

The final point I make about the fees-we are only, for the purposes of this amendment, talking about the application fee of $30 and $40 respectively, in proposed new regulation 5; we are not talking about the charges of so many dollars per hour, which we will come to later, for the actual reviewing time occupied by an agency-is that it ought to be acknowledged that those fees are not payable, of course, in relation to requests for access to documents of a personal character by income maintenance recipients. That is, as we have seen, the largest single class of FOI access requests. No charge is being made in relation to that class. Furthermore, to the extent that there are other categories of personal documents that might be sought, other than by income maintenance recipients, there is still a provision retained in the legislation for a remission of this fee on the basis of hardship in any individual case. We believe that that particular safety net mechanism will ensure that no injustice is done and no insuperable difficulties are put in the way of anyone seeking access to those classes of documents which, I repeat, are both the largest single class of documents that are sought under the Act and also the class of documents where the problem of financial disincentives is obviously most acute. By and large-although there will no doubt be exceptions from time to time-people seeking business documents, people seeking policy documents, are people who can afford quite easily to pay the very modest charges that are now set out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not entirely satisfied with the attempt by the Minister to slide over my comments about all of the delays in terms of personnel by saying that the Department of Social Security does not keep its records in very good order. For instance, how would one balance that if one looks at table 3 on A7 of the interdepartmental committee report? The Department of Social Security received 220 requests for access to personnel files and it took, according to table 5, 5.8 staff hours on access requests and 0.64 access staff years. That should be compared with figures for the Department of Science, which got three requests for personnel files; yet, if one looks at the way in which those other tables are set out, it took 0.03 access staff years and was involved in 20 staff hours on access requests. If one looks at the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, it got one request for personnel files and, under the `personnel' heading in the next table, the figure is 0.01. In the table which shows staff hours spent on access requests the figure is 20. I do not believe that the Minister can skate over this business by saying that the Department of Social Security does not keep its records in very good order, therefore it is not surprising that the figures are as high as they are. Quite clearly, if that is the real problem, somebody ought to put the proverbial rocket up the Department of Social Security, instead of saying: `It is all terribly sad, but there it is, fellows'. As Senator Evans would undoubtedly say at the end of the day: `Bad luck'. I will not say what he would have said if Senator Sir John Carrick had been making the point; otherwise, he would have just said: `Bad luck'.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point is that the point I was making about the tacking arrangement was not that this was some disrespect to the Parliament, but that it was clearly a device whereby one of the Senate committees-the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances-was being shut out of a particular process. Without being unkind, in terms of both general appearance and colouring, Senator Evans may aspire to look like a sort of cut-down version of a Holbein portrait. But if he now wants to establish a new variation of the Henry VIII principle, he is going about it pretty well. I reiterate the point that if the Regulations and Ordinances Committee is clearly being cut out of a process because the Government knows that that Committee has been particularly vigilant in looking at a particular matter, that is something which is of concern to the Senate, and certainly something which the Opposition will be keeping under close review in regard to legislation that continues to be presented to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to the debate between Senator Puplick and Senator Evans. I am getting more and more worried about, firstly, the efficiency of the Public Service, which I was quite worried about before we started and, secondly, the real understanding that either the Opposition or the Government seems to have of what these problems are about. I would like Senator Evans to give us some type of idea-he says that cost saving is the central theme of why this legislation has been introduced-of exactly what type of budgetary figures he used to estimate what the budgetary effects of each of these amendments will be. I asked that question during my contribution to the second reading debate. I repeated it last night with respect to a couple of areas, particularly the internal review process and the process of application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly concerned about the real effect of these fees on people who can make these applications for freedom of information. The $30 charge may be quite reasonable, especially if it is waived in the case of all personal and personnel requests. The interdepartmental committee report, which we have not had much time to look at, may give us some of the breakdowns, but certainly not in the detail in which I would like to see them. I would like to see budgetary figures which basically predict-not looking backwards over the last year-what type of revenue the Government expects to raise in each one of those categories; and what it expects to raise through departmental incompetence, which is basically what the $40 appeals application fee is about. The $40 application fee is applicable when the department has refused to give a document and the matter then goes to the AAT or through an appeal process. If all of those appeals support the department, at the end of the process, that $40 may be justified. I believe it should probably be refunded if the applicant is proven to be right and the appeal is sustained. What are the arrangements for recovery of cost in that situation? As I said, I can understand the $30 charge. I see the $20 as being just an open-ended charge on people, over which applicants have absolutely no control and no budgetary understanding. The matter is not mentioned in this clause but again it will be open slather, an encouragement, to departments to continue to procrastinate.

Firstly, what will the Government do, or what is it doing, to try to improve the efficiency of the Public Service? Secondly, what is the Government doing to change the attitude of departments which have very high refusal rates and high rates of pushing for appeals? How will that be monitored and reported to this Parliament? If this does not take place we are just legislating blindly: That is exactly how I currently feel. We are accepting figures from a government; we are told that the Department of Social Security's personnel files are in a total mess and that that is an excuse. We are told that the Australian Taxation Office receives half of the freedom of information applications and is totally distorting the picture.

If we get reasonable statistics and the Government intends to produce reasonable statistics we will need to have budget predictions now of what the Government expects to raise in each of these areas and in a year's time we will need some type of review process by which we can compare the Government's predictions on the Budget-this will show how good a manager it is of the Public Service-with the actual performance. Currently, the Government is expecting us to take everything on trust. What amount does the Government expect to retrieve from each of these categories? The Minister may want to take that question on notice but I would expect him to have the answer now. I would be very surprised and most disappointed if the Minister said: `This cost saving measure is the central part of the whole legislation but I do not have the figures'. Can the Minister give us the budgetary figures and tell us what he will do about giving us a report on how effective or efficient they are and what he will do when he finds that certain departments have attitudes which are anti-freedom of information?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should defend the honour of the Department of Social Security against some rather squalid little accusations that have been made by both Senator Puplick and Senator Vigor, purportedly based on something that I had said. The point I was making was not that Social Security records are in a mess but that the very character of so much employment within that Department is such that personnel records tend to be located in a number of different places reflecting the employment history of a number of the people there.

SPEECH.PARA: That apart, let me respond to just another aspect of what Senator Vigor said. Senator Vigor has, as we all know, and have found out and suffered to our cost in Estimates committee hearings, an absolutely insatiable appetite for detail. One of the great mysteries of this place, rivalling I suppose in its magnitude the disappearance of the Marie Celeste, is what exactly he does with the information when it is ultimately supplied to him. One of the things governments have to bear in mind is that sometimes the cost of supplying very detailed statistical information can be such as to simply not be justified, given the nature of the savings that are attempted to be made by introducing the reform in the first place. An awful lot has to depend upon rule of thumb estimates and assumptions. The basic assumptions on which this legislation is proceeding are spelt out in the financial impact statement on page 2 of the explanatory memorandum, where the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) states:
It is estimated that the proposals in the Bill will result in cost savings of about $4m and revenue of about $4m.

How precisely those figures are arrived at is something I will put to the Attorney-General, and I will see whether he wishes to add something more than that. Most of the raw material, in terms of drawing these calculations, is to be found in the interdepartmental committee report that has been tabled. There are innumerable disaggregations to be found in the different classes of documents. Of course one has to make assumptions about elasticity of demand in the context of fees being imposed. Various things simply cannot be quantified with precision in advance, besides which practices are changing, as I indicated last night. Productivity has been substantially improving over the life of this legislation to date as departments get experienced in the operation of the legislation and become familiar with its demands and limitations. That trend may well continue and be an important factor in cost reduction.

We cannot give the detail for which Senator Vigor is clamouring, the sort of detail that, when he receives it, no one ever quite knows what he does with it and is certainly never quite persuaded that the public interest is advanced as a consequence. I will see what further information can be provided to him in due course by the Attorney-General. However, for the moment I believe that we have put on the record, in the general terms of the explanatory memorandum, the second reading speech and the more detailed data base of the interdepartmental committee report which has now been made available, as much as could be reasonably required of any government.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Macklin's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 26 agreed to.
Clause 27 (Schedule to Regulations).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two items are built into this clause. Basically, the first item involves the movement of the hourly rate from $12 to $15. But much more importantly, this clause seeks to impose an additional cost by adding the following item to the end of Part I:

SPEECH.PARA: A charge in respect of the time that is spent (other than on an application under section 54 of the Act for the review of a decision) by an agency or Minister in deciding whether to grant, refuse or defer access to the document or to grant access to a copy of the document with deletions, including time spent-
(a) in examining the document;
(b) in consultation with any person or body;
(c) in making a copy with deletions; or
(d) in notifying any interim or final decision on the request.

According to the Department of Finance estimate, the average time taken for decision ma-king and consultation for a FOI request is 11 hours. So the total cost will be based on $30 to make an application and the cost of the number of hours that are involved. Can the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) tell me-I do not seem to have the information in the material in front of me-the average number of working hours that will be involved under item 2 of Part I? On the basis of the Department of Finance estimate the cost would be calculated at 11 hours at $20 an hour. So we are starting at a bare minimum, without taking into consideration the working time involved, of $250 on average per request.

But I would take the matter even further than that. Applicants who have applied for information which is of a sensitive nature fairly obviously will come under this section in a very heavy way. It is like, quite frankly, sitting in a taxi on the Sydney Harbour Bridge and having the meter tick over in a traffic jam. That is what we are going to do here. The cost will tick over at a rate of $20 an hour in respect of information of a sensitive nature. There will, of course, be discussions by all sorts of people who will be involved. From the discussions that have gone on, we know that this could take months. This has already happened. We are looking at a cost of thousands and thousands of dollars for any information that is vaguely sensitive. There is no cap or ceiling on the cost. The meter is ticking away at $20 an hour.

There is no mention in the Press, which seemingly has shown no interest in something which I would have thought was absolutely vital to it in terms of freedom of information, particularly with regard to items of such a sensitive nature. That $20 an hour meter rate will become an item which any reasonable person in the community, who is unaware of how the bureaucracy might work, may not be able to afford. People cannot go into an open-ended financial commitment. They cannot undertake an open-ended liability over which they have absolutely no control. Basically, the Government will be able to bankrupt an individual who goes to it and seeks information. It will be able to bankrupt a person merely because he is seeking freedom of information material. This can happen quite simply under this legislation-with no trouble whatsoever. Just consider for a moment what the Government could do if it wanted to get at a person who is seeking information. It could simply sit down and talk and then bankrupt the person-who sought what? He sought information, not the Government's information. He then goes off to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, but what does he go to it about? He cannot go to it just because he believes this is an exorbitant amount, provided the bureaucracy, the Government, has been careful and made sure that it is examining a document, consulting with a person or a body, making a copy with deletions or notifying any interim or final decision on the request. So here we have this meter ticking over with no end in sight. What ordinary citizen in the community is going to go into that? Perhaps the Minister for Resources and Energy, being a lawyer, has a much more laid back attitude because the legal field is about the only other area in which ordinary citizens have to enter into open-ended commitments.

We have had debates in this place plenty of times about the extreme reluctance of ordinary citizens to approach the law. Why do they have that reluctance? They have it because of the open-ended liability; not because they do not want to have their rights violated, not because they do not necessarily have a reasonable case, but because when they are confronted with the bureaucracy, with a multinational company or with someone who has more resources than they do, they know that those persons, organisations and the Government can prolong a court hearing until they are bankrupted. As I have said, perhaps the Minister, being a lawyer, would be much more happy to look at those items. But, quite frankly, no citizen who thinks that his request might in any way be sensitive is going to do this.

What requests have we got? We have had excluded personal file requests, so what else will we be looking for? We are going to be looking for material that a government as a matter of course does not provide. Almost by definition there will be at least something provided. The Department of Finance has said that the average time that will be taken will be 11 hours. Once this clause is in the Act I can see that averaging time increasing dramatically. Here the Government has taken the golden opportunity to make sure that if people finally find anything out they will certainly not come back for a second try. The Government is making certain that anybody who is going to look for anything sensitive any more in these files will cop such a hefty bill that he will be deterred from thinking of getting any more information out of the Government. In many cases a person will be paying off the bill for the rest of his life if he is not dragged before the courts with a debt recoverable by the Commonwealth from that individual who has been stupid enough to think that in a democracy the information gathered actually belongs to the citizens just by exercising the basic right.

This clause effectively destroys any reasonable chance by any citizen other than the richest to approach the Government with a freedom of information request. If a constituent approached me in my office and raised, as has been raised in the past, the desire to get some information, I would counsel him very strongly that it would be a very bad thing for him to do. I believe that if any other member of parliament does not counsel a person in that way, he could be criminally liable for suggesting that the person may make a freedom of information request without having told the person of the enormous costs that are down the road for him and of the possibility of his having to owe every penny to the Commonwealth when he finally gets that piece of paper he is looking for.

TALK.START.PARA: —With bits deleted.

—And probably with bits deleted. In the end he might not get anything but a bill. This freedom of information legislation under this Australian Labor Party Government is simply for the rich people and the rich corporations which do not worry about those things as they do not worry about the law. They have their team of lawyers. They take the law courts as a matter of course and they are in and out of them every day of the week. They have a budget set aside for those contingencies. They are the types of people who will be able to use the Freedom of Information Act and they will continue to use it. The Freedom of Information Act is not for the ordinary citizen of this country but for the rich and the powerful. I believe that the rich and the powerful in Australia have enough access to government as it is. I thought that the Freedom of Information Bill, when it was introduced and argued for very strongly by the Minister, was in fact for the ordinary citizens of this country to enable them to get some of the information which they felt was necessary for them. They were the sentiments and arguments put by the Minister. In speech after speech, not only in this place but outside, in articles that he wrote-I have a list of them on my desk in my electorate office-and time after time the Minister eloquently argued that ordinary citizens did have an undeniable right in a democracy for freedom of information.

SPEECH.PARA: This clause, which is supported by the Opposition, will effectively destroy the right of those people to make such requests. If they do they will have this most terrifying open-ended commitment. As the law is terrifying for ordinary citizens so will this be, because without any control over that meter, they could be running up a bill which they cannot meet and which they never thought they would have to meet. My worry is not only for those citizens who might come and see me or another senator or member of the House of Representatives but for those citizens who might be foolish enough to think that we have a Freedom of Information Act which means that they will have access to freedom of information, who will put in a request and think that the $30 charge might be their only cost, or that the $15 an hour charge for work done might be their only cost, and who will not realise what an open-ended commitment they are entering into.

I would be interested to know how the Government is going to counsel anybody in the future who has the audacity to think that some of that information might be his, as a democratic right. I want to know what the Government is intending to do to stop people seeking freedom of information, because I think that is what it needs to do now. How is it going to stop people bankrupting themselves? What type of counselling is the Government intending for anybody in the future who has an inkling of possibly using this Act or what is left of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge, as I have to, that it is the case that this particular provision will increase applicants' costs in a number of cases and will have some deterrent effect as a result in relation to some applications that would otherwise be made. But there are a number of points that can properly be put in defence of these provisions other than the recurring theme of the Government's need to limit the costs of this legislation and to get some better revenue return, that is, to get a more realistic contribution to the costs of open government and to ensure that FOI users who do derive some benefit from the legislation are not in a sense unfairly subsidised by taxpayers who do not use the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from all those financial considerations, however, there are a number of points that can be made. The first which I will quickly make is that, to the extent to which this new provision in the regulations will operate as a deterrent, that is not wholly bad or undesirable, at least in relation to some classes of request which we have experienced in the past and which have been manifestly unnecessarily broad. When asked in the past `Do you want document X or Y?' in the face of a very broad request, rather than honing down and contemplating what might be involved and saying `Either X or Y', the applicant has tended to say: `I want both. Dig them all out, then I will look at them and decide what I want'. The provision we are now installing here will clearly operate as an incentive for people to hone, shape and refine their request with rather more precision than they have been minded to in the past. That is a perfectly desirable outcome from the point of view of rational public administration.

The second point I make goes to Senator Macklin's nightmare of the ticking meter, the open-ended character of the request that he waxed so lyrical about just a few moments ago. I think that amounts to a very considerable distortion of the way in which this will operate in practice. Not only is there a requirement in the Act itself, section 29, as to notification of liability to pay any charges, or potential charges, but also there are a series of mechanisms built into the existing Act and regulations which will ensure that people do not, in fact, find themselves up for huge bills which they are manifestly unable or unwilling to pay. For a start, there is a continuing requirement in the regulations-I refer to regulation 12-for the provisions governing the payment of deposits. They will continue to apply to the charges that are contemplated here in respect of reviewing an evaluation time just as they will continue to apply to the earlier categories of charges for search and retrieval time. The provision there is that where the amount, or the estimated amount of the charge exceeds $25, the agency can make a decision to require the person to pay a deposit before further efforts are expended and costs are incurred in the evaluation in question. That payment of the deposit will be a point--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is for every item now? That $25 covers every item? No item can come out under $25 now? It is $30 to get into the exercise.
—I am not talking about a fee for an application; I am talking about the charges down the track, discretionary charges.
—It is not going to take under an hour.

—I am just saying that there is a capacity. The point is the same whether or not this particular provision is triggered in every case or whether it is triggered only in some. The point is that wherever there is any substantial sum of money involved, or likely to be involved, beyond $25, it is perfectly competent for the agency-a prudent agency undoubtedly will do this rather than expend the cost in the first instance without a guarantee as to a return-and open to the agency to seek the payment of a deposit. That notification associated with the request for a deposit will be an excellent indicator to the applicant as to what the anticipated cost of the whole exercise will be. It will be a perfect opportunity for the applicant to refuse to pay the deposit and thus bring the process grinding to a halt at that particular stage.
—Does he get his $30 back?

—He is under no obligation to pay-I am not talking about the application fee-as a recoverable debt, the amount of the charges incurred to that particular point. That point can also be made in relation to, let us say, a sum of $200 or $300 that may be incurred, or the liability that might be incurred to pay, if the $20 per hour charge does, in fact, mount up in the way that Senator Macklin said.
—Do you accept the average from the Department of Finance of 11 hours? That is $220 to start off with.

—If the fee is charged and it is discretionary-I will come back to that in a moment-it may well be that that sort of figure will prove to be a realistic one, at least for non-routine classes of documents which are essentially the ones we are talking about. What I am trying to say in making a further point is that it is not really a matter of someone being confronted with a bill, the non-payment of which will expose him to court action and debt recovery and all the rest of the horrors that Senator Macklin summoned up for us. There is no provision in the legislation for the formal recovery of an amount thus incurred by way of a debt.
—It is a debt to the Commonwealth.

—No, it is not necessarily to be regarded as a debt at all. The only sanction is that if the amount is not paid the person will not get his information. That is the only sanction that is in the terms of the legislation. If the person gets the information, the argument that it is a debt recoverable at law is very much stronger, but if it is a demand for the payment and if a person does not pay it he will not get the documents.
—That is an extraordinary situation.

—No, it is not an extraordinary proposition; it is a perfectly common and garden proposition and it is why this legislation is drafted as it is in terms of a description of certain liabilities as debts recoverable at law in the procedures that are set out. It is some time since I have worn my lawyer's or Attorney-General's hat and I do not want to be taken as committing the Government irrevocably to the proposition that these things are not recoverable. But that is my impression and it is not one from which I have been dissuaded by the departmental advisers on my left whom I do not want to dob in, in case they want to check the point further. It follows from first principle.
—Are we now to advise people to do it and not pay their bills? Is that what you are saying? That would run up enormous costs to the Commonwealth.

—Realistically, people, rather than being exposed to open-ended meter ticking and horrendous bills at the end of the day which they do not know anything about and are utterly unwilling or unable to pay, in most cases will get advance notification and will have an opportunity to bale out before the costs are even incurred by the Department. If at the end of the day they do not like, cannot pay, or cannot afford the fee that has been incurred, they will, I believe, have the option of not paying the bill and simply, as a result, will not get the information. That puts into a slightly more relaxed context some of the shark feeding frenzy of indignation that we had from Senator Macklin on that particular point.

SPEECH.PARA: A third point that I think needs to be made and emphasised is that the payment of these charges is not mandatory-it is discretionary. It does not have to be sought by the Department in question, and no doubt there will be a great many instances-I cannot speak for Treasury or one or two others-when departments will not want to or will not get around to identifying the charges that are involved and actually seeking recovery from the individuals concerned. One of the interesting experiences of the existing legislation has been the extent to which departments simply have not charged to the extent that they could have done so under the existing terms of the legislation. No doubt that phenomenon will continue in the future. I will not go so far as to say that working for the FOI applicant is the natural indolence of the bureaucracy when it comes to collecting these things-that would be a quite unfair aspersion-but what one might say is that the combination of the administrative difficulty involved in gathering these charges, combined with the natural instinct of the bureaucracy towards openness and willingness to assist members of the public in their reasonable requests, will be such as to not, in practice I believe, place too overwhelming a burden upon people in just and deserving cases, those cases particularly where there obviously is a financial difficulty involved for the person in paying for the charges that might be incurred.

The final point I make is that there is a real agency accountability that is still maintained in the decision making in this area. The provision for charges to be payable is not an invitation to the agencies to incompetence or oppression on their part. The charge provisions are to a significant extent self-regulatory. Agencies will have to justify publicly their time, not just to the AAT, which raises further objections I have heard about fees for review applications, but also to the Commonwealth Ombudsman. He will have jurisdiction. He does not cost anybody anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank goodness for that. We are about to get a Bill on that, I imagine.

—Not yet, anyway. Those who dither over innocuous documents will be exposed by the Ombudsman, the review procedures, or in other ways. One must work on a presumption of reasonableness as far as the bureaucracy is concerned.
—Why, if this is freedom of information?
—Senator Macklin, let the Minister speak. You may speak later if you wish.
—I am helping him along.
—Senator Macklin, I warn you.
—My goodness! That is all I need to say. It certainly is all I am able to say in response to the contributions that have been made. I urge that the Committee support the amendment accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has advanced four of the most fascinating propositions ever to come forth from a Minister of the Crown about why this matter should be viewed with equanimity. They are: First, that the Australian bureaucracy is open and anxious to help people; secondly, that the charges are not mandatory anyway; thirdly, that even if charges are made, people do not have to pay them if they do not want to; and fourthly, that, after all, the bureaucracy is accountable. I do not think that anybody has ever constructed such a flimsy framework of justification for a particular clause but the Minister deserves considerable credit for having tried so manfully on the basis of those propositions to defend this clause.

SPEECH.PARA: The points that I want to make, however, relate to some of the statistical information in the interdepartmental committee report. Senator Macklin has been using the average time of 11 hours as an example. On page 17 of the inter- departmental committee report the averages for various categories of request are analysed. In terms of the processing times for search retrieval and decisions it says under the averages for various categories of request that for policy documents the average is 56 hours. In other words, a policy document takes an average of 56 hours to be processed through the system. That results in a charge of $616 plus $30 to get into the system in the first place.

The idea that people will not be pursued for the money becomes quite interesting when one looks at the fact that in 1984-85 the Australian Taxation Office had 683 requests for policy documents. If all were taken on the average figure that I have just given, the Tax Office would have been able to charge $441,218. Given the voracity with which the Commissioner of Taxation pursues people for $10 or $20, the temptation on his part to chase up $441,218 will be somewhat greater than is indicated by the dismissive attitude of the Minister towards the open-hearted approach of the Commissioner of Taxation to assisting average citizens to live their lives free from persecution.

The points made by Senator Macklin in that regard stand without having been answered by the Minister. However, two amendments have been made by the chamber on the way through the passage of this legislation, one of which is to delete the multi-document request provision and the other to strengthen the public interest exemption. I think they are significant and hopefully will pull the teeth out of some of the more objectionable implications of this amendment. The other point is that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal certainly will have to lay down some very early rules or guidelines for the bureaucracy about the sort of attitude that it intends to take. It will be necessary to have a couple of early test cases. Hopefully, the AAT will have some impact on departments indicating where they will and will not defend, particularly bearing in mind the suggestion being widely canvassed that the Tribunal ought to have powers to be more flexible in the way it awards costs. I hope that the Tribunal would be in such a position from time to time, particularly where the case at issue was the Department's attempt to deny access, that the Department would end up bearing far more substantial costs.

I know that the Attorney-General's Department has been quite active in trying to persuade departments not to go to court when it is not necessary. Certainly, it has put the onus on departments not necessarily to brief senior counsel to come along with batteries of juniors and so on. There are new mechanisms in place whereby appeals matters are very much filtered through the Attorney-General's Department. That has been a very great contribution by the Department. Nevertheless, Senator Macklin argued about the impact of this legislation on public interest groups. I particularly reject the claim by Senator Evans that many freedom of information users will get some advantage and they should not be subsidised by the rest of the taxpaying public. After all, many requests, particularly those taken out by public interest and advocacy groups for policy documents will be of enormous public benefit on the basis of exposing what government is doing, establishing policy or establishing the facts which are relevant to important public debate. The Minister cannot shelter behind that excuse.

The last matter on which I will comment is that I notice the admission by the Minister that this clause will have a deterrent effect. It is clearly what it is intended to do. Therefore, I conclude only by saying once again that if this matter had come to us in legislation which was not adjudged to be a Budget Bill we would be very much opposed to this new regime of charges. I make it clear that it is only because we accept this legislation as a Budget Bill, that it has been tacked on as a regulation to a Budget Bill--

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you repeal it in office?

—The Minister will not have to wait long to have that question answered. He will have to curb his natural enthusiasm and his patience will have to be tested in that regard. All one can say is that one is aware that that is an attempt by the Minister to overcome the fact that he has made promises which he was not capable of delivering and he seeks to seduce others into doing likewise. While I may be temporarily on the front bench, there are absolutely no guarantees on the matter. Nevertheless, if this legislation had been in a separate document or regulations it would have been opposed by the Opposition. Because we accept it as a Budget measure we will not vote against this clause.

—Regarding this funding or procrastination section, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) raised a point about departments not collecting fees. I ask the Minister two things: First, what discretion has a department not to collect money which is owed and, secondly, are the charges and their computation able to be charged? In other words, I can imagine that one reason why a department would not bother to collect some fees would be if the cost involved in estimating the fees could very well exceed the fees. Can the Minister inform me whether the cost of the time taken to compute the fees that are charged is now able to be charged to the individual?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter point, the answer is clearly no. The terms of the regulation as proposed to be amended extend only to permitting a charge to be made for the time taken in considering a particular document on its face. One could not add that extra component. As to the business about how could the department or agency have some discretion as to whether or not it will pursue these charges, I draw Senator Macklin's attention to regulation 3 (1) of the existing Freedom of Information (Charges) Regulations which is not proposed to be altered in any way by this legislation. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Where an applicant has made a request for access to a document of an agency or an official document of a Minister, the agency or Minister may make a decision whether the applicant is liable to pay in respect of the request . . . any of the charges applicable under these Regulations.

So it is clearly discretionary. There is no doubt about that. It is quite deliberate on the part of the Government. There is no desire to make this mandatory. Everything else I said as a result follows naturally from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am at a loss on this matter. Senator Puplick, who I presume has had access as a committee member to material to which I do not have access, but to which the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) obviously does, made a re-estimate. I was only able to go on a Department of Finance estimate of an average of 11 hours. Senator Puplick's estimate got up to--
—Fifty-six hours for a policy document.
—Thank you. Does the Minister accept that as the accurate average cost we would now be looking at under the freedom of information legislation for a policy document?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The reference that Senator Puplick made was to page 17, paragraph 4.2.5, of the interdepartmental committee report which has been made available to the Committee. The figure of 56 hours for a policy document occurs there but is a reference not just to decision-making time within the meaning of this clause but also to search and retrieval time.
—Is there a breakdown?

—I do not have a breakdown here. There may be a breakdown somewhere else. Why does Senator Macklin not make a freedom of information application for this document and wallow around in it? In 45 days time we will make sure that he gets it, provided that he pays the appropriate charges. I am happy to make this document available in the exercise of my unauthorised discretion to Senator Macklin, provided he agrees to vote on this provision within the next two minutes so that I can get to a meeting.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point that 56 hours is cumulative and covers all these things. It would be recognised that many of the policy documents that have been sought have been quite elaborate and technical in character and have involved a lot of search and retrieval time as well as review time. A further disclaimer is made throughout the IDC document, particularly in paragraph 2.7.1, which is that the statistics on which estimates of FOI costs are based must be treated with some caution. They are based on agency estimates which used a variety of means and sources. Clearly, it is very difficult to get uniformity of data, even with the best will, effort and skill in the world, from the Attorney-General's Department. These figures should be taken as merely indicative rather than in any way as gospel. That apart, I do not think there is anything more I can usefully add to what Senator Macklin has asked me.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Minister is saying, with all the ifs, buts, maybes and shuffles, is that, on average, for a policy document we are looking at about $600.
—If it is asked for.

—I do not imagine that it would cost a penny if it were not asked for, although it could very well do; we will probably get a Bill on that shortly. What we are facing in terms of freedom of information has been clarified. We are facing massive hikes in charges. As I say, clause 27, which the Australian Democrats will vote against, essentially funds procrastination on the part of the bureaucracy. The longer the bureaucracy procrastinates, the more it will cost. To my way of thinking that is the most extraordinary thing we have heard in a long time. I would have thought that the longer it took the bureaucracy to come up with a request, the more a person would be entitled to a discount. He should not have to pay more. Obviously, this provision will effectively stop most ordinary citizens from ever wanting to go anywhere near this legislation again.

— Mr Chairman, I am the last person to want to prolong this debate as I have to be somewhere else, but I think I ought to mention for the record that I should have made a fifth point in explaining and justifying this provision, and that is that the hardship remission provision in section 30 (3) (a) of the existing Act is applicable to this new category of charges as well as to the pre-existing category of charges. That is, the Minister can remit, taking into account whether the payment of the charge or any part of it would cause financial hardship to the applicant in question. That is a further qualification to what Senator Macklin wants to describe as the rigours of this provision and as such it ought to be understood.

—The starry-eyed view of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) of the attitude of the Australian Public Service towards freedom of information is obviously firmly held. I believe that the Minister has answered the questions reasonably well about what will happen to people under this legislation. They will be charged a lot of money if they want any documents. But will this provision also not be an open-ended invitation to the Public Service to procrastinate? This amendment will become known as the procrastination promotion provision. Unless guidelines incorporate Senator Evans's starry-eyed view about why departments should not charge people and all that type of thing, which I would like on the public record if we are to save anything in this freedom of information legislation, I ask the Minister how he will stop this provision from becoming an excuse for procrastination. Departments and agencies would be able to beat their breasts and say: `We are getting more revenue'. The Minister said at the beginning of the Committee stage that this was a cost saving measure and would reduce average costs. Can the Minister tell us what guidelines he will issue to departments to give them the type of `morality' he would like them to have?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether morality can be engendered by guidelines of any kind. The Attorney- General's Department has prepared a series of memos which are guidelines on the administration of existing clauses and sections of the Act and regulations. One such memo gives such guidance to other agencies on the existing charges as they presently apply and all the discretions that are available to departments. That memo will be rewritten as a result of the passage of this legislation and further guidance will be given by the Attorney-General's Department, which is sensitive to many of the considerations that have been advanced here today. I am sure that will, again, moderate some of the rigours that are alleged to exist by virtue of these new provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the Freedom of Information Laws Amendment Bill 1986 on the third reading because either the Opposition does not know the real purpose of the Bill or it is in a cynical conspiracy with the Government to see that Australia reverts to a more absolute rule by bureaucrats. If this Bill passes its third reading, without doubt not only will the bureaucrats' power be extensively increased but also they will have been given an open mandate to deceive, conceal, conspire or do whatever they feel without any recourse by the public to that action. The bureaucrats will know that that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a serious charge to make. I propose to substantiate it by going back to a matter that honourable senators know about quite well-what has been called the Army land grab in New South Wales. The Army attempted to secure large areas of land in the Orange district against the will of the land-holders there, and this resulted in probably the most successful and best organised citizen protest that has ever been carried out in this country. I was at the final victory dinner of the No Bases Committee in Orange not two months ago. At that meeting, the main topic of conversation of virtually all of the 400 people there was that this Bill, which is virtually passing the Senate, represented a result of that exercise; that because of that exercise and the facts that the Government and the Department of Defence were literally found to be in a state of lying and that a citizen group had succeeded in exposing those lies for what they were, these amendments to the legislation have come forward. I believe that is the purpose of this exercise. This amending Bill is intended to make it virtually impossible for any public interest groups-peace groups, farmer groups or anyone of that type-ever to have recourse to freedom of information provisions.

It is another piece of tinkering which has become very popular with government, not only in this country but also in others. They fool the public by appearing to have legislation to do something and then they tinker with it until it does not do that type of thing any more. Believe me, if this Bill receives a third reading there will no longer be freedom of information machinery in Australia. That is what it means; it is being destroyed. I am very concerned that it is being destroyed by apparent agreement among the National, Liberal and Labor parties. Going back many years, I remember the long and bitter debate during the term of the Fraser Government over the introduction of the Freedom of Information Bill. Senator Gareth Evans fought inch by inch for every amendment he could possibly get. Now what has happened? The conclusion now is that we are going to destroy the freedom of information machinery. I will illustrate this by quoting extensively from a letter to Senator Haines from Mr Tim Robertson, the Secretary of the Council for Civil Liberties, describing how the Defence Department behaved and what happened when freedom of information legislation, especially section 24, was used.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason, I remind you that you are not permitted to rehash arguments that have already been put to the Senate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, my request is to quote from a letter which has been sent to the Australian Democrats by a constituent which has a bearing on this matter. To my knowledge it has not been raised previously in the debate.
—I shall watch that point very carefully.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I think this is of vital consideration because it illustrates more than anything possibly could the damaging effects of this Bill. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In July 1985 the No Base Central Tablelands Association requested of the Department of Defence all documents relating to the Army Training Facilities Project. The Department replied that it was relying on s. 24 to refuse to process the request, and invited the Association to narrow it down.

Section 24 was that provision put into the Freedom of Information Act to protect public servants, properly, against silly, unusual or facetious requests for documents. This request was not in that category. Even before these amendments, section 24 was abused. I continue to quote from Mr Robertson's letter:

As the Association's lawyer I rang the appropriate officer of the Department to engage in ``consultation'' on that request. I asked for the names and numbers of the files held in Army Office and Defence Facilities Divisions of the Department on the Project, so that we could request specific files-
I would have thought that was a reasonable request-

. . . and therefore exclude from the request the many copy documents that were floating around other parts of the Department. I was informed that the Department was under no obligation to give me any information concerning the nature, quantity or description of any of its files. Without that information it was of course impossible to narrow the request.
Accordingly, I decided to draft a request that would not fall within s. 24--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Mason, you are out of order. You must relate your speech on the third reading to the Bill. It cannot be a second reading type of speech. In my opinion you are not relating your speech to the Bill at all. I ask you to address your remarks to the Bill.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, should I take you to have ruled that I may not quote this example which seems to be a precise example of what is actually in this Bill? Remember that it is section 24 that has been amended in this Bill, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—You must relate your remarks to the Bill. You are entirely out of order. I ask you to talk to the Bill.

—I relate these statements precisely to the amendments to section 24 of the Act. I repeat that point: Everything I say or quote is relevant and relates to amendments in this Senate to section 24 of the Act.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. By virtue of the passage of the Opposition's amendment, there are no amendments to section 24 of the Act.

—I uphold the point of order. Senator Mason, you must relate your remarks to the Committee stage. The amendments were dealt with in the Committee stage and your remarks at the third reading stage must relate to that. You must not make a second reading type of speech and your remarks must relate to the Committee stage. I make that ruling and I ask you to confine your remarks in that way.

—The amendments to section 24 of the original legislation-I am obliged to Senator Puplick-were dealt with extensively by Democrat spokesmen, I know, in the Committee stage of the Bill. I support their view and reiterate it at this stage. Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to continue to quote from Mr Robertson's letter because I believe it is relevant to this Bill and to what has been done. I most seriously ask you whether you rule against my continuing to quote from it.

—Yes, I must. It does not relate to the Committee stage and I have to rule against that. You may quote it on the adjournment or at some other time but in the third reading debate you simply must relate your remarks to the Committee stage. You cannot make a second reading type of speech.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek clarification of that ruling. I am afraid we might be creating a precedent which will limit debate in this place. A speech at the third reading stage does not allow the introduction of new material, I would take it, as far as I can recall. I am even doubtful on that, but I thought the third reading stage gave an opportunity for honourable senators to put a point of view that they had not previously put and to recap some of the material that had come before the chamber. If we are to limit the third reading debate to only what has happened in the Committee stage it will lose a considerable amount of its worth to members and senators. Later, at a quarter to one, I shall raise a matter concerning the way in which the procedures in this place have so altered that the rights of members are becoming limited. I do not think you intend by your ruling that the ability of an honourable senator who raises matters at the third reading stage be further limited, in addition to what has occurred because of changes in the procedures of this House.
—What about if an honourable senator was not present for the Committee stage?

—Yes, there are a number of reasons why the third reading is provided as an opportunity to speak. It could enable an honourable senator who was absent from the chamber on other work within Parliament House to speak on the subject.
—That is not a point of order. I simply ask Senator Mason to relate his remarks to the principles of the Bill. This is the third reading stage and not the second reading stage.

—As a point of explanation, Mr Acting Deputy President, I have risen at the third reading stage at the suggestion of the Chairman of Committees. I raised the matter in the Committee stage. The relevant clause was dealt with last night while I was not here, for good reasons.
