The Chairman of Committees properly reminded me that I ought not to press the matter in the Committee stage and suggested that I raise it at the third reading, which indeed is what I am doing. However, with respect, I accept your ruling and I will not continue to quote from Mr Robertson's letter, or its penultimate point, which I think is of vital importance in this debate, and in the circumstances I shall continue by asking honourable senators to come to me at some later stage so that I can provide them with copies of the letter.
—Oh, no, that is not satisfactory.

—No, I do not find it so. I would like honourable senators to see the letter. Of course the Bill will have passed by then. I am greatly concerned. All I can say at this stage is that I implore the Opposition to reconsider its position and to join the Australian Democrats in voting against the third reading of this Bill because it is a destructive Bill. The whole debate during the Committee stage has illustrated that point. The admissions of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) during the Committee stage have made it absolutely plain that it will be virtually impossible for any public interest group to afford to institute any kind of freedom of information inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation was put in place in this country because the need for that sort of thing, and for bureaucrats to be responsible for what they do, was evident. What are we doing now? We will, provided this third reading stage is passed, hand it back to the bureaucracy. It will be able to act irresponsibly, without any responsibility to this Parliament or anybody else. The bureaucracy has been put in an ivory tower where nothing can be done to touch it. Every department that has a filing system that is in disarray will be able to say: `This is too much trouble'. An inefficient government department will be able to conceal its inefficiency and will be able to say `We can't give you this. It is too much trouble', or `it will cause an inordinate amount of work'. Honourable senators will know that that is the effect of the amendments to section 24 of the original Act. Delays, costs of an impossible nature and, as some of my colleagues have said during the Committee stage of the Bill, a virtual impossibility for any interest group or individual to know in advance what it will cost them to carry out some freedom of information inquiry, make this, to my mind, one of the most cynical, one of the most despicable and one of the most deceptive pieces of legislation ever perpetrated on the unfortunate people of this country.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 October, on motion by Senator Ryan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1986. The legislation has been introduced within the context of the statement by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) in the last week or so about what she has called Austudy, the Government's new proposal for student support generally. But let us put that to one side for a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: In short, the Student Assistance Amendment Bill which is now before the Senate does only three things. First, it widens the definition of a student to include secondary students, mainly by deleting the word tertiary wherever it appears and allowing secondary students to be considered as students for the purpose of this Bill. Secondly, in proposed new Part III the incidentals allowance is deleted. That allowance is now absorbed into the higher allowance rate at the tertiary level. The Opposition has no concern about that. Thirdly, the Bill provides certain transitional arrangements. For example, it tightens up certain double dipping arrangements which existed between student assistance and the Social Security Act, and we have no objection to that. All the substantial elements of Austudy, which were announced by the Minister for Education in her statement, are taken up not within this Bill, which is a fairly small piece of legislation, but within the appropriate regulations which are made under the amended legislation. The existing regulations are very substantial. Most of the changes will take place by regulation, not legislation.

The Bill sets out to do some quite significant things. It sets out to amend the principal Act to provide for the granting of assistance to students in secondary education. The current provisions limit student assistance under this Act to students enrolled in universities, colleges of advanced education and certain students in technical and further education colleges. The amendment Bill will be the legislative framework to achieve that change and for regulations to be made to introduce the Austudy scheme. They will allow the establishment of a single scheme of assistance covering both secondary and tertiary students. We do not have any concerns with that.

The Austudy scheme has arisen from considerable work which has been done and considerable disquiet which has been expressed about the disincentive effects of unemployment benefits as they relate to educational benefits. As early as 1983 the Beswick report on Studies of Tertiary Student Finances-I think I commissioned it when Minister-advocated equating the rates payable under the unemployment benefit and the rates payable under student assistance at the tertiary level. Honourable senators will be aware that those rates have always been different and are different today for most students. It was thought desirable that they should be brought together because a perverse incentive has existed for young Australians, when given the choice, to follow the money, to take unemployment benefit, which was the higher rate, rather than to undertake further study and take a lower rate of educational benefit. So the Beswick report, as early as 1983, recommended that the rates should be brought together.

The policy document, which the Liberal and National parties took to the 1984 election-as shadow Minister for Education I produced that document-actually advocated, as policy, that those two rates be brought together. We could see the wisdom of what the Beswick report recommended; we could see the foolishness of the perverse incentive and we thought the rates should be brought together. There have been further reports, such as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development review of youth policy in Australia and those prepared by the social welfare policy secretariat, and they have all recommended widening the scope of education benefits generally to include all people in post-compulsory education in Australia. The Austudy proposal-let us forget the name `Austudy,' which is a jargon name-attempts to put some of those recommendations into effect. It was introduced as part of the Government's Priority One: Young Australia strategy.

Briefly, what is proposed is that from the age of 16 years there will be an allowance structure based on age-I will come back to that matter-with higher rates applying from the age of 18 years. It will be phased in so that from 1989 the student assistance rates and the unemployment benefit rates will be aligned for each group. It will take a couple of years for that to happen. It has further been proposed in this legislation that the Austudy allowances, like unemployment benefits, should be paid directly to student beneficiaries. This represents a very significant change from existing support. At present students in years 11 and 12-the senior levels of secondary schooling-could, if their families have qualified by income, draw benefits from the secondary allowance scheme under which assistance in respect of secondary students is paid to parents or legal guardians of the students. That measure was introduced, promoted and expanded in an attempt to help families who may be needy to encourage young Australians to stay in schooling. This Bill proposes to change that to pay the benefit directly to the students. Certainly two issues immediately arise from this legislation. They are the payment of money directly to students rather than to families and the qualification by age rather than by level of study undertaken; for example, it is a move from the senior levels of secondary study back to age 16 years, and that raises some problems.

The Opposition does not oppose this legislation; we will support it. However, we are concerned about those two matters to which I have referred. We are not concerned about, in fact we applaud and support, the proposal to bring together the unemployment benefit level and the student allowance level. We think the difference between them, which acts to the disadvantage of education, has been unfortunate. We do not support it and we are glad to see that it is being attended to in this legislation. However, we are concerned about the other two matters to which I have referred. First there is the question of benefits being paid directly to students rather than to parents. The Government is, to some extent, in a cleft stick because while the benefits are paid to parents or legal guardians, to families of students in years 11 and 12, the student may say: `There is no benefit to me accruing from the payment of this benefit and therefore I might leave school and take the dole which is paid directly into my hands'. That is not just a theoretical possibility. At one time I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and had the unpleasant experience of knowing of examples within the Aboriginal community in western New South Wales where some bright young students, who should have gone on to years 11 and 12 in school, actually took that decision. They said, quite openly: `If we leave school we get the money. If we stay at school other people get the money.' So, they took the opportunity of leaving school and taking the money in their hands. Of course it was to their long term disadvantage.

The Opposition is concerned that one of the reasons the secondary allowances scheme was introduced was to try to help families in need to support the minors who were still in schooling to go on through years 11 and 12 even though that family was in need. If the allowance were paid directly to the student and if the family does not get the allowance and the family now has to rely upon payment of family allowance, upon maybe family income support payments, one of the benefits of the SAS would be lost immediately. It seems from what I have read that one of the stimuli to students staying on at school, completing years 11 and 12, adding to the pool of skill available to Australia and helping to produce a better retention rate through year 12 is the influence of family advice and family counselling upon their children.

It seemed to us that each time we increased secondary allowance payments-in the 1982 Budget we were able to get a very significant increase; I have an idea that it was 40 or 45 per cent-that was followed by considerably increased interest in the benefit from families in the community and by increased take-up of the benefit. We have no doubt that the result was that children within families were being given advice to stay at school because if they did their families could draw the benefit and would be able to see it through financially. There is no doubt that having a student at school in the post-compulsory years represents a financial dilemma for some families. If they encourage the student to leave school extra money may come into the household. If the student stays at school the amount of money coming into the household may be less but the family may be planning for a longer term benefit.

The Opposition believes that most of the students we are talking about-students in years 11 and 12-are still minors. Most of them are 15, 16 and 17 years old. Some of them, of course, will be 18 years old. They will be adult in that sense. But the ones who are 15, 16 and 17 years old are still minors. We still look to families to support those students where family structures are adequate. We believe that the arrangement under which this benefit is paid to parents or legal guardians in respect of students is a better arrangement. It is an arrangement which we would like to see continue. I indicate now to the Minister that during the Committee stage we will move an appropriate amendment to seek to retain that provision so that the benefits, which we welcome, can be paid to the parents or legal guardian in respect of minors and particularly in respect of those children in years 11 and 12, as is being done now. If there is a good educational reason-not just a reason of convenience of administration of the unemployment benefit-for changing the payment from families to the student, we would like to hear it from the Minister in due course.

The other matter I wish to refer to is the question of moving from qualification by level of education to qualification by age. This proposal presents us with a different set of difficulties. We understand that the present proposal by the Government to pay a benefit to 16-year-olds-I take it that it will not apply to all 16-year-olds; it will apply only to students who qualify in terms of income-will bring an extra 38,000 students within the purview of the benefit. I would like that point clarified. If we did not move to an age qualification but retained the present educational qualification, there would actually be a cost saving to the Government. If we simply said, as we do now, that the parents and guardians of students who stay on in years 11 and 12 should be able to apply for access to this benefit, there would be a cost saving over what the Government is proposing now.

The difficulty is that this is not just a black or white, clear-cut problem. I can well remember some of the difficulties we had involving 17-year-old students who planned to go back to years 9 or 10 because they wanted to take up the education that they had missed. Of course, under the present rules, a student of 17 years of age, who is not an independent adult and who went back to school to undertake study in years 9 and 10, could not qualify for access to this allowance because it applies only to years 11 and 12. So we see that the Government, by turning to this age qualification, may in fact be helping a group of people who need to be helped. But I think the Government will have to acknowledge that it will also be disadvantaging another group of students. The fact is-and I believe other senators will draw attention to it-that many students who are only 15 years old and presently qualify because they are in year 11 will lose their qualification for this benefit if the Government's proposal goes through. The Government's proposal says that they must be 16 years old. What will happen to the 15-year-olds who are in year 11 in States like Western Australia-in fact, in most States in Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —And South Australia.

—I hope that my colleague Senator Teague will participate in this debate and make this point because we have some very interesting correspondence in relation to South Australia. If the Government's plans are put into effect, people who have access to this benefit at the moment will lose that benefit. We want the Government to explain why this is being done. How will the Government explain this change to the families of students who lose access to a benefit which they now receive. Surely the Government should be trying to ensure that more Australians complete their schooling and more Australians go on to undertake further education. The difficulty we see is the considerable extra costs that will be involved if we try to take the best of both schemes, if we try to retain the present entitlement based on academic qualifications-that is, for years 11 and 12-and if we try to add to that the benefits of what the Government is trying to do by bringing in the 16-year-olds who would not otherwise have qualified. The Opposition finds this a very difficult matter to address.

SPEECH.PARA: I would indicate that we have some sympathy for what the Government is trying to achieve. But we have considerable disquiet about this legislation, and we will be looking for explanations from the Minister at the Committee stage. Since the Minister is not in the chamber at the moment, we may repeat these arguments when the Bill is being considered at the Committee stage. We will be seeking from her explanations about the people who will actually face disadvantage, who will actually lose access to a benefit as a result of these changes.

I have indicated that it is the view of the Opposition that this legislation will not be opposed by us. While we support most of the changes, we draw one exception. We are not in support of the proposal to move the payment from parents or legal guardians to students of age 16 or 17 years. We will move an amendment to try to give effect to that view. We are going to seek more information from the Minister in relation to the consequences of her decision to move payments to secondary students from those in years 11 and 12 to those who qualify by age alone. We see some quite significant problems in this area which, as far as we are concerned, are unanswered, unresolved and unexplained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1986 introduces changes which are of major importance to students and the families of students. It gives me a lot of pleasure to speak on this Bill, which constitutes a real step forward in assisting students. Of course, it also offers long term benefits in terms of social effects on employment patterns and the reduction of social inequities. This legislation also means a lot to me personally because for a number of years before coming to the Senate I was a student counsellor in a high school and dealt with the very real problems facing students who wanted to stay at school but whose choice was made difficult or impossible through poverty or through family difficulties which had forced young people on to their own resources.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past, student allowances have been related not only to income-certainly they should be so related-but also to the place where the student was studying. Thus in 1983, when I left my work in student counselling, the weekly rate for a secondary student who received the full allowance was $16.70-a grossly insufficient sum to live on-and there was no extra allowance for those living away from home. In contrast, the maximum tertiary education rate was $38.55 at home and $59.45 for students living away from home. So a student undertaking a business course at a high school had to try to exist on less than $17 a week, while the student doing a similar course at a business college or a technical and further education college could receive more than double that allowance even if he or she were living at home and much more if living away from home. In my experience, this had adverse educational effects in many cases where the high school was offering a course which included at the year 11 level academic subjects such as year 11 English, economics, and accounting, which would increase the students' chances of a job compared with those of students who had done a business college or TAFE course, although the students' financial needs would force them to transfer to another school just to obtain an allowance on which they could try to exist. Further, since the allowance was related to the level of study and the type of institution in which the student was enrolled, there was no adjustment for the age of the student.

This legislation introduces an Austudy allowance which will replace three former schemes-the tertiary education assistance scheme, which most people know as `TEAS'; the adult secondary education assistance scheme, which had its own problems in respect of the definition of `adult', so some students in particular age groups fell between two schemes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventeen-year-olds.

—Seventeen-year-olds mainly and older students at various stages of the scheme's history. The third is the secondary allowance scheme, which obviously deals with secondary students. The Austudy scheme will come into operation at the beginning of next year and is expected to assist about 238,000 students compared to an estimated 187,000 students receiving benefits this year in total under the three schemes it replaces. Austudy will make available allowances to all eligible students aged 16 years and over undertaking full time secondary or tertiary studies, thus removing the anomalies to which I referred previously. There will be two rates of allowance: One for 16- to 17-year-olds and the other higher rate for those who are 18 years or over.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the next three years the maximum Austudy allowance will be progressively increased to bring it into line with the unemployment benefit so that by 1989 the relevant rates for young people of the same age will be equal. That is a very important reform as it will go a long way towards eliminating the disincentive for young people to remain in education, and I will return to that issue later. When this new allowance structure is in place there will be indexation both of allowances and of income test levels to ensure that the real value of the allowance is not eroded. As with the existing schemes, there will be gradual tapering down from the maximum payment. In 1987 the cut-off point will be from $23,894, where there is one secondary student involved, through to $45,914 where there are two tertiary students living away from home. The cut-off points are higher for the 18 years and over age group.

In 1987 there will be an increased rate of allowance for nearly all students and no present student will be worse off. As I said before, all rates will increase in 1988 towards parity with the unemployment benefit. The maximum income test will be raised by 5 per cent in 1987 to ensure that recipients of Austudy allowances will not be penalised by rises in income levels in the community. In other words, they will be indexed. Students presently receiving the secondary allowance or TEAS in 1986, who are still under the age of 16 years at the beginning of 1987, will be covered by transitional arrangements.

Another important change is that the payments will be made to the student rather than to the parent or guardian. Here I would disagree with the previous speaker, Senator Peter Baume. From my own experience as a student counsellor I believe this is a very important step towards independence for many young people which will remove a source of friction for a small group of families-I emphasise that it is a small group-where parents sometimes use this payment as a form of emotional or financial blackmail of their sons or daughters. It has also been my experience as a parent as well as a counsellor that young people respond very positively to managing their own finances. I believe it has been anomalous that in the past a student in secondary school was kept dependent on parents in this way while the young person of the same age who was working or in tertiary education could be responsible for his or her own financial arrangements.

Payments will be made fortnightly, and that is also important. Previously TEAS and the adult secondary allowances have been paid monthly and the secondary allowances have been paid by the term. This has meant very real hardship for students waiting for the first payment and has also been a financial burden for those many schools, such as the high school where I worked, which deferred charges for school requisites until the payment was received and thereby had to wait a full term for that payment. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That, unless otherwise ordered, till 2 p.m. this day, matters of public interest may be discussed by senators, provided that no senator shall speak for more than 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to raise a matter at this time but I am somewhat constrained by the new arrangements that have been introduced into the Senate. I do not wish to canvass the decision of the Senate to remove, in fact, the facility of senators to speak on the first reading of money Bills and replace it by a period discussing matters called public interest between quarter to one and 2 o'clock on a Thursday. The first reading speeches, of course, on the money Bills allowed senators to raise matters which they considered to be urgent.
—They still can, you know.

—On the first reading? It is by arrangement then that this procedure is now being followed where we have dispensed, by agreement, with the first reading speeches in order to talk of matters of public interest. It is fairly obvious from what Senator Grimes says that perhaps I am not fully aware of the procedures. That is the problem of being diverted from parliamentary work in the House by committee work in other places, at times both when we are entitled to meet and when we are not entitled to meet. In any case, I should not apologise for my lack of knowledge of the new arrangements. Let me merely say that there is a further understanding during this period that no matter of a controversial nature shall be raised.

SPEECH.PARA: I am about to raise a matter which was a matter of controversy and which was raised during a public interest debate on one occasion by the then Senator Primmer. Having in mind that it may also again become of a controversial nature because of my contribution I sought to speak to Senator Chaney prior to this debate to inform him that I was going to raise the matter of his placing on the Notice Paper yesterday and making a matter of Senate business two documents, apologies by ex-Senator Primmer to a Mr Henderson and a Mr Bowden. I wished to advise him that I had certain comments to make on that. Unfortunately Senator Chaney was not available at the time I called and I also found out that he has another engagement, an official engagement, to fulfil. Therefore I will not expand on the matter as perhaps I would like to.

I would also say to the Senate that I am under a further constraint as the matter has been placed on the Notice Paper and, in effect, that somewhat limits my ability to speak on it at this stage. The matter is on the Notice Paper and if I were, say, in a position to object I would object if any senator endeavoured to speak on a matter that has been properly placed on the Notice Paper. There is a possibility that it could be discussed in the adjournment debate.

Let me get to the matter which arose when notice of motions Nos 426 and 427 was given by Senator Chaney yesterday. It was an unusual procedure for a senator to place on notice two apologies made outside the House in connection with a certain matter that was before the courts. I regret that Senator Chaney did so because it reopens a whole debate. It is unfortunate that it should open again the whole debate because there are many of us in this House who were aware of the circumstances of Senator Primmer's statements in the House and his one or two subsequent comments referring to his statements in the House which led to an action by a Mr Henderson and a Mr Bowden. That should be a warning to all members of the Senate that they should be extremely careful in what they say in the House. They may be obliged to say it in the public interest, as I think Senator Primmer did.

One has to be very, very careful about what is said concerning a matter outside the House, even in referring to what was said in the House, to give further currency to the matter and to the statement. In this particular case it led to a defamation action being taken by Mr Bowden and Mr Henderson against Senator Primmer for statements that he made inside the House and to which he referred outside the House. Senator Chaney is lawyer enough to understand, I do not doubt, and others who are lawyers here would understand, that often a defamation case becomes a test between the two litigants and the test is who has the strongest will and who has the greater purse.

Some of us were aware of the pressures being brought against Senator Primmer and the pressures were considerable to the point where they affected Senator Primmer's personal life. One could argue that perhaps it was brought upon himself but it did seriously affect his personal life in a rather drastic way. It also affected his financial position in that he had to put in a defence. My experience in this place has been that defences against actions are costly. Sometimes the actions are frivolous. Sometimes they are a test of, as I said, will and financial resolve.

It was suggested to Senator Primmer that we should take the matter up in the House to explain the pressures that were being brought to bear on him. Senator Primmer took the view that it ought not to be done, that he wanted an end to the matter, that he had reached the stage where he wanted it to go away. He could not withstand the pressure; he could not withstand the worry and the matter was starting to affect seriously his personal position and his health. So we did not take the matter up. We did not take the matter up to justify further the position that Senator Primmer had taken at that time because there were other sources of information and other honourable senators were familiar with what was going on within the Department of Foreign Affairs; not in particular relation to this matter, but in a number of other matters.

There were problems in the Department of Foreign Affairs which stemmed from the head of the Department right down to ordinary staff. I have had personal experience of that. I raised it on the Public Accounts Committee at one stage. I was concerned about the intimidation, the pressure, and the harassment of employees by the head of the Department at that stage. Nevertheless, it was decided not to reopen the matter and to let the whole matter go away. Ex-Senator Primmer decided against his better judgment, because of reasons that I have mentioned, to come to an arrangement and to tender an apology. The apology was published in the Press. Mr Henderson had the opportunity on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program-it was also party to the defamation case-to express his gratitude that the matter was over and to indicate that he felt free of the difficulties which had been imposed upon him.

He was entitled, of course, to say that and he was entitled to his defence. Those of us who were privy to the matter were satisfied to let it rest. Now Senator Chaney has placed it on the Notice Paper. Senator Chaney has now made it a matter for debate. Senator Chaney has now made it possible for us to defend Senator Primmer and to explain the circumstances of the apology; to explain that the apology was made under economic duress and must be considered in that light. That would not have been necessary if Senator Chaney had not, for a reason known only to himself, placed it on the Notice Paper.

Why do I speak at this stage instead of speaking later? It has gone on to the Notice Paper as notices of motion Nos 246 and 247, possibly to be buried for months, perhaps never even to reach the Senate unless action is taken to bring it forward. What has happened as a result of the notices being put down, the usual action taken by Senator Chaney? Further currency has been given to the apology in every newspaper that I have read this morning. In the Courier-Mail I notice a substantial argument, which spreads ex-Senator Primmer's apology across its pages. It is not the intention, perhaps, that Senator Primmer had in mind. I believe that he may have made other arrangements, even to his own disadvantage, to take the matter to the courts, because he had a defence. He had a defence of privilege and he had a defence of fact. He decided that he just could not face that tortuous and expensive path.

The apology received was printed in several newspapers at the time it was made. But I do not think ex-Senator Primmer, those who defended him, or those who had further information to give, expected that the matter should be so treated that it gave widespread coverage to his apology. For that reason, I stand to explain the circumstances of the apology. By making references to the apology and the way that it was given we have then to reopen the matters which Senator Primmer raised. I am not happy about raising those matters again. There are certain times when matters are brought to debate and sometimes, shall we say, some heat is engendered, some charges are made and then it becomes the news of yesterday. That is the way this matter should have rested in the best interests of Mr Henderson, Mr Bowden and ex-Senator Primmer. But that is not the case now. I regret that I have to restate that the apology must be considered in the light that it was given under substantial personal and financial pressure against a person who would not otherwise have apologised.

Senator Chaney possibly would like to respond to what I have said, I reiterate that I regret that he has raised the matter again. He may have some reason to have brought the matter forward. He may have felt so strongly about the charges which Senator Primmer had made and the manner in which they were made. I think Senator Chaney was particularly vocal at the time about it, and perhaps justifiably so, having in mind the charges that were being made. But let me say that when you look at what Senator Primmer was saying, he was justified because of subsequent results.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the matter raised by Senator Georges. First of all, I make plain that what Senator Chaney did yesterday was an attempt to achieve bipartisanship in this chamber and it followed discussions with three Ministers, including the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). The intention that Senator Chaney expressed was simple enough: That a matter which had occupied this chamber enormously over a period of two and a half years and had gone on after that for another two years, a matter which had captured the attention of the Press dozens and dozens of times throughout Australia and had come from this chamber, must find its final resting place in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I do hope that Senator Georges will accept these statements I am making. Senator Georges must know-if I may say this to him-that I intervened many times with Senator Primmer to try to see that this matter never got to this stage; so I say this with the best of good will in the world. The fact is that the matter had occupied 200 questions on notice, was well advertised in the media throughout Australia, had been the subject of 12 statements here by the then Senator Primmer and statements by the Ministers for Foreign Affairs of both a previous Liberal Government and the present Labor Government; it had massive investigations and had to find its resting place in the end in the Parliament from which it was initiated and in which the seed bed of its growth developed.

The intention was very simple indeed. The intention and the hope were that there would be quite objective speeches on both sides of the Parliament. I remind Senator Georges that the approach to Senator Primmer was a bipartisan one. Both Labor and Liberal governments had reached the same conclusions. Both Labor and Liberal governments had made investigations. The then Attorney-General had made it perfectly clear in the Senate where his Government stood. The then Attorney-General had expressed the view in the Senate that Senator Primmer had exceeded the bounds of privilege in this place. All that is documented. It was intended to find a way of putting into the record the statements of apology and was hoped that the matter then would rest. Let me put an old fashioned view to Senator Georges: We have in this community two places in which one can find justice and equity; this place with its rules, and in the courts of law.

It is an old fashioned matter of principle that when one has recourse to one of those places and reaches a result, one obeys the umpire's decisions. There has been recourse. Simply then, Senator Primmer took his independent opportunities in this chamber many, many times and therefore made himself subject to examination for doing it. He went further and in public committed his comments. He therefore is subject to the ordinary events of the law and the processes of the law. I do not think it is indeed in the ordinary course of justice to be able to come in here now and to try to denigrate an apology on the basis that there was some duress in it. I have never heard that kind of situation expressed. It gets to the very roots of a challenge to our principle of justice.

The fact of the matter is that, as ex-Senator Primmer signed these statements, he knew that in fact they should be read for what they are, not be read as a result of having some pressure exerted on him at all. Are we now to say that he does not believe what he says?

TALK.START.PARA: —What I say.

—With great respect to Senator Georges, and I respect and admire him for many of his principles and for his willingness to support a friend, let me say this: He may be doing great damage to his friend by the journey on which he takes himself. Senator Georges cannot put into a legal apology, a settlement which is endorsed in the courts of law, any kind of interpretation other than what ex-Senator Primmer says in the statements. Both the statements are unequivocal apologies. Both of them are absolute apologies and, in fact, they say that the many charges that he had made he has now found out were based on bad information, were untrue and that exhaustive investigations had found them to be so.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no purpose in a court of law, there is no purpose in coming together in an agreement if one is going to say, `You must not read this apology for what it is, behind it is another reason.' The fact is that if that were said outside it would put the present Mr Cyril Primmer in very great peril and I do urge that this not be committed here. The fact of the matter is that we have had Senator Gareth Evans, time after time in this place, saying that there was no evidence to support the then Senator Primmer, saying that there were in fact breaches of privilege. One could go to Hansard and recall these things. One has had the fair play. How much more does one want than both sides of politics having the opportunity through their Ministers for Foreign Affairs to make investigations, to look behind the evidence, and to come out with their statements? How much more does one want than to invite Cyril Primmer to give the evidence, have it examined and have it tested?

If the present Government and the present Opposition members say `We have done this and we find no evidence,' how much more do we want then for the opportunity for this to be tested in a court of law, and indeed, then to have a completely unequivocal statement made? Now the suggestion is that the statement does not mean what it says. I put it to Senator Georges that he is on a perilous journey. I ask him not to proceed on that journey, in the interests of his friend. His friend has said quite clearly now that what he had done had been proven to be untrue.
It is very important indeed to understand what he has said. I invite the Senate to listen to the terms of the apology to Mr Bowden:

I withdraw without reservation or qualification all accusations, allegations and innuendos which I have at any time made within and outside the Parliament, against Ivor Gordon Bowden, an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs, formerly Australian Ambassador to Iran and Australian Commissioner in Hong Kong and currently serving as Australian Ambassador to Pakistan. While I acted in good faith, I acknowledge that I produced no evidence to sustain these attacks and that successive, competent investigations, whose verdict I unreservedly accept, have on each occasion cleared his name. I regret and apologise sincerely for the distress which these unwarranted attacks have caused him and his family and for any damage which these attacks including those contained in the letter I wrote to the Head of State of Pakistan on Mr Bowden's appointment as Ambassador may have done to his career and to his standing in the community.

That is a totally unequivocal statement. If it had not been raised today, that item would never have come up for debate in this place. The apologies would have been put in the Senate records; they would have been read by the people of Australia; there would have been no need for a debate; everyone would have understood that Mr Hayden and Senator Gareth Evans and the members of their Government had made their investigations and had reached a conclusion, as Mr Street and the Fraser Government had done. Everyone would have been satisfied that what ex-Senator Cyril Primmer had done in a manly fashion had put an end to the matter. I wish it had rested at that. I understand that Senator Georges did not consult his people to find out the discussions had happened. He would have found that we had said to the Ministers: `We want a bipartisan approach on this. We do not want any vexatious debate on this. We do not want this matter to be opened up, it can do nobody any good. We believe in the legal processes, we rest on the legal processes. What a pity indeed that this should have happened?

It is a first-class situation now if it is left at this, because we have had an unequivocal clearing of the good names of Mr Peter Henderson and Mr Bowden. I only wish that Sir Nicholas Parkinson could have had just a similar kind of statement. I regard it as outrageous to have suggested that there was anything improper in the retirement of Sir Nicholas Parkinson, when everybody knows that his medical condition regarding his eyesight was of a perilous nature. I rise here simply to say that. I plead with Senator Georges to accept that we approached in good faith the Ministers of his Government and expressed the fact that since the matter had been born in this place, nurtured in this place, and spread to the four winds through the media in this place, by the then Senator Primmer, it is very proper indeed that the wording of these apologies should come to rest in this place.

We expressed the view that any debate at all ought to be a debate that was not vexatious, that was bipartisan and would put the matter to rest. The last thing in this world that one would want to do, either for Cyril Primmer or anyone else, is to look behind an apology and to put meaning into it which can never be there. In a court of law these kinds of agreements mean what they say in plain words, and it is not for any of us to presume to alter the course of justice in this regard. It is bad enough to have the abuse of privilege here. It is bad enough indeed, and one would hope that never again in this place would privilege be used to the extent that it was done in that regard. I quote Senator Gareth Evans:

Senator Primmer has just stated that he believes on this occasion, as on others on which he has canvassed the same topic, that he has not abused parliamentary privilege. Others will have a different view.
That is pretty clear. Again I quote:
It is not right that there should be a capacity within Parliament to injure reputations carelessly and indefensibly without any form of redress or at least a reply being available.

I could go on and quote and quote. A matter which ranged over two and a half years of Senator Cyril Primmer's occupancy of this place, 200 questions, 12 statements, and investigations, has come to rest in legal statements and settlements. Let us leave it at that. Men's reputations which had been sullied are now cleared. It is for us who believe in British justice to uphold that, to uphold what the plain meaning of the words is and to rejoice in the fact that good men have been found to have been men of high reputations and their reputations stand and that nothing that has been said in the past has sullied them in any way. I do hope that we will leave it at that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been inadvertently misrepresented.
—I would not have done it intentionally.

—Yes. Inadvertently I have been misrepresented and it does not concern me personally, but I want to make it fairly clear that nothing in what I said can be taken to mean ex-Senator Primmer has the view that I have. It must be fairly clear. There has been no consultation, no discussion, no communication with ex-Senator Primmer. It is my view that what has happened happened in the way that I have expressed it, not Senator Primmer's. I want to make that particularly clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate to address an issue which I feel honourable senators and all members of parliament ought to note and that is the issue of overregulation and the economy of Australia. The difficulties that many families find themselves in, I think, make it essential that the process of government should give a top priority to the means of reducing costs to the consumer of items where, indeed, those are caused by acts of government. It is notorious, of course, that acts of government cause enormous costs to the consumer.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak on the issue of overregulation as it affects the sale of margarine. It is a classic example, important in its own way, because although it is impossible to quantify a precise figure, it is a fact that every family in Australia pays unnecessarily 5c, 10c possibly more, for every container of margarine that they buy. As early as 1905 there were discussions in this country about the need to adopt model food laws throughout Australia and 80 years have passed without anything really having been achieved in that regard. The Confederation of Australian Industry, when discussing the need for uniform business legislation, has indeed stated that uniform food legislation is its No. 1 priority. In fact, CAI has estimated that in the decade to 1985 Australian consumers paid an extra half billion dollars in food prices due solely to conflicting State legislation. That, I think, should be a pointer to the Commonwealth Government to immediately set into train consultations with the States to see whether this question of uniform food legislation cannot be brought back into the meeting hall so that at least in the future the public will know that those sorts of things are no longer a problem.

Margarine is a classic example. As background, there are two major margarine manufacturers in this country: Goodman's Fielder, which accounts for about two-thirds of the market, and Unilever Australia Ltd, catering for the other third. There are other manufacturers, but their share of the market is relatively small. Because the market is, in fact, dominated substantially by two manufacturers it is highly competitive in nature. There are some 30 different State government Acts and regulations covering the manufacture and sale of margarine in Australia. Rather than tediously bore the Senate with a list, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of these different Acts and regulations.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
LEGISLATION AFFECTING MARGARINE MANUFACTURE

(a) South Australia: Margarine Act, 1939-1975 and amendments. Margarine Regulations, 1976 and amendments. Food Act, 1985. Regulations Under Food Act, No. 13 of 1986, incorporating South Australian Food Standards Code, 1985. Dairy Industry Act 1928-1974 and amendments.
(b) New South Wales: Pure Food Act, 1908 and amendments. Pure Foods Regulations, 1937 (under the Pure Food Act) and amendments. Dairy Industry Marketing Authority Act 1979 and amendments.
(c) Victoria: Food Act, 1984 and amendments. Food Standards Regulations, 1985 and amendments. Margarine Act, 1975 and amendments. Margarine Regulations, 1976 and amendments.
(d) Queensland: Food Act, 1981 and amendments. Food Standards Regulations, 1982 and amendments. Margarine Act, 1958-1978 and amendments. Margarine Regulations, 1959 and amendments.
(e) Western Australia: Health Act, 1911 and amendments. Health Act, Food & Drug Regulations, 1961 and amendments. Margarine Act, 1940 and amendments. Margarine Act Regulations, 1974 and amendments.

(f) Tasmania: Public Health Act, 1962 and amendments. Public Health (Food & Drug Standards) Regulations, 1971 and amendments. Public Health (Food Standards) Regulations, 1986. Public Health (Food Hygiene) Regulations, 1977 and amendments. Dairy Produce Act, 1932 and amendment. Dairy Produce Margarine Regulations, 1944 and amendments. Dairy Produce Amendment Act 1982.
(g) Northern Territory: Food Standards Act, 1979 and amendment. Food & Drugs Act, 1980 and amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The situation, I am informed by the industry, is least oppressive in New South Wales and probably at its worst in Western Australia. Hence the situation in Western Australia is worth discussion. Under the Western Australian Margarine Act, section 29, sub-section (1), it is required that starch be added to margarine by 0.1 per cent weight. It is further required under section 30, sub-section (1) (a), that table margarine be sold only in cube form. These two mysterious happenings go back to a very strange and outmoded view. The addition of starch for Western Australian products is of considerable nuisance value as special blends are required to conform with Western Australian regulations. The regulation requiring starch was introduced in the 1940s so that it was possible to distinguish margarine from butter.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an example of a regulation which is no longer required and should be repealed because the whole issue of passing margarine off as butter is no longer one that is really relevant to the community. The cube tub requirement, which is unique in Western Australia, has a very similar background. Small brand volumes in Western Australia mean very short tub manufacturing runs and this, of course, involves high packaging costs; added to this are the costs of maintaining separate stockholdings of the packed product and the loss of machine changeovers in the factory. All these are inefficiencies in the industry which could be avoided if this whole issue were brought back to Commonwealth-State consultation.

The Western Australian Government says that the clear requirement is necessary only so consumers can easily identify margarine from butter; that is, as I say, no longer of any significance in the community. It has been put to us by Unilever that the result of the differing regulations in Western Australia can be stated at some $288,000 per annum. If that be so, extra cost to the consumer of that one item alone is 4c to 5c for a 500-gram pack or some 8c for a kilogram of margarine purchased from Unilever Australia Ltd in that State.

Mr Acting Deputy President, there is a further classic example in the production of Fairy margarine variance. In New South Wales and South Australia there are no specific regulations covering cooking margarine and the product is manufactured to normal margarine colour level and sold in a common wrapper; so it is not a complication or problem there. However, in Victoria, aside from specific labelling requirements in respect of cooking margarine, the Margarine Act 1975 forbids the manufacture of cooking margarine containing prescribed colouring or flavouring substances and specified a maximum colour level for the base oil blend.

These requirements necessitate the holding of stocks solely for Victoria with a cost penalty incurred yet again. Tedious though these points may seem, all of them represent, I must remind honourable senators, a material cost to consumers which finally ends up on their grocery bill. In Western Australia it is prohibited under the Margarine Act to manufacture cooking or manufacturing margarines, quite apart from ordinary margarines, `in imitation or semblance of butter'. To conform with this legislation many types of margarine have to be produced and handled, with another resultant increase in cost to the consumer.

In Queensland the relevant Act governs the labelling of cooking margarines so that labels with different wording are required for Fairy margarine sold in Queensland from those on Fairy margarine sold in most other States. Again, here is another cost burden being applied to the community because these labels have to be printed separately and this is passed on directly to the consumer. Fairy margarine is not a major brand in terms of tonnage, but the net result of this conflicting legislation is for variants of this type of margarine.

Manufacturing margarine is the third major area of margarine manufacture and it is the final point I want to discuss today in the light of these comments. The term `manufacturing margarine' refers to a large range of industrial cooking margarines which are used by large scale industrial pastry producers, artisan bakers and pastrycooks. In Victoria the Margarine Act forbids the production of manufacturing margarine containing prescribed colouring or flavouring substances. Under section 10, sub-section (b) (iii), a statement is required which specifies the constituents of the fat content of the margarine which must contain a minimum 60 per cent of edible tallow.

There are no real reasons for any of these provisions above the standards of other States. In New South Wales, for instance, there are no restraints on the composition of the fat content and colouring is permitted. In Queensland, under the Margarine Act, it is required that the product blends contain a minimum of 40 per cent of edible tallow and these must be separately cartoned because of the different regulations regarding labelling, even though the blend may be identical with the New South Wales blend. Hence there are at least five products affected, some of which are packed both in solid block or as in extruded pieces for easier use, but in each case storage and packaging requirements are trebled and the additional costs incurred, here again, are passed on to the consumer.

One could go on and on through all these 70 regulations. I do not propose to do so; I think I have made the point. I have made the point to the Government that in referring to this one example I have made a case, I believe, that the time is ripe for the Government to look again at uniform business laws and uniform food laws, particularly in this country. It should be a top priority for the Government, given the willingness of the State governments, to amend the so-called `uniform' Companies Act of 1961 and for the partial rewriting of the Model Food Act by the South Australian Government, to cite two examples. The willingness and the will are there on the part of the States. The Federal Government could make a promising start in this regard by holding discussions with the State governments with a view to implementing a model food Act for Australia which, after all, was endorsed by all State Health Ministers back in 1980.
Sitting suspended from 1.24 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In a speech last night at the annual dinner of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Council of Australia he referred to the fact that in considering the future level of protection afforded these industries, the Government would:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . seek to provide reasonable levels of protection during the period of adjustment and, at the end, the industry will be protected at a level more than three times that of manufacturing industry as a whole.

In referring to three times a certain figure, is the Minister talking about the present overall level of effective protection for manufacturing-that is about 25 per cent-or does he mean approximately 15 per cent which applies when the highly protected textile, clothing and footwear and motor vehicle industries are removed from the average? In other words, is he suggesting an ultimate textile, clothing and footwear industry protection level of about 75 per cent, or is he saying that the Government's decision is likely to result in a protection level of under 50 per cent?

TALK.START.PARA: —I quite clearly was not saying either of the things that Senator Chaney would like to suggest. I was referring to the average rate of protection for the manufacturing industry, excluding the two majors. All I was saying was that under any formula which the Government is likely to adopt, the rate of protection for the textile, clothing and footwear industries will exceed three times that amount. The mathematics of it are fairly simple.

—Can the Minister for Community Services explain the applications process being used in Queensland under the home and community care program and why no organisations have been told whether their applications for funding were successful?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation in Queensland as far as the home and community care program is concerned is a worry to us all. The only new projects that have been funded in Queensland to date have been those funded from unmatched Commonwealth funds. I approved these projects earlier in the year and the money was paid to the State before the end of the last financial year. The home and community care program is a joint Commonwealth-State program with the State being responsible for its day-to-day administration. The Commonwealth, in fact, funds the State to carry out that administration. On the application side, we, at the Commonwealth level, drafted an application form which we asked a number of States to use. The Queensland Government refused and drafted its own form which is described by various people with such words as `dreadful', `too complex', `hard to fill out' and `extremely bureaucratic'.

ANSWER.PARA: I am concerned also that the form used in Queensland is numbered by the Queensland Department of Health and that only those people who fill out the numbered forms have their applications considered. Only organisations of which the Department of Health approves get an application form. So we have an extremely bureaucratic and restrictive application system, whereby only those organisations whose applications have been vetted are even considered. Those applications have to be approved by the Queensland Department of Health and, I assume, by the National Party in Queensland, which seems to be the way things operate up there. I have asked officers of my Department to go to Queensland to talk with Queensland officials to see just what is happening and why this screening out process is occurring. If this is going to happen I question the worth of being involved with the State in such a program. A further problem in Queensland is the time taken to consider applications. Applications were to be in by 15 July, 15 August and 15 September. I understand that no applications have been considered by the Queensland Government, and that the Minister, Mr Austin, has announced that nothing will be approved until after Christmas. As my Department has practically finished the administrative process I think that is a pity.

TALK.START.PARA: —He might not be there after Christmas.

—He might not be there, that is true. The administration of a new program such as this is always complex, but the complexities and the difficulties in the bureaucratic process which are going on in Queensland, and which I can only believe are aimed at restricting funds to organisations of which the Queensland Government does not approve philosophically, will be the downfall of the scheme in that State. That would be a great pity, but I would rather see the scheme not working in that State than for it to become a source of political patronage by the Queensland Government.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to my question on 7 October and his response on 9 October on the offset liabilities of computer companies tendering for the Australia Post office contract. Is the Minister aware that the information given to the Press by a senior officer of his Department, prior to the evaluation of tenders, has been commercially damaging to two of the computer companies concerned? Does he consider that the disclosure of such information is merely explaining Government policy, particularly if the information were untrue, as one of the companies is $25m in credit in its offset obligations?

—I understand that it has been alleged that it was commercially damaging to the companies in question, but these allegations fly back and forth and I cannot be an arbiter of those matters in Question Time in the Senate. I will see whether, I can get a more detailed explanation of the situation for the honourable senator.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health a question about the Co-ordinating Committee on Women and Health, the membership of which consists of women's health advisers from the Commonwealth and the States. Does Tasmania participate on this Committee by sending a representative, and given that Tasmania does not have a women's advisory unit, is the representative suitably qualified to represent the health interests of Tasmanian women? If Tasmania does not participate on this Committee, how does this lack of participation reflect the Gray Government's attitudes to the needs and concerns of Tasmanian women?

—The Commonwealth-State Co-ordinating Committee on Women and Health had its first meeting in October 1985 following a resolution from the second National Women's Health Conference that the Commonwealth sponsor such a committee. The role of the Committee was and is to facilitate the exchange of information on women's health issues between the States and the Commonwealth to see how these can be developed in a satisfactory way. All States sent senior representatives to the first meeting, but Queensland and Tasmania have declined to send representatives to meetings this year. The person who has represented Tasmania at a couple of the meetings made a valuable contribution to the Committee. In fact, everyone agrees that her absence from recent meetings is a matter of regret. Despite the non-participation of Tasmania and Queensland, copies of meeting papers and minutes are forwarded to all States, including those two States. The Tasmanian Government has, as Senator Coates says, no women's advisory unit, no women's advisor, no women's advisor on women's health, and no anti-discrimination legislation. They are not interested in that sort of thing down there.
—They don't need it.

—I know they have Senator Walters to give all the advice, but her advice tends to be a little biased. Senator Newman is only new so I understand that they go only to Senator Walters. That is why the Gray Government is notorious for its views which echo Senator Walters's views rather than the previously echoed views of Senator Newman. I think it is a pity that the Gray Government seems to have no regard for more than 50 per cent of the population in this way. It is a pity that it does not participate at least on a committee of this type which is a co-operative committee and which is trying to improve the delivery of health services to women. One can reflect only that it is because of something deep in the psyche of the Premier of Tasmania and his colleagues.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs.
—He is on the phone.
—As long as the Minister is concentrating on the question, I will continue.
—One ear is enough.

—It is probably an improvement to be all ears instead of all mouth. Is the Minister aware of the contents of the Liberal Party publication `Living in a Nuclear World' which has been distributed to schools in Victoria by the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party and which has been described by the Victorian Secondary Teachers Association as a blatant political document which attempts to promote Liberal Party foreign policy? Does the Minister agree with the assertions in the publication that getting out of ANZUS would not help the disarmament process, that the bases we share with the United States of America help peace and that uranium mining does not mean more nuclear bombs? If the Minister disagrees with these assertions, what actions will he take to counteract this misinformation which has been given to school children in Victoria? Finally, does the Minister consider that this publication confirms the view of South Australian Liberal member of the Legislative Council, Mr Lucas, that the Liberal Party leadership is open to criticism for its hero worship of the United States on peace issues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the pamphlet to which Senator Haines refers. I am afraid that I could not accept that it presents quite such a picture of unrelieved gloom and toadyism of the kind that she paints. I will not go so far as to suggest that it demonstrates any sophistication or sensitivity in the Liberal Party but the document is something of a curate's egg-it is good in parts. One of the parts which is good is that which endorses a number of the policies on arms control and disarmament which have been adopted by this Government.

ANSWER.PARA: It is gratifying that the Opposition has accepted in great part the wisdom of our approach in this respect. Among the things in the pamphlet with which we agree are the propositions to which Senator Haines refers, namely, that getting out of ANZUS would not help the disarmament process, that the joint defence facilities help the cause of peace and that uranium mining, whatever else it means, does not mean more nuclear bombs. The reasons why we agree with those propositions have been canvassed repeatedly in ministerial statements and publications and most comprehensively in the paper issued by Mr Hayden in 1984 entitled `Uranium the Joint Facilities Disarmament and Peace'.

When all that is said, the pamphlet contains a number of assertions with which this Government profoundly disagrees. I mention in particular that the Government cannot accept the comments in the pamphlet that are made about the United States strategic defence initiative program. Our view is that SDI is not merely a research program but is also an initiative that carries with it the high risk that it will lead to intensification and strategic competition or the extension of military competition into outer space and complicate the conclusion of new agreements limiting and reducing nuclear arsenals, as we saw so unhappily in Reykjavik a few days ago. We do not endorse either the SDI or comparable research programs from the Soviet Union.

The Government places a different emphasis from that in the pamphlet on nuclear deterrence. We support deterrence because, until better systems of restraint are in place, to forgo deterrence would not serve the cause of peace and would risk catastrophe. Government policy is primarily directed towards achieving a world where deterrence will no longer be necessary once the goal of the complete elimination of nuclear weapons has been achieved. As we have communicated to both the United States and Soviet government emissaries this week, we fully support the continuing efforts of both super-powers in seeking to achieve this goal.

I should also mention that there is an error of fact in the pamphlet in one obvious respect. The Government has no evidence that the Soviet Union has deployed weapons systems in Vietnam which directly endanger Australia. That is just another rerun of some outdated theories and neuroses which do not deserve wider currency, particularly with young people. To that extent there are elements of misinformation and error in the pamphlet. I have to say in response to the last part of Senator Haines's question that it would not be appropriate for the Commonwealth to take any particular action other than the kind I am taking today in drawing attention to those matters. The material distributed to schools in Victoria is a matter for the State education authorities. The Government's policy is one of allowing all points of view, however misconceived, to be expressed and discussed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer please inform the Senate how the Government's tax reform initiatives, such as the removal of double taxation on company profits, will advantage small businesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the best way to answer that question would be to draw a comparison between the taxation of a hypothetical small business under the administration of the former Treasurer and how it will be taxed under the Hawke Government's reformed tax system. When Mr Howard was Treasurer and a small business made a profit, pre-tax, of $100,000, what happened? The company would pay $46,000 in company tax. The remaining $54,000 was then taxed at the personal income tax rate of up to 60c in the dollar. As a result, the total tax bill of the business could be as high as $64,000. Even more horrendous, for each extra dollar this small business earned, nearly 80c went in tax to the then Treasurer, now Leader of the Opposition. That is, one extra dollar in profit was taxed at 46c in the dollar in the hands of the company and at 60c in the hands of the individual. That resulted in 21c for the small business person and 78.4c for the Leader of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the Hawke Government's new tax policy, the same small business with a pre-tax profit of $100,000, under the imputation system which wipes out tax for small business, would pay a tax of $49,000. If it then distributed a dividend of $51,000, the $49,000 already paid would be offset against the total tax liability of the shareholder. Depending on the individual's marginal tax rate there is the possibility that the individual would receive a rebate and pay less than $49,000 tax in total after the distribution of the post-tax profit, against an amount of $64,000 under the previous system. That assumes that the hypothetical company or companies concerned had been honestly paying tax in the past.

It is a matter of historical record that a huge number of companies, owned and controlled by prominent people in the Liberal Party, did not pay any tax because they were into all sorts of tax avoidance and tax evasion schemes, bottom of the harbour rorts, macadamia nut schemes, cherry picker schemes and so on. So there will be exceptions. The many prominent people in the Liberal Party who had become accustomed to paying virtually no tax during Mr Howard's treasurership will pay more tax than they paid previously. They are kicking up a big fuss about that. That is not surprising. Those are the sorts of people who are kicking up the fuss. These prominent members of the Liberal Party who are manipulating these puppets in here and telling them--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator will withdraw that.

—I will withdraw that, Mr President. Those people are manipulating the members of the Opposition and denigrating the system of taxation which this Government is about to introduce, which is much more satisfactory for honest companies which have been paying taxes all along but less satisfactory for those who have been in the habit of evading-such as all those prominent members of the Liberal Party who have become accustomed to evading their tax liabilities. Those people are kicking up a fuss. They are telling the Opposition that it must oppose this tax reform. The Opposition dutifully is doing so.
—Mr President, I ask that the Minister table the document from which he quoted.
—The Minister has tabled the document at the request of Senator Messner.

—I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to reports of the changes proposed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions to superannuation which would mean, amongst other things, the establishment of a national development fund for the purpose of industry investment. I ask the Minister: Has the Government yet had any discussions with the ACTU on this proposal?

—Discussions were held yesterday with the ACTU. They were led by the Prime Minister and other Ministers, including me, participating in those discussions. The ACTU put a number of matters to us which I think have been fairly well publicised, certainly the issue to which Senator Short referred. The Government has made no response on any of those issues. We will be meeting again with the ACTU in due course. Some issues clearly require close examination.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen media reports which indicate that South Africa is poised to invade Mozambique? Was the South African decision to expel Mozambiquan workers from South Africa another step in the campaign to destabilise the region?

—The Government is aware of reports that a meeting of leaders of the front line states in Maputo, the capital of Mozambique, on 12 October, expressed their deep concern at the external assistance reportedly being given to rebel forces in Mozambique and at the possibility of renewed acts of South African destabilisation against Mozambique. The concerns of leaders of the front line states come at a time when South Africa has announced the expulsion of Mozambiquan migrant workers from South Africa, although the South African defence force has denied that its forces are concentrated along South Africa's border with Mozambique. The Australian Government has repeatedly expressed its concern over South Africa's policy of regional destabilisation. We remain concerned over the deteriorating situation arising from the South African Government's refusal to negotiate a peaceful end to apartheid and the deeply unsettling effect this has on the southern African region as a whole. Apartheid remains the underlying cause of violence and a very serious threat to regional peace and security. I mention also, as we have previously stated, our complete and unequivocal rejection of the use of armed force in the region to resolve differences and, in particular, South African armed attacks. We sincerely hope as a government that all parties will exercise caution and restraint and that confrontation will be avoided.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. In view of the fact that sophisticated superannuation schemes provide a benefit geared to the contributor's final salary-for instance, a company which typically would pay, say, 11 to 12 per cent of its wages bill to provide five times the employee's final average salary-is the Minister aware that to maintain the employee benefit under the regulations proposed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, employers will have to increase their contributions? Will the Minister advise the impact on the economy of the ACTU proposal?

—I do not have in front of me, nor do I have memorised, the ACTU proposal in question, so I am not in a position to answer the question off the top of my head. Private superannuation is the Treasurer's responsibility. I am responsible only for superannuation for Commonwealth Government employees and Commonwealth authorities. I will refer the question to the Treasurer and get an answer.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen the article in yesterday's West Australian headlined `Holiday offer leads Libs' membership drive'? Does the article deal with the Liberal Party brochure entitled `Knocking on a few doors can win you a trip for two to Europe'? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether a political party offering holiday packages as an incentive for signing up new members would be subject to the fringe benefits tax? If the Western Australian Liberal Party is subject to fringe benefits tax for providing that incentive package, is it an intended or unintended consequence of the fringe benefits tax? If the Western Australian Liberal Party is not subject to fringe benefits tax for providing the incentive package, will the Minister take steps in the context of the present review to ensure that it becomes an intended consequence of the fringe benefits tax to tax the package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the last part of the question, which could be interpreted as an invitation to victimise the Liberal Party--
—Outside the law, you mean.

—I certainly will not recommend that that should happen. I do not think it would be very fair to single out the Western Australian Liberal Party for unduly harsh treatment. It has enough problems of its own making without the Commonwealth Government adding to them. I have seen the article. Subject to the confirmation, I suppose, by the Commissioner of Taxation, I believe that the position is as follows: If the people receiving the incentive package are members of the Liberal Party but are not employees of the Liberal Party the incentives would not be subject to the fringe benefits tax. If the people receiving the incentive package are employees of the Liberal Party and are not members of the Liberal Party the incentives would be subject to the fringe benefits tax. If the people receiving the incentive package are employees of the Liberal Party and also members of the Liberal Party the question of whether their incentives were subject to fringe benefits tax would depend on whether they took part in the recruiting program as part of their duties as an employee of the Liberal Party or as members of it.

ANSWER.PARA: Returning to the second part of Senator Cook's question as to whether I would recommend that that particular incentive package be subject to the fringe benefits tax in all circumstances, I have already mentioned that I do not think it would be proper to discriminate against the Western Australian Liberal Party in that way. Senator Chaney and some of his moderate friends are trying to do a good job in their attempt to rebuild the Liberal Party in the face of the scungy practices which have flourished within it for so long. For example, there has been widespread stacking of branches, formation of skeleton branches, armfuls of proxy votes from fictitious branches carted into State conferences, signing up members out of telephone books, transferring members between branches--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister is debating the issue. He is clearly now out of order. I ask him to come back to the answer.

—Certainly, Mr President. For the reasons I have mentioned and for a number of other reasons-if anyone wants to see me afterwards I would be pleased to give them a more comprehensive list of what has been going on in the Western Australian Liberal Party-apart from the general impropriety, even, of a government designing its tax policy in a way that discriminated against a particular political party, on the grounds of more general fairness, Senator Chaney and his friends, who are trying to do a good job, albeit with little success, should not be further impeded in their attempts to clean up the sorts of scungy practices which Senator Crichton-Browne and his friends indulged in in the Liberal Party for so long.
