—I ask the Minister for Finance: How much was Tasmania overpaid in dam compensation money in relation to the Franklin River? Will the Federal Government reconsider future payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the question a little difficult to answer because of the definition of overpayment. I presume that Senator Siddons is referring to the fact that the forecasts by the Hydro-Electric Commission of the growth rate of power consumption were, by a factor of about three, in excess of that which has occurred. The actual growth rates in power consumption were even marginally in excess of those which had been estimated by the Commonwealth Department of Resources and Energy when I was Minister for Resources and Energy. However, the capacity planning of the HEC endorsed by the State Government had built into it the assumption that power demand would grow at that rate. The Tasmanian Government, especially the Premier, was too stubborn and pigheaded to take advice from those who, it has now been demonstrated, knew better.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose it could be argued on those grounds that the Commonwealth has overcompensated the Tasmanian Government, and, indeed, has effectively underwritten the planning errors of the Tasmanian Government. However, an agreement was signed. I suppose other people are at liberty to raise this matter with other Ministers if they wish, but it is not my view that the Commonwealth at this stage ought to review the $20m per year which, in January 1984 prices, it has agreed to pay to Tasmania.

In addition to that compensation, of course, large additional amounts were provided to Tasmania to maintain employment in the interim period between the cessation of construction on the Gordon below Franklin dam and the winding up of construction on the two alternative schemes. Virtually all of that money has been spent in any case, but the bottom line, assuming that I have correctly divined the purpose of Senator Siddons's question, is that the Commonwealth's fiscal treatment of Tasmania has been extremely generous. Perhaps if we had known at the time not only how ungrateful Mr Gray would be for Commonwealth generosity but also his propensity habitually to distort facts and misrepresent facts, we may have been less generous. But I think that is water gone down the creek, or the river, so to speak.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an open letter to Sir William Knox, the Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia in the Queensland Parliament, published in the Suburban Express on 14 October by Frank Gaffy, QC, the National Party of Australia candidate for Ashgrove? The letter calls on Sir William to dissociate himself and the Liberal Party from statements describing the Queensland economy as the worst in Australia, made by Alan Sherlock, the Liberal candidate for Ashgrove. Can the Minister comment on the accuracy of Frank Gaffy's assertions in the letter that Queensland's economic difficulties result from ill-advised Federal policies which adversely affect Queensland more than any other State, including excessive interest rates, unreasonable levels of tariffs and the effect of a decade of a grossly overvalued Australian dollar?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have, indeed, seen the letter to which Senator Jones refers. In reply, perhaps I may say, firstly, that how alleged inappropriate Federal Government policies would affect Queensland any more than any other State remains a matter for wide-eyed conjecture. No suggestion or line of argument is developed as to why that would be so. As to whether the Federal Government's policies in question are inappropriate, I suppose to some extent that is a matter of judgment, but it does surprise me that the Queensland National Party candidates are so ready to put the blame on the policies of their Federal National Party colleagues as well as their Liberal Party colleagues, or enemies, these days.

ANSWER.PARA: The three policies mentioned in the letter were quite specific. I will go through them. The first was excessive interest rates. Of course, the former Treasurer, John Howard, holds the record for having presided over the highest interest rates ever recorded, of more than 21 1/2 per cent on 90-day bank bills in April 1982. Secondly, reference was made to an alleged unreasonable level of tariffs. The level of tariffs in Australia peaked in the 1960s when the National Party or then Country Party leader, John McEwen, was effectively running the country. That is when the level of tariff protection peaked, and it did so under a Country Party coalition government, which party later became the National Party. I do not know whether we should assume from that that as well as repudiating the present Federal Liberal Party and the present Federal National Party, the candidate, Mr Sherlock, is also repudiating McEwen.

Finally, and most importantly, is the reference to a decade of a grossly overvalued Australian dollar. That is, in the main, true. It was not grossly overvalued for a whole decade but it was certainly grossly overvalued through the late 1970s and the early 1980s. Not only was it grossly overvalued but also it was deliberately overvalued because the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, used a grossly overvalued Australian dollar as a substitute for a wages policy. Because he had no wages policy, the Treasurer of the day, Mr Howard, and the Government of the day deliberately maintained an overvalued Australian dollar in an attempt, futile as it ultimately turned out to be, to control domestic inflation.

In closing, this letter to which Senator Jones refers is really just another instalment in the mutual Queensland Liberal and National Party slanging match. To demonstrate the bitterness of that, I remind the Senate that I have written to the Queensland Premier in an attempt to exhume some of the sordid details of some of the national disaster relief loans that have been granted in Queensland. I can advise that a senior official of the Queensland Liberal Party has made an indirect approach to me and has asked that, if I manage to dig up any dirt about that, would I let him have some of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In light of the recent statement by Mr Alan Coates, Managing Director of Australia's largest superannuation fund, the AMP Society, that `the speed of growth of investment opportunities, especially in the case of equity investment, is not sufficient to enable the total funds to be absorbed efficiently', and in view of the fact that the overseas portfolios of the major super funds are far outperforming their Australian portfolios, even after the payment of 15 per cent withholding tax to foreign governments, is the Government considering introducing any changes to existing regulations to force investment capital back on shore?

—That is a question that is more appropriately directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. As far as I am aware, the Government is not currently considering that matter. I will make inquiries, and if the Treasurer has some proposals about that matter, he will either announce them in due course or I will tell the senator that he has some proposals.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. A letter from a Western Australian headed `True blue and Qantas' which appeared in the Australian newspaper last Monday, 13 October, was critical of Qantas's policy of supplying its passengers with overseas made goods such as English butter and Swiss jam rather than Australian made goods. Could Qantas's purchasing policies be seen to be in breach of this Government's announced policy on purchasing Australian goods wherever possible? Will the Minister comment on this matter and report on any Government representations made to Qantas about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a view, which I believe has bipartisan support, that buying Australian goods is a very important ingredient in improving our economic circumstances. Therefore, we would expect the Qantas organisation and our principal domestic airlines to follow that practice. In respect of the question asked by Senator McKiernan, I understand that Qantas adopts a policy of substantially complying with government policy and that something in excess of 95 per cent of its purchases are goods made in Australia. But there are some particular difficulties about quarantine regulations involving other countries, as well as freight problems in taking, for example, Australian jam to a port overseas; there would be a freight charge in respect of the use of fuel for that particular matter. In respect of butter, we might come into conflict with other countries because of quarantine regulations.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's public and private domestic airlines, Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia, have an obligation to comply as far as they are able with requests of government to purchase Australian goods. From travelling on both those airlines I have noticed that that policy is not being put into practice by our domestic airlines. Whilst Qantas has difficulties in respect of its obligations to other countries, such difficulties do not apply to our domestic airlines.

I have found, for example, that Ansett has both crockery and cutlery purchased from other countries. Australian Airlines has crockery purchased from other countries. I expect, therefore, that they will apply government policy in future purchases of these items. Whilst they are statutory and public organisations outside the control of government, I think they have an obligation as far as is possible to comply with government policies in these matters. On the particular question asked by Senator McKiernan, I am advised that Qantas largely complies with government policy in these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister representing the Treasurer will recall that on 25 September 1986 he answered a question I put to him on the capital gains tax as it relates to principal residences and he stated that his answer was subject to confirmation. I ask: Does the Minister now confirm his answer or is he now aware that his statement that a home is exempt, whether lived in or not, misled the Senate and is incorrect? In view of the fact that the Government has claimed that the family home is exempt when in fact the family home is taxable in many circumstances, does the Minister define this as an unintended consequence? If so, will he review the matter?

—I do have some recollection of the question to which Senator Watson referred. I believe he correctly said that I said `subject to confirmation'. No, I do not have any confirmation yet. What I can do for Senator Watson though is to let him know what one of the intended consequences of the capital gains tax legislation will be, and that is that people who have played around with company take- overs to minimise their taxation obligations in the past and who have gained huge tax free capital gains through manipulating those company takeovers, people such as, for example, Mr Elliott, the Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has demonstrated for a second time his incapacity to answer the particular question addressed to him by Senator Watson. He is now proceeding to debate a question which has not been asked and to engage in his usual rhetorical flourishes. I ask you to sit him down so that we may get on with Question Time.
—Order! The Minister is still within the realm of the question asked of him but he is getting on to the periphery of it. I ask him to relate his remarks to the question.

—Certainly, Mr President. May I note for the record that at least Senator Chaney is trying to cover up the scungy activities of his own party members this time instead of those of members of the National Party in Queensland.
—Order! I ask the Minister to answer the question asked by Senator Watson; otherwise I will ask him to resume his seat.

—Certainly, Mr President. If people want to know one of the intended consequences I refer them to an article written by Terry McCrann and published in the Age on Tuesday, 15 April 1986 which refers to the takeover of Henry Jones by Elder Smith and the various devices by which Mr Elliott cleared for himself a tax-free profit of $650,000.
—Order! I ask the Minister to resume his seat. That is clearly outside the realm of the question.

—Is the Minister for Community Services aware that some criticism has been levelled at the adequacy of child care provided in rural areas? How does the Minister respond to the claim that in the provision of child care rural areas are disadvantaged when compared with metropolitan areas? My concern, of course, is with the Northern Territory and I would be grateful if the Minister would comment on the situation in the Northern Territory in his response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, there has been criticism of the inadequacy of children's services in rural areas. I suppose that in some ways that criticism is justified. In the past children's services have developed on a submission basis and people in urban areas frequently have had the capacity, the experience and the skilled representatives to provide information on which to base such submissions. Therefore they were closer to the source of funds.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, programs have been a bit rigid in the past in not allowing for the special needs of people in rural areas, particularly those in smaller country towns who do not need the long day services but who need more occasional care, crisis care. However, in recent times, by changing from a submission-based model, by creating more flexible services such as multi-functional centres which can cover a wide range of needs in a small centre, by increasing the number of occasional care services and by extending family day care to rural areas, we have been managing to overcome those deficiencies of the past.

In the Northern Territory, in co-operation with the Northern Territory Government, we have introduced special programs aimed at assisting Aboriginal communities and the more isolated communities, particularly of the Centre. In those areas previously there had been no capacity to provide funding.

In recent times we have provided new family day care schemes in rural areas such as Ballina and Byron Bay in New South Wales, the north-west coast of Tasmania, the upper Murray Valley in Victoria and Port Lincoln in South Australia. We have also provided a new remote areas funding package in the Northern Territory, as well as the funds I mentioned earlier, which will enable us to develop low cost self-supporting structures in some of the communities in the Territory which are more suitable to their remoteness.

Gradually we will be able to do much more, particularly for rural women, such as the farmers' wives who, I have noted, are willing to travel considerable distances to provide advantages for their children in play groups, pre-schools or child care centres to overcome some of the isolation which they think affects their children due to living on their properties. As I said, I think in the past some of the criticism has been justified. We should be able to overcome the difficulties in the future.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FREMANTLE GAS AND COKE CO. LTD

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and follows his continuing interest in the affairs of non-Labor governments, non-Labor parties and their supporters. I ask the Minister, since I have raised the matter with him several times, whether he has made any inquiry about the Western Australian State Government's involvement in the purchase by the Western Australian State Energy Commission of part of the assets of Fremantle Gas and Coke Co. Ltd. Is he aware that part of the company's assets were bought by the State Energy Commission for $40m when the whole of the company had been acquired in a recent competitive market-place situation for $25m? Has he examined the role of the Western Australian Labor Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Parker, in that transaction and in particular the role of the Minister in exercising his statutory powers in approving a substantial increase in the authorised capital of Fremantle Gas and Coke Co. Ltd, as a result of which the asset acquired by the Government had its market value enormously enhanced? Has he examined the role of Australian Labor Party members and donors to the Australian Labor Party in that State in this transaction? If the Minister has not taken any action to inquire into or examine these matters, will he do so or does he reserve his indignation for those who dare to involve themselves in political parties other than the Australian Labor Party?

—Mr President, I could request, I suppose, that you rule the question out of order on the grounds that it has nothing to do with my ministerial responsibilities. But I will not plead that because I am very happy to answer it. The fact remains, however, that Senator Chaney is yet again trying to protect the National Party Administration in Queensland. I suggest he should take a leaf out of the book of the senior Queensland Liberal Party official who said: `If Walsh manages to get any dirt about those drought relief loans, will he let me have some of it'. I think Senator Chaney would be much better advised politically to follow the lead of that Queensland Liberal Party official, rather than the practices that he follows here. The reason for my interest in the disaster relief loans, of course, is that Commonwealth money is involved. Whatever the Western Australian Government may or may not have done, it did not use Commonwealth money to do it. Senator Chaney seems to think there is something very peculiar about the value or the price paid for a company increasing from $25m to $40m in a fairly short period. That may or may not be so; I really do not know. But it is very much more peculiar, I think, for an outlay of $3,000 to produce within a very short period a return of $657,000, all of it tax free. That is exactly what the Federal Treasurer of the Liberal Party engineered for himself, as a director of Elder Smith when it took over Henry Jones.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Does the Federal Government have any interest in the total loan raisings of the State Government of Western Australia and other State governments, and the loan raisings of statutory authorities in those States? Does the Commonwealth therefore have any interest in the fact that $40m is required by the State Energy Commission to meet this contract? Is he concerned at the very odd circumstances which surround the transaction, and the involvement of a Labor Minister in the issue of shares, which have caused a substantial revaluation upwards of the company?

—Borrowings by the State Energy Commission of Western Australia are now contained within agreed limits. The administration of those borrowings is a matter for the Treasurer, not me. I add, of course, that in the last couple of desperate years of the Fraser Government, there was no such control on borrowings by electricity authorities, and that that abdication of responsibility by the then Treasurer, as part of the resources boom hype-the resources boom which never happened--
—You are just a fraud, Walsh. You are an absolute fraud.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will withdraw that remark.
—It is a two-faced approach. He is going on and on. I think it is utterly offensive to this Senate.
—Order! I have asked the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw the remark he made about the Minister.
—Mr President, I withdraw the remark, but I accuse the Minister of rank hypocrisy.
—Order! I take it that the Leader of the Opposition has withdrawn the remark unequivocally.
—Yes, I did, Mr President.

—In the last couple of desperate years of the Fraser-Howard regime, there were no such agreed limits on borrowings. Because of that, State governments recklessly borrowed enormous amounts to provide infrastructure for a resources boom that never happened. That was the reason why the current account deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product reached its all-time record level in 1981-82. Although it is correct that there are agreed limits on borrowings by State government business authorities, such as the Western Australian State Energy Commission, there is certainly nothing remotely resembling the direct linkage between the provision of Commonwealth money, from the Commonwealth Budget, for administration by State governments, as happens in respect of national disaster relief arrangement loans and the Queensland Government. To the extent, if any, that Senator Chaney's question has any relevance to Commonwealth administration, it is a matter for the Treasurer.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware of a report on social security recipients in Queensland? If so, will he inform the Senate of any details relating to claims made by the Queensland Premier that a winter influx of southerners can be blamed for increases in unemployment in that State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fortuitously the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, has given me some information on these matters. I think it is worth while putting to rest the nonsense that has been spoken by the Queensland Premier and some sections of the Queensland Press about suntanned dole bludgers who they apparently believe abound in Queensland. The report on social security recipients in Queensland outlines the following facts, as distinct from myths: The fastest growth in the number of unemployment beneficiaries in Queensland has been in metropolitan and rural areas, not in resort areas. Young people in receipt of the unemployment benefit are not over-represented at resort areas and their numbers have been growing less rapidly than the numbers of older beneficiaries. Regional office statistics from the major resort areas-Southport, Burleigh Heads, Maroochydore and Mackay-show that since 1983 the growth in the under 25 age group has been below the growth in all other age groups. There has been a 2.5 per cent increase in the under 25 age group and an average of 7.3 per cent in the others.

ANSWER.PARA: Since 1985, with accelerating unemployment growth across Queensland, the UB numbers in resorts rose at a considerably lower rate than in other areas. In the resort area the figure for growth has been 3.9 per cent; in the non-resort area growth has been 10.3 per cent. The State-wide average has been 8.9 per cent. In fact, there is a net outflow of young people from Queensland and a net inflow of older people to Queensland. It seems that the young cannot wait to get away from Queensland. Permanent migration between Queensland and other States shows a net outflow of the 15 to 34 age group of 4,000 and a net inflow of the 35 to 45 plus age group of 7,100.

The Queensland Government takes cold comfort from the Australian Bureau of Statistics September labour force report. The drop in the unemployment rate in Queensland for 15 to 19 year olds was from 21.8 per cent in August to 18.8 per cent in September. We are talking in this area about a tiny sample of about 18,000 people. In regard to the sort of interpretation that has been put on that figure by the Queensland Government, it will almost certainly find that it is nothing more than a statistical hiccup. What has been happening in Queensland is that Premier Bjelke-Petersen, in his use of primitive politics, has been trying to make the young unemployed, in particular, and also sole supporting parents, the scapegoats for the economic failures of that State. In fact unemployment beneficiaries and sole parents in Queensland make up less than 20 per cent of social security recipients.

The simple fact is that Queensland is being hit by an economic slowdown because the Queensland Government has great difficulty with its economy. The economy suffers from a narrow industrial base. If current policies continue, there will be a continuing increase in unemployment in Queensland. That increase will continue to be greater amongst older people in rural areas and in the metropolitan areas, not in the resort areas. That is why Queensland accounts for about 16 per cent of Australia's population and about 19.7 per cent of Australia's unemployment beneficiaries. At the end of September the unemployment rate for Queensland was 9.3 per cent. The national average is 8.3 per cent. The numbers of unemployed in Queensland grew from June 1985 to June 1986 by 11 per cent; Australia-wide the growth has been 1.5 per cent. The Queensland Government should stop blaming the young unemployed and sole parents and look to itself for the reasons for the difficulties in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns disarmament and arms control. Following the visit to Australia yesterday of Ambassador Ken Adelman, the Head of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, who came here direct from the summit meeting in Iceland, what is the Government's assessment of the prospect now for progress in disarmament and arms control, including the tacit proposals for agreement that were considered by President Reagan and General-Secretary Gorbachev earlier this week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not entirely without confidence that some further progress can be made notwithstanding the unhappy outcome of the Reykjavik meeting, foundering as it did as a result of the rigidity of the difference between the two countries over the strategic defence initiative. However, the respective positions of the two countries on SDI remain a matter of concern to the Government, particularly in the light of briefings it has received from Mr Adelman first and more recently this morning from the Soviet Ambassador. It remains a matter of concern that at the moment the gap on that issue appears to be very close to unbridgable. Certainly, as the Prime Minister said yesterday, during the briefing with Mr Adelman, he and the Ministers at the meeting with him explored a number of ways in which the various difficulties might be accommodated while permitting progress toward the complete elimination of offensive weapons over the 10-year period as proposed, very constructively, by President Reagan.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think I can say anything more at the moment as far as the Australian Government is concerned other than that we hope that negotiations can proceed both in the context of the intermediate-range nuclear force round of discussions and the strategic arms reduction talks negotiations in relation to the larger missiles and that it will be found that when those discussions resume the constructive proposals that were on the table in relation to INF, START and test bans will remain there and will be able to be picked up at the same time as discussion on the more unbridgable matters proceeds. Obviously, it is crucially important for the future of the world that a constructive, not a negative, approach is taken by the two countries concerned. Australia will be devoting all its resources and efforts and calling upon every ounce of our credibility and status as a reliable ally of the United States of America to make that view known and to give that process the momentum it obviously deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present the report relating to the redevelopment of the School of Military Engineering, Casula, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Army's School of Military Engineering, located at Casula near Liverpool, New South Wales, is responsible for providing a wide variety of training courses for members of the Royal Australian Engineers and for other Army units. In 1985-86 the school conducted 66 courses of varying duration involving about 1,500 students. Much of the 200-hectare site occupied by the school has been developed by the Army as an outdoors training area in which students undergo practical training in various engineering disciplines, techniques and equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal examined by the Joint Committee on Public Works is for the redevelopment of the school by providing new buildings for training, administration, accommodation, messing, vehicle and plant maintenance and stores. The limit of cost estimate for the redevelopment is $29.7m at January 1986 prices. The Committee found that existing facilities for accommodation, administration, indoors training and support activities at the school are below acceptable standards and should be replaced or refurbished. The Committee satisfied itself that the scope of the redevelopment of the school effectively utilises available functional areas consistent with the master plan and provides accommodation, instructional and support facilities at a scale consistent with its role.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion Paper and Text of Ministerial Statement

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this paper was put before the Senate on Tuesday I was commenting first of all on the fact that the Government was to be congratulated on taking steps to put out a discussion paper prior to launching itself into what could have been rather precipitate, and perhaps controversial, legislation and that it was giving community groups, described in the foreword as `appropriate community organisations', the opportunity of making submissions on the contents of this discussion paper. Unfortunately, they will have only six or seven weeks in which to make those submissions. However, presumably since this discussion paper has been flagged for some months, large numbers of community groups will be only too anxious to have their say about exactly how we should go in this country about ensuring that children from broken marriages are supported financially to an adequate and appropriate extent.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Government has pointed out on page 8 of this paper, currently just over a quarter of a million sole parents and class A widows' pension recipients are caring for some 450,000 children. For the majority of sole parent families the pension or benefit is their only source of income. Government expenditure on social security payments for class A widows and supporting parent beneficiaries has risen substantially over the last decade from $160m in 1973-74 to $1,757m in 1985-86, an increase of some 245 per cent in real terms. The paper goes on to emphasise that part of the problem facing those sole supporting parents is that there are very limited labour market opportunities and that most of the people who are affected are women. Their difficulties are compounded by the fact that we already have more people unemployed than there are jobs but in the main an additional burden facing these women is that they have school age or pre-school age children and therefore require not full time work but permanent part time work and in addition to that child care, the availability of which is, as we know, rather limited in this country at this stage.

The paper points out the problems currently facing custodial parents with regard to the receipt of maintenance. Over half the custodial parents who are entitled to maintenance never receive, or receive only irregularly, the money that is due to them, and this means that they are facing an increasing financial burden, particularly as the children get older. We are also faced with the fact of life that in many ways the Family Law Act encourages a fairly low level of payment per child-usually it averages about $20 a week per child-and this is insufficient on any criterion that is used for an adequate amount of support for a child.

There is also some concern about the way in which maintenance has become an optional payment in many cases. Because it is not deducted at source but is left up to the maintenance payer to forward the payment to the custodial parent, in many cases other debts are given priority and this, of course, rebounds enormously on the welfare of the children concerned. We hope that the Government will listen to the responses for the community. We hope that it will reject any suggestion that maintenance payments should be somehow tied to access of the children, because the two should be regarded as separate, and that it will make the legislation as fair and as flexible as possible. For example, those existing maintenance orders which are currently complied with should not necessarily be picked up under the legislation, although this Government should make every attempt to collect payments, under the auspices of whatever legislation it brings forward, from those people who have evaded paying maintenance to date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to spend a few moments recommending to the Senate the Government discussion paper on child maintenance entitled `Child Support'. This paper represents a vital discussion document in the light of recent trends in Australian society-trends that are best summarised on page 7 of the Government's discussion paper. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has to be commended for recognising both the human and fiscal problems relating to the breakdown of marriages or de facto marriages and the situation of the children involved in those breakdowns. Especially relevant is the attempt in this discussion paper to address the significant problems caused by the fact that less than 30 per cent of custodial parents receive regular cash payments from non-custodial parents.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be said at the outset that no amount of government legislation will solve the problems associated with matrimonial breakdown, especially in cases where one of the partners is determined, or both of the partners are determined, to be unco-operative or vindictive. What can be done, however, is to provide a framework in which couples can separate cheaply and as co-operatively as possible and in which the children are cared for as appropriately as possible. The Government recognises, however, that any improvements to the system cannot be imposed on the community without widespread discussion and detailed analysis of the likely effects of new legislation and administrative procedures, especially those aimed at protecting the interests of children. It is therefore the wish of the Government to elicit as great a response as is possible prior to any legislative and administrative action.

The Family Law Act has been a marked improvement over previous legislation, but in practise, for many couples, it has fallen short of achieving, firstly, the protection of children's interests; secondly, the fair division of property; and, thirdly, the lowering of costs involved in matrimonial separation. Of particular concern is the evidence coming before us that single parents and their children are most likely to face poverty or a substantial drop in their standard of living as a result of separation. By 1984, for example, the proportion of female-headed sole parent families dependent on government welfare had grown to 87 per cent from a 1974 figure of 65 per cent.

At this stage, I wish to talk about the stereotype of the typical defaulter in matters of child maintenance. I believe it is a stereotype that is causing some problems in terms of governments being able to address the real issue in a rational way. This defaulter, who is usually a male, is supposed to be working in another State, probably under a different name-all with the purpose of escaping the payment of child maintenance. In fact, the opposite is more likely to be true. Most live in the same city, work at their usual jobs, but pay irregularly. Attempts to receive the full entitlement by the custodial parent often involve expensive and time consuming legal action. Given that the average maintenance payment is set at about $20 per week, the result of successful legal actions hardly seems worth while. Nor is the defaulter always a man on a low income. He may be a professional who uses every legal trick to avoid his responsibilities. According to recent research reported in an Institute of Family Studies document entitled `Settling Up-Property and Income Distribution after Divorce in Australia', affluent men are often those who are least likely to be paying for the support of their wives, despite the fact that, as this discussion paper points out, most men are substantially better off after divorce than their former spouses bringing up their children.

According to Ruth Weston from the Family Studies Institute, women who choose to be full time housewives and/or mothers are the women most likely to have difficulties gaining employment after divorce due to a disrupted work history and/or their lack of work experience. A very high proportion of women in this category have been married to high income earning husbands. The development is not surprising. More affluent men tend to have assets and income tied up in areas which are excluded from the divorce settlement: Businesses, often incorporated with such complexity that even the tax man must have difficulty following the trail, superannuation policies, and a life-style where personal possessions, from cars to houses and furnishings, are considered part of those almost untouchable business assets.

Many women in this category have been ignorant partners in the associated companies and either have little or no knowledge of the business arrangements or, in some cases, have been deliberately excluded from any effective access or power. To receive justice on separation, those women are then forced to take expensive legal action, a course which they often do not have the financial or emotional resources to follow through to a satisfactory conclusion. The division of barrister and solicitor functions in some State legal systems exacerbates the problem still further. The net result is that those affected women often accept settlements which are inadequate and unjust in terms of their own contribution to the failed marriage or in terms of their future capacity to care financially for their children. I am raising this issue because public discussion about child maintenance and the family law in general has often been plagued by the use of stereotypes, which has inhibited sensible government action in this area.

In matters relating to child maintenance, the suggestion in the discussion paper that the major departmental responsibility should be carried by the Australian Taxation Office is a good one. The Tax Office has readier access and greater powers to investigate the affairs of individuals involved in divorce. Of course, what is needed is a mechanism which makes it possible to achieve a true and more cost-efficient assessment of the non-custodial parent's financial position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the fact that this report on child support is before us. I differ from Senator Aulich in his commendation of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). Indeed, I would condemn the Minister and the Government for their pathetic failure to act over 3 1/2 years on a matter which has been seen by the whole community as one of some urgency. The fact is that the measures that were brought forward by the previous Government in the Budget of 1982-83 were set aside by this Government. The national maintenance inquiry produced a report of some 400 pages in February 1984. It took the Government a year and a half before a Cabinet sub-committee was established to examine options for reforming current child maintenance arrangements, and that has finally resulted in the discussion paper before us now. So we have had 3 1/2 years without any action by this Government on a matter which, as I say, is widely perceived in the community as requiring urgent action.

SPEECH.PARA: A few simple statistics in the discussion paper make it clear why there is community concern. As a proportion of all families in Australia, sole parent families rose from 9 per cent in the mid-1970s to 14 per cent in 1986. Between 1974 and 1986 the number of sole parent families increased by 73 per cent, from 183,000 to 316,000. The proportion of sole parents on a pension or benefit went from 65 per cent to 85 per cent over the last decade. Presently there are about a quarter of a million people receiving the supporting parents' benefit, with 450,000 children in their care. Less than 30 per cent of these parents have any additional source of income. Government expenditure on supporting parents has risen by 245 per cent in real terms since 1973-74, from $160m to $1,757m in 1985-86, with less than 30 per cent of custodial parents receiving regular cash payments from non-custodial parents. In only a minority of cases does a court order or maintenance agreement exist, and less than half of court orders for maintenance made are complied with. Unmarried sole parents are less likely to receive maintenance payments-only 10 per cent do-and divorced sole parent pensioners are most likely to receive maintenance payments, but even there, the figure is only 36 per cent.

This is a matter of deep public concern for two basic reasons. The first concerns sole parents themselves and, even more importantly, their children. It has been known for years that that group is more likely than almost any other to suffer poverty and hardship and to need to beg. So this has been seen as an urgent item on the welfare agenda for years-hence the moves taken by the previous Government to start some action. There is also concern, however, on a second front, and that is for the wider community, which has shouldered the rapidly increasing burden of financing income support for them.

The report canvasses most of the key issues which have to be considered and on which this Government will have to take action. I trust that the period of consultation allowed-the seven weeks or so-will assist the Government in achieving answers. The point I want to make, in this short contribution, is the shameful political and careless way in which this Government has approached this problem. We introduced amendments to the legislation in 1983 which were voted down by the Government and the Australian Democrats. Subsequently Senator Durack introduced a private member's Bill which encompassed three key areas of change. It is worth noting that those three areas of change received little attention and were dismissed by Government speakers when addressing the legislation. Yet now we find in this paper acknowledgment of the three areas that Senator Durack's Bill proposed to challenge as being key areas for consideration.

In the debate on the Family Law Act in 1983 we sought to have the provisions which require the Family Court to take into account the availability of social welfare benefits in determining the maintenance obligations of non-custodial parents deleted from the Act. We failed in that but the Government-again, it was criticised when we brought the matter back into this place in Senator Durack's private member's Bill-now acknowledges in this discussion paper the structure of social welfare benefits and the deliberately low maintenance orders and agreements consequently made through the Family Court as being a key issue.

The second issue addressed in our Bill and now belatedly recognised by the Government as requiring attention and action concerns the priority of obligations facing non-custodial parents for the provision of support for their original and subsequent families. The third concerns the relationship between the division of property and the determination of maintenance. I welcome the signs that the Government may be stirring itself in this area. The poverty suffered by sole parents and their children and the excessive burdens of taxpayers stand as a condemnation of the Government's inattention to this matter over 3 1/2 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised by Senator Chaney's opening remarks in his contribution, but I think it is tied with the possibility of two criticisms. One is that his Government had seven years and why did it do nothing about this for all that time? His Government left us with such a mess when we came into government that it was not possible to address everything straight away. There is no doubt about that.
—That one has been done to death.

—Thank you for that contribution, Senator Walters. If only death would overtake the honourable senator. We have to say this again and again for the people to appreciate it. This Government came into office facing the chaos left behind by seven years of Fraser Government. In that time that Government did not address the maintenance question and yet its members have the gall to carp and criticise this Government, particularly in the face of this document about which some very useful comments have been made, including by Senator Chaney.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the debate about maintenance ought not to be too distracted by the tedious points of who should get the kudos. I think it is very important to appreciate that this document does give a focus for all of the critical issues involved in this area so that community discussion can focus on those issues that are indeed very well covered together in this booklet. Community response will be welcomed. In fact by some of us it will be sought very particularly and very actively. It is the Government's firm belief that, as is stated in the conclusions on page 41 of the report, titled `Child Support. A discussion paper on child maintenance':
. . . all children have a basic right to be supported by both their parents to the best of their ability.

I think that sentence needs to be underlined and reiterated. The rights and responsibilities of parents are recognised by this Government. Parents do have to accept responsibility for the financial assistance towards bringing up their children. The consequence of divorce particularly and marriage breakdown is the principal reason why we have such an increase in the number of sole parents. It is sometimes believed in the community that we have sole parents because lots of younger women are not seeking to be married. This document points out that that is a misunderstanding and that the majority of sole parents are the consequence of marriage breakdowns. Of course, as has been said by previous speakers, the consequence of those marriage breakdowns means that many of those single parent families-some 94 to 96 per cent of single parents are women looking after children-are now likely to be living in considerable poverty in this community. That is not to say that poverty did not exist prior to 1973 or 1974, particularly for women who were supporting parents. What we now have is the very hard statistical data to make that unmistakeable. Senator Chaney drew our attention to-this is on page 7 of this document-the dramatic increase in the number of families likely to live in poverty because of the increase in the number of sole parent families, particularly since the early 1970s and until 1985.

As well, an expectation has somehow developed in the community that the responsibility of non-custodial parents has not been insisted on to the extent that many non-custodial parents have abandoned their responsibilities for maintenance and have left it to the taxpayer to pick up the responsibility for the maintenance, care and provision of children in our community. That bill has risen from $160m in 1973-74 to $1,757m in 1985-86, which is an increase of 245 per cent in real terms. I think the Government is very concerned that not only will there be a response from the community on this discussion paper but that there will also be action taken by government to require the responsibility of parents, particularly non-custodial parents, to contribute to the maintenance of their children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is almost in a state of stunned disbelief that I rise to speak on this matter. I could not believe my ears at the former speaker's contribution--
—I can't believe your ears either.

—I could not believe what my ears heard, Senator Button, that a Government member would wish that death would over take a member of this chamber. It is one of the most childish and insulting contributions I have heard-only one of the most because I have heard a number from the Government, but that one in particular stands out.

SPEECH.PARA: I endorse the comments made by my Leader, Senator Chaney, on the paper on child support that the Government has released. The Government has had the report since 1984. Since then its Cabinet sub-committee has looked at it and no doubt it employed consultants at vast expense and now it has produced this report which has, as Senator Crowley said, focused on some of the issues that need to be resolved before the Government can proceed. Nonetheless, after all this time these issues are unresolved. It is simply not adequate for the Government to say that this is as far as it has come because it now needs to consult with the community. Seven weeks is not sufficient time in which to consult with the community.

As Senator Crowley pointed out, responses from the community will be welcomed and, as she further pointed out, they will be sought by some of us. I would like to be one of those people who would seek community response to this report. As a consequence of that desire I have tried to acquire further copies of this report so that I can distribute it through the community and ask people what they think. But I can get only 4, 5 or 6 reports from the office of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). For the Government on the one hand to pretend that this report is released as a discussion paper and that it is seeking views from the community and on the other hand to produce a report, sufficient copies of which are not available to allow that consultation process to proceed, is ludicrous in the extreme.

Another point that I do not think is adequately addressed in this paper is this: When the Government finally does decide on the resolution of these issues on which community views are being sought, it will presumably act and remedy the situation for the children of couples who will divorce from that point on. However, there remains the problem of the people on the supporting parent benefit, generally women in poverty, as sole parents with children who will not be assisted by the outcome of this report. I am not suggesting that any retrospective legislation be introduced which would affect the rights and responsibilities of people who have settled their arrangements on the basis of existing laws, but I am suggesting that something more could be done than what this report suggests. I look forward to the Government, as soon as it has dealt with this issue, dealing with the issue of the many people now living in poverty as a consequence of the inadequacy of our law in this respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important document which we are at last considering, because I think most people have been aware for a long time that it is necessary for us to amend the law as far as the payment of maintenance and the enforcement of maintenance orders are concerned. Senator Chaney has outlined our position on the matter in the past and has highlighted the fact that the Government did not respond to the opportunities it previously had to make some significant changes. Senator Crowley perhaps should also note that the Family Law Act only came into operation in 1976, so some considerable time was necessary to elapse before it was possible to assess what adjustments needed to be made. It is a fact that a number of children are living in poverty as a result of marriage breakdowns. When we assess what changes need to be made in the area of maintenance payments we have to be very careful that we do not just focus on one group of people who are in this category. There are some children from families which were living almost in poverty before the family broke up, and no changes in maintenance arrangements will help them a great deal. The responsibility for many of those children lies squarely within the social security system and will have to be addressed there. Of course, that is not the case with all children. We know that a lot of people pay maintenance, men and women, and accept a very real responsibility for their children. I think we also in that area need to be careful that we do not embark upon setting up formulas for establishing maintenance, setting up enforcement procedures, which intrude into the areas where maintenance is working properly. People whose marriages have failed but who both accept a very real responsibility in working together in a way that gives their children the very best opportunity should have the opportunity to make their own arrangement and see that it works. But having identified those two groups, those extremes, there are cases where maintenance is not paid where it ought to be and is not capable of being collected as it ought to be.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to remember that we are dealing with human beings and that as a result of marriage breakdowns there will be occasions when both parties will be vindictive. It is necessary in establishing formulas, new rules and enforcement procedures that somehow we get around that problem, so that a woman who wants to pursue her husband cannot do so in a way that is directed more by vindictiveness than by the welfare of the children or, on the other side, so that a man does not refuse to pay maintenance because he is attempting to get back at his wife. It is the children who will suffer most. It will be very difficult to draw up formulas that get it right. For that reason, although this matter is urgent, I suggest that to allow only from now until the end of November for submissions to be made flies in the face of what has to be done. There are many groups in the community which have looked at this problem and which have prepared papers. They now need to look at this problem in the light of what is before us and within the guidelines of what the Government has invited them to address themselves to.

The question of access has been mentioned. Nobody would suggest that access and maintenance should be tied together, but we cannot prepare any formula for the payment of maintenance and ignore the fact that access is frequently withheld and is used in a vindictive manner. There is no doubt that that is often the case. While addressing the question of maintenance one must look at the arrangements that can be made for access to children in some of the very difficult cases which presently are before the courts.

The Government has set out in paragraph 3 of the tabling statement the issues on which views are particularly sought. I think it is a pity that in that there has been no reference to taking into account the capacity of a custodial parent to pay. There are instances where the custodial parent has a better capacity to pay than the non-custodial parent. I would not want anyone to think that because it is the non-custodial parent's maintenance that is particularly being addressed that that should be ignored. It is referred to in passing under item (c) as to whether the custodial parent's financial circumstances should be considered and if so how. The present Act requires a court assessing maintenance to take into account the needs of the children and the capacity of parents to pay. Of course, the needs of the children still must be very much up front when we start considering contributions to the support of the children from each of the parents. We have to have a formula which takes into account the fact that at different ages children have different needs and demands. We have to have a formula which is capable, while not being abused, of being adjusted to meet these different matters. There is a great deal more that could be said. It is an important report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason for this discussion paper, `Child Support', is that in 1975 this Senate passed the Family Law Act that gave the judges, when deciding on maintenance, a requirement to take into account the eligibility of the supporting parent for the supporting parent's benefit. Judges are not entitled to ignore the fact that there is an eligibility, when deciding on matters of maintenance. In 1980 the then Fraser Government set up a joint select committee to review the Family Law Act. As a result of those deliberations we brought forward recommendations to cover the area of maintenance. Those recommendations were in the process of being legislated for when we went out of office and the Labor Government came in.

SPEECH.PARA: Because the Labor Government did not take any action at all in this area, Senator Durack introduced a private member's Bill in which it was suggested that the requirement for a judge to take into account the eligibility for a supporting parent's benefit when deciding maintenance should be taken out of the Family Law Act. The Government voted against that. I do not know why because ever since it has been beating its breast and saying that it should not be in there. It has now had two committees look at it. As has already been stated, this Cabinet sub-committee on maintenance has reported and the Government has had this report for some time. We know that 40 per cent of maintenance is not paid in full. We know that those who refuse to pay maintenance say they refuse to pay for a number of reasons. Some of these reasons have already been mentioned by Senator Reid. On matters of access they say: `If I'm not given access that has been attributed to me by a judge-the judge said I must have it-and I have not been able to get access easily from the mother looking after the children, I refuse to pay the maintenance'. This place cannot legislate for human behaviour. We have never been able to legislate to make parents responsible for their children. If they decide that they are not going to be responsible for their children we should make some effort, and we can make it easier for the law to place the responsibility where it should be placed, that is, on both parents.

I hope that the discussion paper will be distributed widely. It is important that people who are affected by this discussion paper be able to put their views to the Government. I hope that as a result of this discussion paper we will be able to work out the most appropriate way of gathering maintenance. Many suggestions are floating around the community that maintenance should be gathered either through the Department of Social Security or through the Australian Taxation Office. It is essential that we have that input by people who are affected in this area. I certainly hope that we will not go on and on, and that the Government will not linger in deciding this issue. It is imperative that something be done very quickly.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report and Text of Ministerial Statement

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 October, on motion by Senator Powell:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have the opportunity to return to the report of the Better Health Commission which came before us two or three days ago, at which point none of us had had an opportunity to grasp the magnitude of the work reported or the significance of the report. I expect that I am being charitable to Senator Sheil when I refer to his contribution on that occasion. I suspect that he looked very briefly at the report, took one small portion quite out of context and found that small portion, concerning specific targets to be established for the reduction of injury in Australia by the year 2000, to be a nonsense and a subject of levity, ridicule and trivialisation. This does the report and its authors a very serious injustice.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw attention to the fact that in sections 11.5 and 11.6 the report summarises for the very first time in Australia a composite picture of the nature and magnitude of the injury burden. I quote:

This investigation highlights two major factors: The need for adequate resources to be devoted to injury control, including premature death resulting from injury, which affects a substantial proportion of the population; and the need for a national centre for injury, epidemiology and prevention. No detailed data covering the total spectrum of injury, including its severity, magnitude and cause, exist.

From that beginning, the injury task force goes on to identify what is injury and then comes to the extent of the injury burden in Australia. There is no nonsense or trivia about this. It is a matter of very great concern. The report states:

Although there is a dearth of recent national data . . . the data that are available indicate that each year there are approximately 7600 deaths, 300 000 hospital admissions, 2 million bed-days, and 10 million medical treatments as a result of injury. It is estimated that the total economic burden of injury in Australia is approximately $11 000 million.

During this discussion the report goes on to summarise the recommendations of the injury task force. This is where the totally legitimate concept of targets is introduced. The World Health Organisation's program of health for all by the year 2000 contains implicitly the concept of targeting. It is a cause of great satisfaction to me that our Department of Health has so thoroughly produced a blueprint of this nature. To go once again to the specifics which Senator Sheil found so amusing, I refer to the report, which says there is evidence, for example, that proper rules for safety can almost eliminate pool drownings of babies as a cause of death. Therefore, being realistic the report does not say that pool drownings can be completely eliminated in the next year or so. The report proposes that the following would be realistic:
A 90 per cent reduction in pool drownings of children under 2 years of age by the year 2000; a 95 per cent reduction in pool drownings in all children under 12 years of age by the year 2000.

If we look further we might be able to say that the state of the wisdom of the world would be enough to eliminate 100 per cent of pool drownings by the middle of the next century. These targets are followed in the report by a set of perfectly legitimate and valid strategies for achieving them. I simply wanted to put on record that this report is full of excellent statements of this nature, statements which are realistic, which go to the heart of the questions and which should be seriously studied by everybody with an interest in the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to the report `Looking Forward to Better Health'. I refer to chapter 12, `Health Problems of Groups at Additional Risk', particularly the part which refers to the health of Aborigines. When one looks at the pessimistic view taken in the report one can only believe that there will be no improvement in Aboriginal health in the future. The submission from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs points out that the history of the Aboriginal people is one of conquest, dispossession, dispersion and oppression. It continues along those lines. One wonders where on earth we are going on this very important subject.

SPEECH.PARA: To measure the magnitude of the poor health of Aboriginal people we could look at the grave-yards, child care, hospitals, emergency services and homes for aged people. Then perhaps the magnitude of the problem before the nation can be appreciated to some degree. We have a very real responsibility to improve the health of Aborigines. This is not to say that something is not being done. In the field, in hospitals and in so many other areas there are many dedicated people but at the same time much has not been done that must be done. The Better Health Commission report states:
The Commission recommends that its proposed national `Community Development Fund' be especially applied to groups that have specific health concerns.

This is one of the aspects of Aboriginal health that concerns me because the report says that money in the form of a community development fund will help the problems. For quite a long time I have been talking about the money spent on Aboriginals. It involves an incredible amount. Just the budget for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is over $300m, I believe. If one adds up all the funds in the various other Federal government departments, the activities in the States and so on, in my estimation-it is very difficult to assess because governments do not know what they spend in association with each other-there would be well over $600m a year spent on Aborigines.

What is being gained? That is what concerns me. It seems that the achievement is to say: `We spend $600m on Aboriginal people'. But it should be seen how this money is spent because if money and services were better utilised there could be more inroads made into Aboriginal health. Between 1,000 and 1,200 organisations are funded supposedly for the benefit of Aboriginal people. Many of us who live in Aboriginal areas and, for that matter, honourable senators from other States, would know that a lot of money is ill spent and is not getting down to Aboriginal people at the nitty gritty. It is a very big regret of mine that money is being ill spent. Money which is required for better Aboriginal health services is not getting down to those people. Time is against me already, so I am unable to talk about child mortality and various other aspects of Aboriginal health. Perhaps at some other time I will have more time to do so. If the Australian Government and the Australian people wish to bring about better Aboriginal health they should consider the money that is being ill spent now, whether by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs or elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address some remarks to the part of the Better Health Commission report which refers specifically to the health problems caused in Australia by tobacco. I wish to relate those remarks to some actions by Qantas Airways Ltd which are not in keeping with efforts that have been made in this country over some years to make the Australian public aware of the dangers of cigarette smoking. I have in my possession-I think I obtained it from you, Mr Acting Deputy President, at an Estimates committee hearing-an empty packet of cigarettes containing the words: `Warning-Smoking is a Health Hazard'. You will know, Mr Acting Deputy President, as I know, that every packet of cigarettes sold in this country, in the States or the Territories, is required to carry a health warning. There are moves to change the health warnings on cigarette packets.

SPEECH.PARA: I became aware that Qantas Airways on its flights sells packets of cigarettes which do not have that health warning. I have in my possession now a packet of Benson and Hedges cigarettes which carries on its side the notation `Specially packed for Qantas' and which contains no health warning or statement that smoking is a health hazard. I have another packet of cigarettes, Peter Styvesant filters, also carrying the note `Specially packed for Qantas' and also containing no health warning whatsoever. These cigarettes were purchased by an acquaintance of mine on a Qantas flight. Not only do those cigarette packets have no warning at all, but also there is some other relationship between Qantas and the cigarette companies. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that I am holding a shopping bag containing on one side the Qantas logo and, on the other side, an advertisement for Marlboro cigarettes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which was tax deductible.

—As Senator Vigor says, it was probably a tax deductible exercise. So we are probably paying for some of this. I took the opportunity at a hearing of Estimates Committee F on 18 September to address some questions to officers of the Department of Aviation in relation to the unmarked cigarette packets and the shopping bag. I have subsequently learned, by the way, that the Peter Stuyvesant cigarettes, whose packets are without the health warning, are produced in Australia at the Phillip Morris factory in Moorabbin, Victoria. There is no question: They are not manufactured in India and brought on to the aircraft; they are manufactured in Moorabbin, in Victoria. The cigarette companies do this as a direct attempt to avoid having to obey the law which requires health warnings on packets.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Estimates, I addressed questions to a Mr Potter from the Department of Aviation. I have some sympathy for Mr Potter, who had to try to cope with all the questions. A number of questions were referred to Qantas Airways for answer. I might say that I always try to fly Qantas. I will continue so to do. Qantas is my preferred airline. However, I would like Qantas not only to obey the law of the land in relation to cigarette smoking but also the spirit of the law of the land. The spirit of the law in this country is that cigarette packets will contain information for the use of consumers so that they can become aware that smoking is harmful to health, a fact which surveys show up to 40 per cent of smokers do not know, even today.

The questions I put to Qantas were as to how Qantas explained certain matters, whether it felt it had a civic duty of corporate citizenship, whether it regarded its action as being outside the spirit of Australian law, what its relationship was with the cigarette companies and so on. I have now received through Estimates Committee F a letter from the Secretary advising me that Qantas Airways is refusing to answer the questions put to it at the Estimates Committee hearing and that it has referred these matters to its lawyers. The response states:
Qantas is involved in investigating questions of law with the Department of Health. A response will be forwarded as soon as it becomes available.

I find that highly unsatisfactory. We are concerned with better health for Australians. The diminution of smoking is the single greatest public health measure we could institute today to the benefit of Australians. Qantas Airways is not playing its part. It is clearly breaching the spirit of the regulations which apply in this country. When questioned it chooses not to answer by hiding behind some legal stratagem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a report entitled `Looking Forward to Better Health' by the Better Health Commission. The many and varied contributions to date highlight the many areas in which preventive medicine is important and that perhaps it should have a much higher profile. The area I specifically want to address relates to women. I hope that we will be able to say that from now on younger women can look forward to better health than has been the case for many women until now. I refer particularly to a problem which affects women more than men, osteoporosis, referred to in an article I read recently as `the quiet lady killer'. The reason I suggest that younger women ought to be able to look forward to better health is that now much more is known about his disease from the point of view of getting more exercise, not going on crash diets, maintaining one's calcium intake and being aware of the sorts of foods which contain calcium such as broccoli and red salmon which can help to increase the calcium content in the body, thereby helping to counteract the effect of osteoporosis.

SPEECH.PARA: Osteoporosis undoubtedly gradually happens to every woman, from about the age of 35 onwards. The report says that medical practitioners could be a major resource in preventing disease, particularly diseases which are caused mainly by specific behaviours or lifestyles. I hope that all doctors who have women patients over the age of 35 or so, particularly around the age of 50, will not just treat them for the things they ask about but also, on occasions, say to them: `What are you doing about the problem of defeating osteoporosis and not becoming another victim?'. Many older women in our community will become victims of and suffer from the consequences of osteoporosis. Victims of osteoporosis are in hospitals and nursing homes now. It is a debilitating disease. It is distressing and should be unnecessary in the future. It is certainly very costly to hospitalise the many women who suffer from broken bones because they have this disease.

I hope that the medical profession will accept a very high degree of responsibility to see that its women patients are made aware of the causes of osteoporosis and the ways in which they can help themselves not to become victims of it. It is a matter of diet. Other things can and need to be done. No doubt the disease will not be eliminated completely, but we can make significant inroads if there is publicity, if people talk about it and if women go to their doctors and ask about it. It is certainly frequently written about in women's magazines. If a woman's doctor says that it does not matter or that he or she does not know about it, the woman should go and find another doctor who will take the matter seriously. One's old age will undoubtedly be of a much better quality if one knows that one has done everything one can to avoid this disease. It is certainly possible. I have referred briefly to only one matter that is raised in this report. It highlights the need for preventive medicine, not just by doctors but by all of us. This is an area I regard as particularly important. I hope that gradually there will be more and more publicity so that the women of the future are free of osteoporosis.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend this report to the Senate. In speaking to the report, I wish to draw attention to the section headed `Study of Agricultural Co-operatives'. In February 1985 a working party on agricultural co-operatives was formed and its report was submitted to the Australian Agricultural Council with the following proposals:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the establishment of an Agricultural Co-operative Service;
(b) enactment of uniform co-operative legislation;
(c) a review of the taxation legislation and its effect on the operation of co-operatives;
(d) collection of uniform statistics on co-operatives; and
(e) specific research into aspects of co-operative operation.

I am concerned that the Australian Agricultural Council did not endorse the working party report but merely released it as a discussion document. I believe this represents an extraordinarily short-sighted attitude on behalf of the Agricultural Council. Given the current problems of viability being experienced by many rural people and the need for restructuring in the primary industry sector, co-operatives would surely represent an alternative economic unit, both for those facing survival problems now and for others who might wish to establish themselves in a rural industry but who lack substantial capital base in going in on their own.

I draw attention to a recent report on co-operatives prepared for the Victorian Government called `The Co-operative Way'. This report came to the Victorian Government from a ministerial advisory committee on co-operation which was set up in 1984. That report defines the co-operative philosophy as stated by the International Co-operative Alliance as follows:

The common element at all times has been that co-operation at its best aims at something beyond promotion of the interests of the individual members who compose a co-operative at any time. Its object is rather to promote the progress and welfare of humanity. It is this aim that makes a co-operative society something different from an ordinary economic enterprise and justifies it being tested, not simply from the standpoint of its business efficiency, but also from the standpoint of its contribution to the moral and social values which elevate human life above the merely material and animal.

This report to the Victorian Government also noted that co-operatives play an important part and could be a viable alternative to the agra-business firms which are making a heavy impact, forcing farmers to accept less for their produce as these giant firms increasingly monopolise agricultural markets. Further, Victoria today produces about 67 per cent of Australia's milk, which is almost all processed co-operatively. Co-operatives could play a crucial role in that they would ensure that farmers retain control over their produce. I think we can even look beyond Australia to the Mondragon co-operative enterprise in the Basque region of Spain where both rural and urban enterprises are undertaken in a co-operative way. Overall it seems to me that there is considerable potential for co-operatives in development in the rural sector, but, as the report says, future worker and food co-operative development are awaiting decisions from government. I hope that the Agricultural Council will look at the Victorian report and support its working party recommendations.

Finally, also from the report but on a different matter, as today is World Food Day, I simply take a minute to express concern at the resolution of the Council to oppose the Economic Community's ban on the use of growth hormones and to deplore the increasing and extended use of that process in Australian agriculture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate, noting Australia's rising inflation, increasing unemployment, worsening balance of payments crisis, record interest rates and declining investment-
(a) deplores the confusion created by misleading and contradictory statements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the state of the Australian economy and calls on the Federal Government to:
(i) reduce the record spending budgeted for this year,
(ii) restructure the industrial relations system as recommended by the Federal Opposition,
(iii) reduce the heavy burden of Government regulation, and
(iv) abandon its damaging anti-business taxes; and
(b) condemns the Treasurer for trying to paper over these defects by reverting to his old habit of falsely talking-up the economy.

Yesterday the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stood on the front steps of this place and said: `Gilt, gilt, gilt'. He was spelling it with an `i'. In fact, he spelt it wrongly. It is `guilt, guilt, guilt' on the Treasurer's part, relating to his guilt in misleading the people of Australia and, it may well be, misleading people overseas about the consequences of his own actions in playing such a large part in generating a very difficult economic environment for Australia. Let us look at how serious that environment is. We hear a lot about comments from overseas about Australia.
