When the Treasurer was talking about `gilt, gilt, gilt' and how much money could have been thrust upon him by overseas people had he only wanted it, his pockets were already full with the wooden spoon he was given during the week for being the world's second worst Treasurer. Let us look at what Salomon Brothers Inc., the world's leading international bond market people from the United States of America, said about the apparent strengthening of the Australian dollar. It said this:

The shift in sentiment appears to be related to the willingness of the Australian authorities to maintain a high interest rate policy for a longer period than financial markets had anticipated, although the recent economic indicators suggest that the Australian economy may be slipping into a recession.

What it is saying there quite simply is that the Australian authorities-the Australian Government-is artificially holding up interest rates, damaging the housing sector and hitting people who are borrowers, simply to push up the Australian dollar and to hold it up there. Salomon Brothers further said:
It is widely believed that the Government has set a floor of US$0.60/A$ for the currency and that rates will eventually be relaxed as the currency continues to appreciate.
I stress `the Government has set a floor'. It further said:

In the near term, the Government will be constrained by upcoming current account and inflation statistics. These data are expected to show a continued large deficit on the current account in September-
of course, that has happened now-
and October and a pickup of inflation in the third quarter of 1986 to 8.5% . . .

So there is a clear recognition from overseas that things in Australia are far from fine. The Treasurer apparently endorses the comments of Moody's Investor Services Inc. in Moody's Sovereign Credit Report, which predicted continuing high inflation, unemployment rises and current account imbalances for the current financial year. It said that structural rigidities in the labour system will constrain economic prospects into the 1990s. It said that short term interest rates will remain in the 14 to 18 per cent range, which is among the highest in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. It said that the economy will slow sharply in 1986, that escalating debt servicing charges will cancel out a large part of the trade gains from the depreciating currency and that the flow of long term funds into Australia is likely to slow as investors show a wariness about Australia's external debt situation.

In addition, Moody's described the Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions accord as being on shaky ground and declared that institutionalised wage inflation is a main cause of Australia's high inflation rates relative to its major trading partners. It said that with Australia's strong trade union movement there is limited scope for removing inefficiencies and rigidities and that Australia's international competitive position will continue to be undermined by this structural phenomenon. Moody's forecast that Australia's unemployment rate will average 8.3 per cent in 1986, and given the outcome of the first nine months this implies a projection that unemployment will rise to above 9 per cent before the end of this year. Moody's predicted the Australia's external debt to gross domestic product ratio, which is a measure of our external imbalance, will continue to rise through the next few years before stabilising around 1990.

This, of course, is in sharp contrast with what Mr Keating told an investment seminar in London only last week when he said that the debt burden would stabilise in the not too distant future. Moody's also warned of factionalism within the ALP between Hawke's free market centrists and the Party's socialist left wing and referred to the trade union movement as an albatross. It is worth noting what Moody's had to say because the Treasurer has now endorsed and accepted Moody's assessment. He has been trumpeting that all over the place.

Let us see what has happened as a result of the Treasurer's own actions. He is now saying that the economy is on track and that the Government has the right policy settings. He is saying all the same things that he was saying before April's extraordinary reversal. Remember, everything was going wonderfully then; there were no problems. In fact, he was encouraging Australians to borrow overseas, at enormous risk as it now turns out, in order to proceed with investment. He was criticising those people who did not do so. It was his confidence and his misleading of many Australians which caused them to go heavily into debt on foreign exchange markets. As a consequence many of them are in severe financial difficulties as a result of even further devaluations. Once again the Treasurer is giving the impression that everything is all right. The things he is saying now are as meaningless, as inconsequential, as misleading, as damaging and as dangerous as those very same words were prior to his banana republic statement of April-May. This Treasurer has no concern for the consequences of his comments other than the seeking of short term political gain.

What is really happening in Australia? Let us look at the rising inflation. The annual rate at the moment is 8.4 per cent, compared with the OECD rate of 2.2 per cent. Our rate is something like four times as bad as that of our major trading partners overseas. To my knowledge, that is the worst ever inflation ratio that Australia has had. Of course this is a result of the incredible activities of the world's second worst Treasurer. We have increasing unemployment. The rate currently is 8.4 per cent, the worst for 15 months, and it is rising toward 9 per cent. We have a worsening balance of payments crisis with an annual rate of something like $17 billion. That means that Australia is going bad at the rate of about $32,000 a minute. That is the rate at which we are going into debt because of the Government's incompetence and incapacity to regulate and effectively run this economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have lost $300,000 since you started speaking.

—I like the point. We have lost $300,000 since I started speaking and by the time this debate concludes, how many millions will we have lost? We have record interest rates. It is incredible to hear Senator Walsh still trying to pretend that, because on an overnight market once in 1982 a couple of people got caught in trading and had to cover themselves suddenly and unexpectedly, the momentary rate that applied that day reflects a genuine interest rate. This sort of phoney argument is just intolerable. Everybody knows that Australia is now suffering the worst real interest rates in its post-war history. At the moment these record interest rates are three times Japan's, they are 50 per cent worse than those of the United States, they are double West Germany's and they are one-third worse than those of the United Kingdom. Yet this Government appears to be quite happy to listen to Senator Walsh misleading the Australian people about the state of interest rates in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: What about economic growth? I do not know whether honourable senators are aware that Dr Barry Hughes, who is the Treasurer's adviser, was recently in Washington. It was reported that while he was there he made some comments about the Budget forecast of a 0.5 per cent increase in domestically generated product. That is a pretty appalling rate anyway. It was cut back because of the Government's belated recognition that it had overheated the economy. The 0.5 per cent which appears in the Budget apparently has now been revised according to Dr Hughes. No one has bothered to tell this Parliament. The Government would not tell the Senate. Senator Walsh would like to keep us in the dark. He has no interest in relating the truth or the reality to this chamber. He is endeavouring to keep this quiet. We heard the news from New York that the rate has been revised to zero. Judging by a report from a Government official, the Treasurer's economic adviser, this year's growth will be reduced from 0.5 to nil.

Dr Hughes is hoping that this will not mean a reduction of the hoped for 2 1/4 per cent rise in gross domestic product over the full year because the turnaround in our external account will make up the difference. In other words, imports will be reduced and exports will be increased in order to give us that 2 1/4 per cent growth. That is not going to happen. That is not talking the economy down; that is talking reality to try to make certain that people are not so misled that they are exposed to grievous risk, as they were exposed by the Treasurer in the past and as he is trying to expose them again now through this incredible and irresponsible talk that he goes on with.

The reality is that even if there is a 2 1/4 per cent economic growth rate this year that will lead to a significant rise in unemployment. Australia needs an increase of about 3 per cent in economic growth simply to maintain the present unemployment level. So we are certain to have a massive and continuing increase in unemployment even if this Budget forecast is achieved. But what Dr Hughes has admitted in Washington, and what the Government has not yet admitted, puts an immense additional pressure on the balance of payments situation. So far we see no evidence of this big increase in the external account. On the contrary, it is far worse. We have had enormous growth in external debt. It was $86 billion in June and it will be $100 billion or so by December. The current account deficit for the first quarter is $4.2 billion.

Let us see how the improvement, the turnaround in our external account that we keep being promised by the Government and its apparatchiks, is going. So far in this financial year exports are down by 3 per cent and imports are up by 4 per cent. This is providing, of course, a record deficit on merchandise trade of $1.5 billion. We have never in our history had such a trade deficit. Yet the Treasurer is still talking this economy up. We have throughout a whole range of activities-in the housing industry, for example-continuing disasters. We have had an 11 per cent fall in dwelling approvals in August. The Managing Director of the Housing Industry Association of Australia has said that the private rental market is in a parlous state and unless firm action is taken to alleviate the rental crisis, many thousands of low income families will be pushed even further into housing poverty. We see across a whole range of activities the consequences of this Government's extraordinary economic policies, which all stem back to one dominant factor-that is, its total refusal to cut its own spending.

We have heard all about the so-called spending cuts. How realistic are they? This Government will increase its spending by $4.8 billion this year. That is an increase of 6.9 per cent. It is a record increase even after one takes inflation into account. It is that massive increase in government spending that has taken place, not simply this year but over the previous three years, which has put the Australian economy into this intolerable situation. That is why the Opposition has a very sound, very sensible and very practical approach to resolving these problems. That is why the Opposition is calling on the Government to reduce the record spending budgeted for this year, and to restructure the industrial relations system, as recommended by the Opposition, and which has been pointed out by almost every overseas commentator as being a major reason for Australia's present economic disaster.

We certainly want to reduce the heavy burden of government regulation, which is one of the factors in the expected fall of one per cent in investment in Australia this year. Quite frankly, that expected fall of one per cent, I believe, massively understates what the real fall will be. We are saying we should reduce the heavy burden of government regulation to allow investment to proceed. Of course, it would also have a better chance to proceed if the Government were not forced to use monetary policy-in other words, high interest rates-to try to cover up its other massive mistakes.

Of course, we seek to abandon its damaging anti-business taxes. Income taxes overall are going up by 11 per cent to a record 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product this year. The Government keeps pretending that there will be tax cuts. We will deal with that later today when we debate another matter. But the reality is that under this Government the economy is in a crisis situation. We would have had problems anyway because of the terms of trade. But because of this Government's actions it is in crisis. To make matters worse, the Treasurer has in the past, and is now, talking the economy up and is trying to paper over his mistakes and his Government's mistakes, thus putting more and more Australians at risk.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly on Senator Michael Baume's motion. I know that many honourable senators wish to speak about the important issues that have been raised in this motion. I was interested in that part of the motion which calls on the Federal Government to restructure the industrial relations system-a very topical question at the moment. Only yesterday the Australian Council of Trade Unions was negotiating with the Government on the so-called two-tier system of wage fixing, the inevitable fact that the accord mark 2 is now defunct and a new wage fixing system must necessarily come into being. I believe that industrial relations and wage fixing are the critical issues today. As I have heard Opposition senators speak from time to time, it seems to me to be very clear that the essential difference they are advocating, as far as the management of the economy is concerned, between themselves and the Government, is that they have a different approach to industrial relations in general and wage fixing in particular. I believe that this debate could very profitably focus on this important and topical issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to throw in a few thought starters and indicate, in general terms, the Australian Democrats' position on wage fixing and industrial relations. In fact, next week we will, I hope, introduce a Bill which sets out in great detail our ideas on wage fixing. It is to be called a collective agreements Bill. The title, I think, indicates the fact that the Democrats believe there is a place for direct bargaining, for collective agreements, in the wage fixing system. To that degree we agree with the Opposition. But I am not absolutely certain what the Opposition is advocating, so I will say what I believe the Opposition's position is on direct negotiation and collective agreements. As I understand it, it is advocating that the employer and the employee negotiate directly on an agreement and that that negotiation should take place, if necessary, in isolation from the trade union movement. In other words, it is advocating that the work force and management should negotiate directly and, if necessary, bypass the trade union movement. It is also saying that they should be allowed to negotiate on both above award rates of pay and below award rates of pay; in other words, they should be allowed to negotiate the wage rates downwards.

The Democrats are in fundamental disagreement with the Opposition on those two matters. We see no way in which one can bypass the trade union movement in this country. I was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation. I must say that the Committee was brilliantly chaired by Senator Harradine. We heard evidence from almost every important trade union in the country. We heard evidence from every employer organisation in the country, and from the ACTU. It is my very firm belief, as it is of my Party, that there is no way that one can disband our system of conciliation and arbitration, short of a revolution. The system is ingrained in our society. To confront it would be to precipitate enormous industrial upheaval in this country.

Our suggestion is at variance with what the Opposition is advocating. We believe that there is a place for collective agreements, but only on the basis of above award payments. We believe that the parties concerned should get together and negotiate on a broad range of issues-not only on wage rates, but also on issues such as profit sharing, employee participation, working conditions and so forth. If there are to be negotiations on broad issues, it is better for the two parties-management and the work force-to negotiate directly, but in association with the unions. If one tries to bypass the unions they will demand their pound of flesh sooner or later. Any agreement on a company by company basis must involve the trade union movement. The better approach is to say: `We will negotiate directly with the trade unions and the workers on an agreement, but that agreement must be ratified by a secret ballot of all the work force'.

The problem with the large number of trade unions in this country is very real. In an enterprise there can be six, seven or up to 10 trade unions represented. The solution to that problem is to embrace the concept of a principal negotiating union. The unions within an enterprise get together and decide which is the dominant union, and appoint that union as the chief negotiating union. It then negotiates directly with management and arrives at an agreement which is set down in writing for a period of 12 months, two years or three years, and that agreement should be enforceable in our civil courts.

The essential point I wish to stress is this. The basic problem with Australia's industrial relations is that we try to use two systems concurrently. We have our system of centralised wage fixing and at the same time we negotiate directly with companies. This was common before the accord. Unions put a log of claims in front of enterprises and say: `We want to negotiate on that log of claims and if we do not get a satisfactory answer we will call a strike'. So management is used to direct bargaining. But the essential problem is that we use both systems together. We use centralised wage fixing-we have national wage cases-and we also allow unions at the same time to negotiate directly.

The Democrats' concept under our collective agreements Bill is to voluntarily disassociate the two systems. If the unions and management wish to negotiate directly they are allowed to do so within the legislative framework which would make an agreement legally binding in the civil courts. However, if they opt for that alternative they are not bound by the centralised wage fixing system. So we use one system or the other; not both together. If centralised wage fixing or collective bargaining were an option collective agreements would become very popular. Both systems could work without impinging on each other. If we were left to the parties concerned to decide which system they wished to adopt I believe we would find that collective agreements would become popular. Certainly they would become popular in companies that had export contracts to meet and companies that had specific problems. They would become popular with small business. They could arrive at an agreement, in association with the trade unions, setting down conditions for a period of years. They would be isolated from the centralised conciliation and arbitration wage fixing.

I hope that other speakers in this debate will make clear what the Opposition is advocating in its new industrial relations initiative. I would like them to address the problems of how they hope to negotiate awards downwards. I would like them to address the problem of how they hope to negotiate in isolation from the trade union movement. These are critical and central questions and I believe that the Opposition must address them. It must make it clear whether it is advocating a confrontationist approach in industrial relations, whether it thinks it can bypass trade unions and get away with it. I do not think that we can and I do not think that is the way to go. It will lead to enormous industrial upheaval. Trade unions are a part of life in this country; they are a necessary part of our conciliation and arbitration system. It is written into our Constitution. So let us accept the trade union movement and say: `We want to co-operate. But let us have two systems-a centralised system and a system of direct negotiation, both of which involve the trade unions'. One involves the conciliation and arbitration system and the other the collective agreements system which would be subject to new legislation and would establish a legislative framework to make written agreements between the work force and management legally binding.

It is probably no surprise to the Senate that there is no way that agreements can be made legally binding today outside the conciliation and arbitration system. So we need new legislation and with that I believe that we could set up two systems running together both of which were viable and would meet very pressing needs in specified industries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues today in first of all congratulating Senator Michael Baume on bringing forward this motion. I speak in support of him and my other colleagues in deploring the confusion that has been created by the misleading and contradictory statements on the state of the Australian economy by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who is trying to paper over the defects in the economy by reverting to his old habit of falsely talking up the economy and in doing so ignoring completely the parlous state into which the policies of this Government have put the Australian economy. It is a parlous state which is evident around us through rising inflation, increasing unemployment, a worsening balance of payments crisis, record interest rates in real terms, declining investment, declining consumption in Australia and declining economic growth all adding up to increasing unemployment. It is an extraordinary situation into which the Treasurer has put our nation and himself. Only two years ago, against everyone's expectations and the reality of the situation, Treasurer Keating was given an award by the influential magazine Euromoney as Finance Minister of the Year.
—The Mexican Treasurer got the award the year before.

—How he ever got that award I do not know. Senator Siddons says that it is probably because he followed Mexico. In the space of two short years he almost got an even more significant award. Yesterday he was nudged out by a short half head as the worst Treasurer in the world. He was second in line for the wooden spoon award for the man who has done the most harm to his economy. He ran in a notable field. The choice for the wooden spoon included Yugoslavia, Morocco, Australia and Malaysia. In the end, the winner of the wooden spoon award was the finance Minister for Egypt. The reason for this remarkable turnaround in the world's perception of the Treasurer, and through him, very sadly, the Australian economy, is the achievements that have been seen as a result of the economic policies of this country over the last two or three years and this Government's very conscious and very deliberate economic policy decisions for which the Treasurer has been the prime spokesman.

SPEECH.PARA: The dollar has plunged more than 50 per cent since Mr Keating received his Finance Minister of the Year award. Anyone who moves around the financial communities either here or overseas must get disgusted as I do with the fact that our dollar and our balance of payments have become the butt of endless jokes. We have seen for the first time in our history a reduction in our credit rating. We have seen our foreign debt mushrooming at an extraordinary rate. By June next year at the latest, it will reach a figure of $100 billion, yet only three years ago it was less than $30 billion.

As this has happened, the Treasurer has become even more contradictory and oscillatory in his attempts either to talk down or to talk up the Australian economy. Only on 20 March this year the Treasurer is reported in Hansard as saying of the Government's economic strategy:
The strategy has been entirely appropriate.
Again, on the same day, he is reported as saying:
The fact is that the Government's policy settings this year have been totally correct.
Only three weeks later, on 3 April, when addressing a conference on equity financing, the Treasurer said:

We are convinced that the policy mix which has underpinned our achievement-particularly the policies of the prices and incomes accord and our overall approach to fiscal and monetary policy-are the right mix for Australia.

Within a month of that, the Treasurer made his famous, or rather infamous, `banana republic' statement. Suddenly, within the space of three or four weeks, the Treasurer had turned his views on the Australian economy, its prospects, and its situation, both present and future, on their head, and he had accused the Australian economy of running the risk of rushing down the road to banana republicanism. But within six days of that, he was back on the track of trying to talk the economy up again. On 20 May, six days after his banana republic statement, he said:
. . . what we have is an entirely healthy economy.
He also said:
Let me make the point that the Australian economy has been entirely robust.

It is no wonder that the financial markets and the observers of the Australian economic scene-the people both within Australia and overseas whose decisions on investment and other financial matters determine the fate of this country in terms of economic growth, employment, inflation, interest rates, the value of the dollar, and so on-are greatly confused. The Treasurer obviously is. His Government also is obviously confused as to just what is the real state of the economy. If one looks at the situation in any depth at all, one can see that there are very considerable problems. I can only endorse entirely the comment by Terry McCrann in today's Melbourne Age when he said:
. . . Mr Keating has embarked on the dangerous course of talking up policy and the dollar to attract the necessary capital inflow to cover the current account deficit.

That is something that can be done for a period. One can paper over the cracks. But the longer one does that, the more difficult one makes the long term situation and the more difficult it becomes to take the necessary measures to correct that situation.

Just let us have a look at the real state of the economy, at some of the basic facts concerning the Australian economy today. Interest rates, in real terms, are at their highest level in our history. The level of unemployment is on the rise again. There is a very significant decline in the rate of economic growth in this country, including the rate of investment and the rate of consumption. Indeed, at a recent conference in Washington the Treasurer's private economic adviser, Dr Barry Hughes, was reported as having said that the Budget forecast of half a per cent real growth in domestically generated product for 1986-87, a key statistic on which the 1986-87 Budget was produced, has now been revised down to zero. That has some very significant implications for our balance of payments situation, for an even further slowdown in total gross domestic product growth, for an on-flow negative effect on investment and for an inevitable surge in unemployment.

These things are happening not, as the Treasurer would have us believe, because of matters outside the control of Australian governments or the Australian economy. They are essentially the result of economic policies deliberately put in place by this Government. Those polices have been lamentable, disgraceful and very costly to this nation in several key respects. I know that even the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has tried very hard within his own ranks to get spending under control. However, he missed; he failed lamentably. The Government as a whole, in terms of its spending, has produced a rate of increase which is entirely beyond the capacity of this economy to pay for. As a result of that, we have taxation which is now at record levels. We have borrowings at dangerously high levels, both domestically and overseas. All of these results have flowed directly from the Government's wanton, spendthrift policy in terms of the expenditure side of the revenue. I wish to quote from an excellent article by an acute observer of the Australian scene, David Hale, who, after examining the Australian economy just a few months ago, wrote:

When the financial history of the 1980s is written, Australia's large offshore borrowing may prove to be a case study of how large budget deficits interacted with financial deregulation and surplus global liquidity to produce a dangerous and ultimately destabilising rise in external indebtedness.

That in turn all stems from the essential problem that this Government has faced, and that is its total inability to control expenditure to a level that is within the capacity of governments, and more importantly, the nation to pay. The price that this has imposed in terms of the whole range of activities in this country is enormous.

They are the sorts of things that financial markets are looking at. They are the sorts of things that are making people disbelieve the ability of the Treasurer of this nation to produce policies which are in line with the needs of this nation. It does the Treasurer no credit at all to quote selectively, to paint up a picture of the Australian economy which is totally out of line with reality. If this picture is not changed in terms of the policy direction of this Government, as the highest spending and highest taxing government Australia has ever known, the Treasurer's premonitions of months ago will prove much more accurate than his wantonly deliberate and misleading statements of recent days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In July 1985 the trade weighted index of currencies stood at 68.5. A year later it was valued at 49.8. This is a depreciation of 28 per cent in 12 months. Against the yen-the currency of our major trading partner, Japan-the fall has been considerably more. In fact, Australia's fall from respect has paralleled that of the fall from grace of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), because a little over two years ago he was stamped as one of the best Treasurers in the world. As my colleague Senator Short said, he was narrowly beaten for the wooden spoon just recently. In New South Wales students studying for the Higher School Certificate are being advised in the special school feature in the Telegraph, written by experts in their field, that the J-curve is deemed to be a likely question in the economics exam. The interesting feature of the article on that is that if they want to pass this exam they need to recognise problems in the J-curve phenomena:

SPEECH.PARA: Like the Scarlet Pimpernel `the cursed Keating seeks it here, seeks it there . . .' as so much of government policy hinges on the upturn of the J or an improvement in the ballooning current account deficit. The politically thorny path of high interest rates to support the declining $A and to slow down the import `gobbling' recovery was expected to be a short one: one abandoned as Australian competitiveness and the current account deficit improved.
How did those experts sum it up? They said:
The J-curve was a `get-out-bet' in the last race and regrettably it's still running.
This expertly written article just shows how out of touch the Treasurer of Australia really is. At the moment even he would not pass the HSC economics examination.

Let us get off the subject of the Treasurer and look at some of the problems besetting Australia. The Australian economy remains riddled with so many regulations and other restraints to competition that even if all tariffs and quotas, my dry friends, were removed there would be no guarantee that improved efficiency would result, because in Australia we have a high level of bureaucratic interference, an inflexible labour market and a lack of research and development, and all of these contribute to Australia's declining performance. Australia has a high reliance on imports of capital and intermediate goods. This means that when the value of the dollar goes down, firms' cost structures move up. Competitiveness is eroded as a result of currency depreciation.

One of the best yardsticks with which to gauge the state of the economy is the ratio of foreign debt servicing costs to the value of our exports of goods and services. Five years ago debt servicing costs-this was in the time of that so-called dreadful Prime Minister, Mr Fraser-were only 8 per cent of our export income. The figure now, under the Hawke Government, this so-called great achieving Government, in 1985-86, is likely to be 36 per cent, and for 1986-87, 39 per cent. This almost puts us in the same category as the Philippines, Morocco and Nigeria. We recently entertained the Indian Prime Minister. How does India perform in relation to this ratio? It stands at 15.5 per cent. Where is Australia? It stands at 36 per cent-India is less than half. Where does Canada stand? It stands at 16.6 per cent. Japan stands at 9.7 per cent and the Netherlands at 3.9 per cent. This is testimony to the poor state of the Australian economy and it has all happened in the time of this Hawke Labor Government. We are really in trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be 42 per cent soon; 42 per cent this year.

—And it is growing, yes, Senator Baume. Australia must have a dramatic fall in interest rates before we can expect an upturn in our domestic economy. Those in the Government and in the Australian Council of Trade Unions who continually urge business to invest more are obviously unaware that business will do so only when the after tax real rate of return on investments exceeds the available return on low risk financial assets. But what is the best that the ACTU can say? It says that business has gone on strike in Australia. What a pathetic attitude. It is vital that Australia increase its domestic savings and raise its export performance. Australia will see no improvements in its economic position until the terms of trade can be turned around. The Government is blaming low commodity prices as the sins for all its neglect.

SPEECH.PARA: The slight improvement in the value of the Australian dollar in the past few weeks could prove to be a problem to us unless there is a coinciding improvement in the terms of trade. In fact, our balance of payments problems could worsen as imports become cheaper and exports become more expensive. Australia is the only developed country whose exports have failed to grow as a percentage of gross domestic product over the last decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whose fault is that?

—That is right; it is your responsibility. Our traditionally strong mining and farming export sector can no longer be relied on to support the economy. Falling prices and stronger competition dictate that Australia must improve the quality, marketing and packaging of its products. In spite of all the Government's rhetoric about encouraging exports and the growth of Australian industry, it has set out systematically to destroy business incentiveness. How has it done this? It has established abhorrent taxation regimes such as the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax, negative gearing and increases in company tax rates. There are millions of dollars in Hong Kong and all around Asia that people want to bring into productive investment in Australia, but this has been prevented by the high tax rates applicable to companies. The money we are getting is going into all those speculative areas; the very things the Government condemns all the time, but its policies are pushing in the wrong direction. It is encouraging the wrong sort of growth and investment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government claimed earlier this year that investment would be strong next year as firms, particularly those in manufacturing and mining, move to take advantage of the depreciation of our currency and induce improvements in our international competitiveness. I must say that the prospect of this occurring at this stage seems remarkably remote. In fact that is what the kids were told when they were studying for their HSC if they wished to pass the economics exam. The Government's economic policies, centred on the prices and incomes accord, have provided significantly higher inflation, higher wage and interest rates than have been provided in our major trading partners. This is a major problem which we are faced with because the accord has not proved to be the big success that the Government claims it has been. In fact Moody's Investor Services Inc., which recently downgraded our credit rating, saw the inflexibility of the prices and incomes accord as not being able to cope with the critical trade problems we are facing. In order to run the country efficiently Australia must have a more flexible system, particularly in the wages area, so that when the terms of trade improve the country can take advantage of that.

The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission must be made to acknowledge that our terms of trade deterioration must be taken into serious consideration in future national wage decisions. We seem to have a preoccupation with entitlements rather than with ability to pay. Restraint with equity was the explicit basis of the accord. However, since the accord unions have gone from strength to strength. What is the ordinary person's attitude to this? Opinion polls have shown a steady drop in public approval of union activity in recent years. In fact a recent poll showed that eight out of 10 Australians believe that the unions have far too much power. I wish to compliment my colleague, Senator Michael Baume on his motion. I support the motion 100 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the notice of motion moved by Senator Michael Baume, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate noting Australia's rising inflation, increasing unemployment, worsening balance of payments crisis, record interest rates and declining investment-
(a) deplores the confusion created by misleading and contradictory statements made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the state of the Australian economy and calls on the Federal Government to:
(i) reduce the record spending budgeted for this year,
(ii) restructure the industrial relations system as recommended by the Federal Opposition,
(iii) reduce the heavy burden of Government regulation, and
(iv) abandon its damaging anti-business taxes; and
(b) condemns the Treasurer for trying to paper over these defects by reverting to his old habit of falsely talking-up the economy.

The Australian Labor Party Government could not have come to office in a more favourable world economic climate. Real gross national product in the United States of America grew by 6.6 per cent in 1983-84. Over the previous year it increased by 4.4 per cent. Real GNP grew by 4.3 per cent and then by 4.8 per cent over the same period in Japan, and by 4.5 per cent and 4 per cent in the seven major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. The growth in the major economies of the world, countries which form our major trading partners, provided an enormous boost to the Australian economy. At the same time the drought broke and during that year Australia's total agricultural production increased by 24.7 per cent, equivalent to a windfall to the economy of something of the order of $4 billion. Together, these factors contributed to major increases in export earnings.

In the two years from 1982-83 and 1984-85 our export earnings increased by 41 per cent. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) at that time saw himself as the world's greatest Treasurer. This Government took all the credit, but the situation was that there was little more than fortuitous circumstances at that time. The Government was riding on the crest of a wave with no long term vision for the future of Australians. While it lasted it kept on riding. The Government spent and spent, increasing outlays by 15.7 per cent and 12.9 per cent in its first two years of office. In an increasingly competitive world market the Government tolerated an industrial relations system which was and still is hopelessly inappropriate for modern international trading conditions. In the name of consensus the Government effectively handed over the economy to the trade union movement with, in the first place, accord mark 1 and accord mark 2, and in the second place with the National Taxation Summit farce which gave, as we now know, the Australian community the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax.

Fortuitous economic circumstances do not last forever and there comes a time when a government must do that which it was elected to do. Talk no longer works. Policies are needed and hard decisions are required. Decisions have to be made. Governments have to govern. The Hawke Government has betrayed this trust. It has not governed. It has let the Australian people down, it is sending the economy into ruin, and it is gambling with the future of our children as it does so. We now have an annual rate of inflation of 8.4 per cent which is more than three times that of the inflation rate of our major trading partners. The unemployment rate is now at 8.4 per cent and this is higher than all but five months of the 86 months of the Fraser Government. Presently, there are 634,200 unemployed, and 31,800 young people between the ages of 15 and 19 are presently looking for work. This is six weeks before more young people will come on to the job market. In fact, more than one in five of the people between the ages of 15 and 19 can expect to stay on the dole under this Government.

Australia's balance of payments deficit is still hopelessly out of control. We spent $13,713m more than we earned last financial year. This is the largest current account deficit in the industrialised world on a per capita basis. Other than the United States, to my knowledge, in aggregate terms it is the highest. In September, the balance of payments deficit was $1,450m taking the total for the three months to the end of September to $4,263m. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) tells us that he is reasonably satisfied with the current account figures. The deficit for the three months to September this year is 18.6 per cent higher than the deficit for the three months to September 1985. If the Prime Minister is `reasonably satisfied' with the balance of payments deficit increasing by more than 18 per cent over the past 12 months, I wonder what is his idea of a problem.

Australia's interest rates are the highest since the Great Depression. Overdraft rates start at around 19 per cent and rise into the low 20 per cent range depending upon the customer. Finance company interest rates vary between 20 per cent and 24 per cent for the purchase of some goods. These rates of interest are a direct result of the Government holding the dollar at a higher rate than the market would otherwise have given it. It is a reflection of the $2 billion of taxpayers' money that has been sent to the money markets to prop up the dollar at the modest level at which it presently flounders. The government has also had to maintain the exchange rate at a higher level than the market would have set. If it falls any further it will, of course, spark further increases in the consumer price index. This Government does not have the courage to tell the trade union movement that there will be a discounting effect on wages if the consumer price index is to be compensated throughout the economy. Again, this Government has shirked its responsibility and fails to govern in a responsible way.

The need to finance our current account deficit has been met, by and large, by borrowings. Our high domestic interest rates have, however, forced many borrowers to find sources of funds overseas. At the end of June 1983 Australia's gross external debt was $35,646m or 13.7 per cent of gross domestic product. At December 1985 it had risen to $74,589m. Treasury estimates in the Budget Papers now put the figure at $86m to the end of June 1986, or 37 per cent of GDP. Australia's debt has more than doubled in the 3 1/2 years that this Government has been in office. Some is private debt. However an increasing percentage is public debt. A significant proportion is now public debt. In June 1983, the first year of this Government, the public sector was responsible for, by Australian standards, a modest 14 per cent of the net external debt. At the end of 1985 it was responsible for 34 per cent of the net external debt. To a very large extent this is due to the need for the Government to borrow to finance its spending programs.

The high interest rates, the lack of confidence in the economy and the Government's taxes have all contributed to a fall in real investment in Australia. Private new capital spending fell by 19.1 per cent in seasonally adjusted constant dollar terms in the June quarter. This is the highest fall in this Government's term of office. It is the highest fall that I can remember in many years. Gross domestic product has either fallen or stayed constant for three quarters in a row. That, by definition, is a recession; that, by this Government's definition, is a recession. The response of the Prime Minister, of the Treasurer, and of the Government, has done nothing more than try to talk the economy around. Earlier this year the Treasurer was maintaining that the economy was running to plan-whatever his nefarious plan might be. On 2 March 1986 Mr Keating said:
The economy has been doing very, very well.
On 11 March of this year he said:
The fact is that the policy mix at the moment is entirely and appropriately balanced.
The Prime Minister also contributed to this euphoria. At a Press conference on 19 February 1986 he said:
This is a government which has shown its capacity to produce an overall economic strategy which produced the best results for the economy.
At the National Press Club on 5 March 1986 the Prime Minister said:

We don't have to come to the Australian people and say: `Trust us', we will do it, because we have got the runs on the board. That is the way we have operated successfully to this point. We will do it again in the preparation of the 1986-87 Budget.

Yet within the space of two months the economy had changed from being on course to being on the course towards becoming a banana republic. Now, only several months after these statements, the Treasurer is claiming that there is a new-found air of confidence in the Australian financial markets and that the Budget strategy is again working. I wonder who the Treasurer imagines he is fooling. Does he really believe that the average Australian, in an economy of $230,000m, imagines that in one month all the structural faults inherent in a banana republic can be rectified as a result of a Budget? The Treasurer certainly has not fooled the business community or those contemplating investing. This talking rather than taking decisions which are necessary to put Australia back on the road to prosperity is why the country is in the trouble that it is in.

Rather than being the world's greatest Treasurer as he was but two years ago, Mr Keating is now judged by the people who gave him that rather illustrious title-Euromoney-as being in a photo-finish for the worst Treasurer in the world. The policies which the Government has pursued have not improved the economic situation but have contributed to its destruction. Those policies were formulated in the boom years. There has been no attempt to prepare Australia for years when things are not as easy as they have been. This dereliction of duty has placed Australia in its present situation. Worse still, stubborn persistence with this extravagant style of government means that this Government has not learned from its mistakes. It has continued to compound its errors.

The most crucial need in Australia today is to make existing industrial components competitive and to provide an economic climate in which there will be investment in new productive and competitive industries. The policies of the present Government have not provided this. This Government is a high spending, high taxing government. In 1984-85, in a more prosperous economic climate, Commonwealth spending was equal to 30.4 per cent of GDP. That was at the time when we were high-rolling, when we set our sails for future strong growth. We were running well, on top of the waves. Now we are in a climate equivalent to `a state of war', to quote the Prime Minister. What harsh decisions has the Government made? It plans to spend the equivalent of 29.4 per cent of GDP. Its decision to rectify the state of the economy will reduce the sector of GDP related to government spending by one pathetic per cent.

The sacrifices which have been made have not been made by harsh decisions of government but by taxpayers. Taxes have increased by 11.1 per cent, equal to 25.5 per cent of GDP. Australians, on average, will now be working for almost three days out of ten for the Commonwealth Government. We work from the beginning of the year until about 17 May each year at the present rate to pay for government spending alone. My time has almost expired. As long as this Government continues in pursuit of its present economic policies and continues in its headlong fashion as a large taxing, large spending government with no cognisance of the reality of economic signals we can expect the economy to continue to deteriorate. No short term measures will achieve a turnaround in the economy. Structural rigidities in our export commodities will not be varied in the short term, so we can expect the economy to continue to deteriorate because this Government is neither competent, confident nor capable of changing the economy to one which is compatible with the Australian lifestyle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the motion by my colleague Senator Michael Baume today which very correctly and in a timely way points out the difficulties in the Australian economy, draws attention to the real problems being faced by the Australian people and points to a line of action that should be undertaken by this Government to restore some sanity to the Government's control of the economy. The situation has been outlined very well by my colleagues who have told us about the problems in the economy. Let us focus on the great and critical weakness of this Government's period of office of the last 3 1/2 years. Essentially, it boils down to the fact that this Government has believed in borrowing, borrowing, borrowing on world markets to blow up the economy, to create a situation in which it believes that it can get away with an argument that it has actually done something to improve the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: All the Government has done, as with any balloon with a pump attached, is blow the economy up more and more so that when it finally explodes we will all be covered in confetti-bits of rubbish-which will be deflated valuable dollars. Eventually they will come back as borrowings which our children and grandchildren will have to repay out of the future earnings of this nation. That is what this Government has done. It has taken over a country with a modest borrowing program totalling about $35 billion in 1983 and built it up to a level now of something like $100 billion. The drag on our Budget of some $7 billion or $8 billion a year in terms of interest servicing and charges is now costing us more than the education budget, the defence vote and the health vote. This is becoming an extremely heavy burden upon the taxpayers.

Who is responsible for all this? It is quite critical to understand where the problem really lies. If ever we had an example of where the real blame lies it was on our television screens last night when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was interviewed outside this building and said that he could have come home from Europe in the last couple of days with his pockets stuffed full of money because everyone wants to lend money to Australia. He said that he could bring back another $20 billion for Australians to borrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is worse than Rex Connor.

—Of course, Rex Connor wanted only $4 billion. This man wants to bring in $20 billion. When one thinks about what the trade union movement has as its national development plan-confiscating superannuation funds' money to put into a compulsory government investment scheme-we have a very clear idea of the way this Government thinks about such matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us come back to the borrowing of $20 billion that the Treasurer claims he could raise immediately for the benefit of Australians. What is he really telling us? He is saying that there is no hope of getting the balance of payments into any kind of order and that we must be prepared to continue to borrow and borrow, $1.4 billion, every month, to keep the economy afloat and pay for the deficit on our current account.

TALK.START.PARA: —And do it through high interest rates.

—As Senator Baume rightly points out, it will have the inevitable result of creating higher and higher levels of interest rates. We all know what that means. It will be harder for individuals to buy their homes and vehicles-big ticket items in particular-and also just to stay alive. More importantly, it makes it extremely more difficult for business to be able to borrow and invest in new job opportunities. That is the fundamental and critical problem that we all face; that we do not create enough jobs to employ our young people, let alone to reduce significantly the unemployment level which is running at 8.5 per cent, or there- abouts. So this Treasurer is committed to a future policy of borrowing more and more, of putting this country into hock with overseas bankers, more and more. The Treasurer seems to enjoy getting around the world and talking to bankers and no doubt enjoying their hospitality. One does not know whether those people are getting tax deductions for that entertainment, but they would not be doing so in Australia because the Treasurer has wiped out those tax deductions. The Treasurer seems to enjoy hobnobbing with the bankers of this world. He seems to be currying favour with them at the expense of the Australian taxpayer. He wants to borrow more and more to keep us out of trouble.

SPEECH.PARA: This is in absolute contrast to the lies we have been told by this Treasurer over quite a number of months. We were told that everything was getting better and better until we had the famous statement in May that we were on the verge of becoming a banana republic. The Treasurer must have had a rush of blood to the head. The truth suddenly came home to him. He realised something the Opposition had realised for a long time. When we were being told how terrific everything was the Opposition was being lampooned and criticised up hill and down dale by the Treasurer. We were called sleazebags, frauds, immoral cheats, blackguards, pigs, mugs-you name it; he used anything he could lay his tongue to. We were told that all our arguments were crazy. Yet eventually the Treasurer had to admit that the banana republic was around the corner. That sudden change on the part of the Treasurer has so unsettled business confidence in this country and undermined even more the position of investors in this country. The Treasurer's actions, his ill-thought-out, hasty, ill-considered, shoot-from-the-hip-type statements are doing so much damage to the Australian economy.

The interest withholding tax announced on 1 July was designed somehow to get at the borrowings from overseas. The Treasurer realised that when the dollar crashed to 57c within a month, he had to do something drastic about it. So before he had even introduced the legislation, he immediately announced that he was not going ahead with it. This kind of nonsense and unsettling behaviour by one of the leading Ministers in this Labor Government is creating so much damage to the Australian economy. I believe that it is time Mr Keating resigned from his position as Treasurer and handed his position over to somebody else who might be in a more stable frame of mind and be able to control the affairs of this nation a little better than he is able to do.

Worst of all is the fact that this Government relies so much on raising the levels of taxation higher and higher in order to fund its spending. It is now taking the greatest share of gross domestic product in tax of any Federal government in history. This is in direct contravention of the supposedly firm, solid, sincere commitment given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the last election in 1984 when he committed this Labor Government not to increase taxation on the Australian people above the level of the previous year. Yet at the first opportunity he had, in both the 1985 and 1986 Budgets, he imposed a higher level of taxation on all of us. It is the highest level we have ever seen and poses a tremendous problem for the Opposition when it becomes the government in 18 months time. It will have to scale back the huge burden of taxation on the Australian people. I believe that we owe Senator Michael Baume a debt of gratitude, as do the Australian community and the Senate, for bringing forward this most important motion which has my wholehearted support and that of my colleagues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I share Senator Michael Baume's concern for the future of Australia's economy. I support his diagnosis of rising inflation, increasing unemployment, a worsening balance of payments crisis, record interest rates and declining investment, but I do not support all his solutions. Australia, like most developing countries, faces a crisis of similar proportions to that faced by Germany before the 1939 war. The crisis is not local. It is caused by a massive breakdown of the world's economic system and its trade. It affects both developing countries and developed nations, but in different ways, depending on their current state of industrialisation. Unemployment is a general international problem caused by the increasing automation of industrial processes which a lack of planning enhances.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is also shared by Australia. Technology and wealth have concentrated in the hands of corporations which cross national boundaries and which owe allegiance to no people and to no government. The maximisation of profits and tax avoidance world-wide seem to be the main drives of such corporations. One of our problems is that we are not collecting tax from the right people. I am talking about taxation rorts such as transfer pricing, which neither the Government nor the Opposition is willing to attack. It is extremely important that we follow-up this rort in Australia. Successive reports of the Commissioner of Taxation over the years have dealt with this rort. A new Division 13 was inserted in the Tax Act to replace section 137 to counter most effectively avoidance of Australian tax through what is commonly referred to as transfer pricing or profit shifting arrangements. That was mentioned in the 19821-82 report. A much bigger section in the 1982-83 report deals with this rort. It states:

These practices have been given a great deal of prominence in recent years, both in Australia and overseas, largely as a result of the growth of international economic activity and the increasing use of tax havens . . . Some industries more than others possess all or most of the classical features generally found to be associated with profit shifting.

The report said that the Taxation Office was trying to co-operate with the United States Internal Revenue Service for industry-wide exchanges of information associated with the aluminium and oil industries. In the 1983-84 report, an even bigger section deals with transfer pricing. There was still inaction by the Government. The report stated:
This innovation-
which was the monitoring of international business transactions-
followed increasing concern over the incidence and potential use of transfer pricing and other arrangements to shift profits abroad or to eliminate taxation in Australia . . .
The other main role of the new branch-
which was being introduced into the Taxation Office-
is to examine selected foreign investment proposals and certain exchange control applications to discover taxation implications which may be detrimental to the Australian revenue.
Research has shown that profit shifting is more prevalent in particular industries.
. . . Cases being examined at 30 June 1984 were drawn from seven industries and further studies were being conducted into others . . .
More accurate criteria are being developed for selecting potential audit cases.
In 1986, all of that has been dropped. We have now completely dropped the proposals of 1983-84. The 1984-85 report states that heavier penalties are needed. It states:

Treaties issued to companies in six industries with total adjustments to taxable incomes of $183m and total increases in tax payable of $80m. Some of these adjustments are under challenge. In excess of 90 cases have been identified for examination of transfer pricing practices.
This seems to be only the tip of the iceberg. The report continues:

Increased computer resources will be required to cope with the expansion of audit activity in the international arena. Industry studies have been undertaken in respect of 10 industries to date and industry-wide audits have commenced in those industries identified as having features conducive to profit shifting practices.

In 1986 the Treasurer reversed all of these types of foreign controls and all of the controls which would allow these tax rorts to be detected and closed down. What has he done? He has left our own farmers and small businessmen completely open to major taxation problems.

The real solutions are not those solutions proposed by Senator Michael Baume. What we need to do is introduce a few large scale government backed projects, such as the Snowy Mountains scheme, which we had previously, and later the European Launcher Development Organisation Program-the ELDO program-at Woomera, which brought money into the country. However, we also need to support technology and to buy Australian-particularly the Department of Defence and Telecom Australia. The Australian Government is not properly supporting any of these major technological developments. I believe that the 150 per cent tax deductions which have been introduced and the grants for industry research and development are only very small attempts to overcome our problems. In the meantime, the Government continues to kill the geese that lay the golden eggs, such as the Overseas Telecommunications Commission and Telecom and their dependent high technology industries. There is no respite in sight. The Treasurer is the chief executioner.

I believe that the Treasurer has left himself no alternative but to try to paper over all of the defects and to talk up the economy, because he seems to be devoid of any other sensible or reasonable solutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Vigor for allowing me the remaining time. We heard from Senator Cook today that anyone who criticises the Government's economic policies and what this Government has done to the economy is nothing short of a traitor. We are told that we are saboteurs. The Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, has said of members of the New Right, who are pointing out that the Government's economic policy has been a great disaster to this country, that they are traitors. Mr Hawke has called them troglo- dytes. Any criticism of the Government or of its economic policies is met with threats and intimidation. This is a sad state for a democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: The balance of payments figures that came out yesterday show that for the September quarter the deficit was $4.263 billion-the highest on record. For the first quarter of 1986-87 it is the highest on record.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $32,000 a minute.

—It is increasing by $32,000 a minute, I am told by Senator Michael Baume. The current account deficit went up 19 per cent on the same quarter last year. Yet we are told by Senator Cook that we must not talk about it, and that if we do, we are saboteurs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer, Mr Keating, has gone further. Indeed, he leaked a foreign document in the House of Representatives. Today there is a report by the Australian Associated Press that the executives of Moody's Investor Services Inc. are furious at the premature leak of its confidential assessment of the Australian political climate. Moody's was shocked today to learn that the Treasurer had read a copy of its report to the Parliament. The Moody's spokesman stressed that the political analysis of Australia was not part of last month's credit review but was a separate document still in the draft stages. The time available to me has expired. I have no hesitation at all in supporting the motion moved by Senator Michael Baume.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Michael Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time allotted under Sessional Orders for consideration of General Business having expired, the Senate will proceed to the further consideration of Government Business.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted earlier I was speaking about the benefits which will be available to young people through the student assistance legislation we are debating today. A further benefit will be that Austudy will also be available to homeless students under the age of 16 years but above the minimum school leaving age, which in my State, Victoria, is 15 years. Eligibility for such students to receive assistance will be determined under the same conditions as for the young homeless allowance, another major reform which this Government initiated earlier this year.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is an integral part of the Labor Government's scheme of financial support for young people. From 1988 there will be three basic sets of age-related rates of Commonwealth support for young people over 16 years. First, there will be a common basic rate for 16- and 17-year-olds whether they are in secondary education, tertiary education or unemployed and the rate will be indexed for movements in the consumer price index. A relatively small number of eligible 16- and 17-year-olds will continue to receive a living away from home allowance and secondary and tertiary students in that age group will be able to qualify for an independent allowance under identical conditions. There will be a common rate for unemployed 18- to 20-year-olds, for students over the age of 18 years and for tertiary students living away from home. The unemployment benefit rate for 18- to 20-year-olds will subsequently be indexed annually and the student independent or living away from home rate will be made equal to the unemployment benefit. From 1989 there will be a common rate for secondary students 18 years and over and for tertiary students who live at home. The real value and relativity of these rates will be maintained by setting them at 63 per cent of the 18- to 20-year-old unemployment benefit rate from 1988.

There has been a lot of comment in the Press and in the community in recent years about the retention rate of students, particularly secondary students. For example, in yesterday's Age Professor Aitkin, a professor of political science at the Australian National University, claimed that the proportion of the relevant age group enrolled in Year 12 is only about half the proportion enrolled in some other developed countries. This is certainly a cause for concern and this Government has done a great deal to address this problem in the last 3 1/2 years. Retention rates to Year 12 level have increased since Labor came to office, from 36.3 per cent in 1982-just before we came to office-to 46.5 per cent in 1985. That is an increase of over 10 percentage points. Of course many factors are involved in influencing retention rates but the financial assistance available to students in the lower socio-economic groups in particular is one of the most significant. In 1985 the Commonwealth Department of Education put out a summary report entitled `Patterns of Retention in Australian Government Schools', which states:

Of those students receiving the SAS allowance, some 16 per cent considered the allowance was very important in their decision to return to school, 14 per cent indicated it was fairly important, 23 per cent said that it was slightly important, and 47 per cent said that the allowance was not important.

Even though the scheme did not generally appear to be a strong influence on a decision to return to school, it did appear to be important for some groups of recipients. It was more important for recipients of lower socio-economic background and for students who at the end of Year 10 had not planned to return to school.
I suspect that if the parents of those students had been asked they would have rated the importance of financial assistance even more highly. The report further states:
Other things being equal, the higher the socio-economic level of the school population the higher the retention rate.

I think it is reasonable to expect that increasing assistance to students of lower socio-economic background will have a marked effect on school retention rates. I return to my earlier point about the importance of the elimination, as far as possible, of the disincentives to remaining in education or training. My experience in working in schools has led me to believe that it is not possible or even desirable for all young people to remain in education to the end of the secondary level. There is a need for changes to training schemes in particular, changes which our Government is now addressing, before we reach a retention percentage level in the high 90s. Nor am I in favour of a form of educational compulsion that has been advocated recently by those who envisage raising the school leaving age to 18 years. I emphasise that there must be a real choice for students who have reached the age when they are no longer required by law to be at school.

I now pay tribute to the schools and teachers that have expanded those choices through curriculum change, creative time-tabling, removal of sex discrimination, information and advice-provided particularly by school counsellors and careers teachers-and, perhaps most importantly, personal encouragement. None of these things can solve the problem of the student who, because of the financial resources of his parents, cannot afford to remain at school. Leaving school means at least obtaining unemployment benefit and at best obtaining a job, even if that job turns out to be not permanent or to offer a less satisfying future than the person would have wished. That problem has now been realistically addressed by this legislation. I appeal to schools, teachers, teacher organisations, parent organisations and departmental officials-who have improved their information giving and its timing over recent years-to give maximum publicity to this very positive contribution to education and so maximise the take-up rate of the allowance. The future of our young people and the future prosperity of the nation are dependent to a significant extent on access to quality education and training. I hope that State governments also will take steps to dovetail existing assistance schemes that they have in place with this legislation and that it will encourage those States which do not assist secondary students in this way at all at the moment to look to their needs.

I am proud to have taken part in the prolonged discussions and consultations which have led to this major step forward for young people. Because I have participated in that process, I know it is a well researched initiative and its consequences have been foreseen as far as possible. This Bill rates very highly in the Budget initiatives, and I look forward to its implementation bringing major benefits to young people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1986. The Australian Democrats broadly support this Bill, particularly those parts which seek to streamline the current diverse systems of education and training allowance support which are being provided in Australia. The present arrangements, as other senators have said, have undoubtedly had undesirable effects. I refer particularly to the differences between education allowances and the unemployment benefit. I think there is a growing awareness-this Bill represents part of that awareness-that those anomalies must be overcome. I suppose we would all like them to be overcome immediately, but the reality is that they will be overcome progressively, provided that the shift that is now taking place-that shift occurs partly in this Bill-brings those various items in line with one another.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter is, indeed, part of the general community debate at the moment, particularly with regard to the recent proposals by the Australian Council of Trade Unions for working for the unemployment benefit. I think we are addressing an area that has not been taken seriously in the past. Unfortunately, we have now moved into an area where, essentially, the debate is on the wrong foot. For nearly 10 years the Australian Democrats' policy with regard to youth has been that we believe that there ought to have been instituted at that time-we think it is even more urgent now-an education-work guarantee for young people, similar to that which is used in a number of other countries. After all, if we see our young people as being the emerging citizens of this country, as being those people who will carry this country forward, we have an obligation to them to give them an induction into the society which is not one of unemployment, which is not one of psychological destruction, and which is not one of no future to look forward to, but is one which in any way would give them security and the ability to partake in those things that this society so abundantly has to offer. That is what we have done until now. Seemingly, we have been willing to do it.

The debate which is now taking place in the community about working for the unemployment benefit, I believe, approaches the issue from entirely the wrong direction. We should not be talking about the acceptance of unemployment for young people; rather, we should be talking about the fact that all young people should have a right to receive from this society, as they are being inducted into it, either education or work, or a combination of both. If one wants to raise the issue of cost, which is raised time and time again in this area, why cannot one count the costs on the other side, of the destruction of young people and the waste of talents to this society? Why must we count only the costs that we can grasp in our hand? We do not do that in other areas. What about the vigorous debate in the community concerning mining, and the cost that will be borne by the community if we leave minerals in the ground? Seemingly, it is all right for mining executives to harangue us time and again about those matters, but when one dares to raise the loss to this community of the talents of so many young people, that, seemingly, is not to be counted; it is not to be put on the ledger. The only things that are to be put on the ledger are the actual costs that are borne in dollar terms for education or the unemployment benefit.

That seems to me to be an absurd type of debate. It wipes off as of no account the lives of those young people and what they have to offer us. It seems to me to be an incredible way of debating such a vital issue. Yet that is what is going on in our newspapers and in halls around Australia. It is being fermented and driven up by people who, after all, have a great deal of wealth, who have luxuries, who have all the good things that this community has to offer. To me, it is utterly disgusting that these people who have all of those good things have the audacity to lecture everybody else about young people who have nothing and who have none of those possibilities of looking forward into the future, of being able to enjoy those types of things. Yet they lecture those people about what they owe to the community. Those young people at that stage are owed something by the community. They are still at the stage of being formed. It is a cliche, but true, that they did not ask to be born. As parents and as a community we have a responsibility for those young people. That responsibility does not end when they reach 15 years of age. It ends when they are inducted into the community in such a way that they are given an opportunity of earning a living, contributing to the community and taking their share of the responsibility for this society. That is when it ceases. That is when they are on their own.

Most parents do not cease to support their children just because they have reached the age of 18 or 21, or even because they have married. Most parents in Australia would still believe that they have a responsibility, that they are there to assist their children to the extent that they are able. So I do not think that our community in general should believe that just because a child reaches the age of 15 and, in most States, has reached the end of his compulsory schooling, somehow or other, miraculously, the community can now wash its hands, and that person can become unemployed, destroyed psychologically, and have no future to look forward to with equanimity; yet somehow, that is nothing to do with us. We are looking at the whole debate in the wrong way. The debate should be about what we owe to the community, not what those young people should or should not be doing in terms of the unemployment benefit. We have an obligation to them; we should fulfil our obligation; we have not been fulfilling our obligation.

I hope we would see it as a natural course that every young person growing up in Australia would have educational opportunities, developmental opportunities, or work of a productive kind. If that were so, we would not need to have this rancorous and divisive debate about working for the unemployment benefit. I think that the more we concentrate on that angle, the less we will concentrate on the productive and effective side. We know, by studying other countries' mistakes-although we do not tend to learn terribly well from other countries' mistakes-that when one has endemic unemployment amongst people, it destroys their capacity for future employment. When those young people who have been out of work-the Northern Ireland experience certainly bears this out greatly-reach the stage of ever getting a job, they cannot keep it; not because they do not want to work, but because they have been destroyed inside.

When we look at reforms in this area we should bear in mind where we want to go. We should hope that every one of these measures is a step towards that goal.
