I think this Bill ought to be judged in terms of how well it makes the step towards where we want to go. In itself it is a small step. But if it is not a step forward, we should not even take that step. As I say, I think it is a step forward in that it acknowledges that we need to bring together, at least in monetary terms, the benefits that are available-be they unemployment or education benefits. That is the first step and we have a long way to go, of course. This legislation deals only with the lower end of the spectrum and, even in the last Budget allowances in other areas were still getting further apart. This legislation is certainly only a small step forward but in as much as it is, it has our support.

I also make the point that income support schemes of themselves do not necessarily make young people more eager to undertake non-compulsory education and training. For some reason that has not got home yet there is a difference between participation in education and training and mere retention. It is true that the Government's policies have increased retention. I would argue that they have not increased participation by anywhere near the same extent. I have no firm evidence for saying that because it is an item about which it is very difficult to get firm evidence. My evidence is only anecdotal in terms of talking to teachers, people in technical and further education and people at the work face, as it were, and who deal with young people. Time and again I keep hearing back from them that lots of people in our schools and educational institutions do not want to be there. They are making life hell for other people who are there and are making it very difficult for the teachers-the educators-to provide educational opportunities for those people who wish to partake of them.

There is still a very large number of people in our schooling system who are merely being retained there; they are not participating. I am not criticising the Government for that. Ultimately, it is not something over which the Government can have much control. It can only make sure that its general social policies are consonant with its education policies because if its social policies are out of kilter with its education policies they will counteract them and work against them. In education many problems end up in the popular media as educational problems and they are nothing of the sort; they are social problems. They are problems which are still in our society. For example, malnutrition stops a lot of kids in early grades in primary school from being able to learn. That is not an educational problem and there is very little that most educational institutions are able to do about it although they are trying. Basically that is a social problem and the extent that problems exist comes down to the level of poverty in our society.

The amount of assistance that is provided in this legislation is still inadequate to meet the declared purposes of overcoming financial disadvantage which forces children to seek unemployment benefits or to work when they have the talent for further education. I do not believe, although it is a start, that this legislation will do terribly much in that area. The major costs of retaining anybody within the education system are never those that the education system generates; they are simply the living costs, the major costs that have to be borne. The costs of housing, accommodation, transport and clothing are all far and away higher costs than any costs directly related to education such as costs for books, specific instruments and the like. If a family finds itself unable to support the child, pressure will not be on the child to stay at school, as much as the parents may like that, but rather for that child to seek some type of work so that he or she can bring some income into the family that is in difficulties.

The Bill has a number of problems and I do not intend at this point to go through those I see in some of its clauses except to sketch in briefly the problem, as I see it, with regard to the way the Government has chosen to treat 16-year-olds and not adopt the non-compulsory schooling approach. The difficulty is borne out by the Bureau of Statistics figures with regard to 15-year-olds in years 11 and 12. If I can just run down the figures I think honourable senators will be able to see very clearly where the problem arose. However, I would not think that the Senate could take this type of approach easily. Let me give some figures for July which apply to Year 11 students. About 2.5 per cent of kids in Year 11 in Victoria were 15 years old on 1 July; in the Australian Capital Territory the figure is about three per cent; in New South Wales it is about 4 per cent; in Tasmania it is 9 per cent; in the Northern Territory it is 36 per cent; in Queensland it is 43 per cent; and in South Australia it is 54 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Western Australia?

—I thought I gave the figure for Western Australia. The figure for Western Australia is 43 per cent. This Bill seems to have been drawn up by people who live in the Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales or Victoria. However, the situation in other States in our federation is somewhat different. I admit that the education Ministers have agreed that children going to school as of last year will be aged 5 years, so this problem will solve itself in time, but that will be some time down the track. At the moment we have a lot of 15-year-olds in year 11. The Government has chosen to start paying the increased allowance to students aged 16 years to bring it into line with the unemployment benefit. As I have said, I think that is reasonable but the only thing we have to bring into line is the amounts. For some reason the Government has chosen to bring not only the amounts into line but also everything else. Since the unemployment benefit is paid to persons aged 16 the Government wants this allowance to be paid to people aged 16. The educational rationale for that does not mesh in any sense because the educational rationale is to make sure that students go from the compulsory year to the non-compulsory year. If we tell them that they will not get paid anything until they are 16-there are still quite a lot of 15-year-olds in year 12; I am not quite sure how they manage it--
—Some 2 or 3 per cent.

—In Australia the total number is quite small but some still manage to get there. For example, 136, 15-year-olds are still in the middle of year 12. They must be pretty precocious individuals but they have made it there. Overall 11,618 15-year-olds are in year 11. I would like the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), when replying to the second reading debate, to give the projections of the percentage of kids who are likely to get these allowances. They are means tested; so not everybody will get them. We are looking at the percentage.
—About a third.

—I would have thought something similar to the tertiary education assistance scheme would be appropriate because we are operating on roughly the same figures. So we would be looking at 22, 23, or 24 per cent. If it is a third, that would be a higher percentage. I can see that there are some reasons why it might be higher. I would be very interested if the Minister would give us those figures. But even so, 2,000 or 3,000 kids will not be getting any benefits in that first year, and that does not seem to me to be the type of arrangement that is required.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of ways out of this problem. One is to combine the age and the non-compulsory schooling elements, because, oddly enough, the Government will be paying quite a number of people in grade 10 who attend school on a compulsory basis. Again, in this respect, there is a difference across Australia. Students in Western Australia have to complete the year they are in, although they may turn 15 during the year. In every other State and Territory a student can leave once he turns 15. However, the Government proposes to pay some people in grade 10 and not to pay people who are in grade 11. I would have thought that in terms of what we are attempting to do-that is, to encourage the transition to grades 11 and 12; not simply pay students to stay in grade 10, but to get them to go beyond the compulsory school years-we should make sure that anyone who goes into grades 11 and 12 and who falls within the framework in terms of means testing is assisted. In terms of the financial implications, possibly a very small number of students will be involved. Roughly 19 per cent of students fall into that category on an Australia-wide basis. On the other hand, about 15 per cent or so of 16-year-olds are in grade 10.

In terms of the Government's rationale, I should have thought it made much more sense to pick up the 15-year-olds in grade 11 than the 16-year-olds in grade 10. I am quite happy to pay the 16-year-olds in grade 10 if the Government can find the money; but I think that in terms of any rationale, we would have to opt first of all for the 15-years-olds in grade 11 to get continuity of educational operations. We certainly should make sure that those people in the lower socio-economic structures are not, by the dint of not having the resources, forced out of school to seek a job on the employment market.

The other matter which is the subject of the Opposition amendment is the way in which benefits are to be paid. Again, I would suggest that that proposal falls down exactly on the point I have raised. The Government, in seeking to bring the student benefits and the unemployment benefit together, has chosen to cover all topics. Quite frankly, the Opposition's amendment does not seem to me to be based on a great matter of principle. But it does raise an important point inasmuch as if one only brings together the amounts involved, it seems to me perfectly reasonable that this allowance should continue in terms of a schooling situation to be paid to parents or guardians. After all, in the vast majority of cases people at school are living at home. Of course, if they are not living at home they fall under the independent living allowance. If they are living at home-as are the vast bulk of school students-their parents pay for their accommodation, provide their food and clothes and so on.

I would suggest that there is a difference between secondary schooling and tertiary education, even for children of the same age. There is a psychological difference. There is a difference in the way in which our society considers the matter. I do not see any reason for moving away from the present position of paying these allowances to parents or guardians, as is suggested in the Opposition's amendment. When we come to the tertiary sector-be that TAFE, in which case many of the students would be of the same age as the school students, or the colleges of advanced education or universities where the students, of course, would be of a higher age-the allowance would be paid directly to the students.

I think the community has a general understanding of the difference between these students. At least one of the differences between secondary education and tertiary education is that those in tertiary education are treated in a much more independent vein. In fact, the whole educational system operates quite differently in a secondary school for a person of an identical age from the way in which TAFE operates. TAFE operates on the basis that a student coming into the system works independently. The obligation is placed on students to do the study. There is a lot of input from teachers in secondary schools in coaxing, urging and getting people to engage in work. So even the whole education system approaches students in a different fashion. It seems to me that society does also and, therefore, it would be appropriate that the Opposition's amendment should be supported on that basis. I think the rationale behind the Opposition's amendment flows from exactly the same thinking behind my amendment, and that is that there is no need to put education allowances and the unemployment benefit together except in money terms, because it is the amount of money that is causing the disincentives.

I hope that at the Committee stage we shall be able to find out from the Government whether it has any other reasons for approaching the matter in this fashion. My amendment essentially disregards age. I think there is a mid-way between the position outlined in my amendment and the Government's position-that is, we could have both age and a non-compulsory schooling or non-compulsory course requirement. In other words, students of that age who are undertaking compulsory or non-compulsory schooling would be eligible for the allowance. That would pick up the 15-year-olds who are in grade 11. That would seem to me to be a reasonable compromise if the Government feels that in terms of the costs involved, which are absolutely minuscule in terms of the whole education budget, it cannot pick up the total amount.

In recent years we have seen some significant changes in our whole economy impact on the education system, particularly the schooling system, in an extremely detrimental way. One need only talk to teachers to know that the problems that pupils are having relate to their perceptions of what is going on and what there futures are. This is greatly affecting their educational achievements. It seems to me that while messing around and making sure that the unemployment benefit and student allowances are considered together is a step forward, I do not think that this measure will appreciably alter the perception held by students-`Why work hard now if all that is going to happen after all of this hard work is that I will be unemployed?' That is the sort of thing that filters down.

This is one of the major disincentives that have operated in the Aboriginal area. Apart from the other factors that operate in our society in regard to the employment of Aboriginals, we know that this sort of thinking has prevented many Aboriginal students from completing their studies. Not only Aboriginal students suffer from this disadvantage. Right across the board kids opt out. While they may be physically in a school, they are opting out, because they say: `No matter how hard I work, the quotas are on at the universities, and there are no jobs, so why bother?' They throw up their hands and give up before they reach their goals. So the psychological problem outside the schools has a far greater effect than the matters we are dealing with here. While we are putting some emphasis on these measures, I would not like people to think that I believe that in any way they will be responsible for a massive change in the psychology of how students approach their task. Their task is a very hard one in our society. Secondary school students are asked to work hours that would make any union official blush. They work the type of hours that we work in this place. They have to work in school. When they go home they have very little time to themselves if they are studying hard, and they have to work late into the night, sometimes for five days a week. Sometimes they also have to work at the weekends just to keep level. It is very important to realise that when we are looking at the induction of young people into our society through the education system, we have to give them hope. Therefore, the strength of the economy is a vital ingredient-probably more so than the amounts we are playing about with here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Student Assistance Act has operated for 13 years. This year, allowances payable under the Act will exceed $500m. The amending Bill which is before the Senate-the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1986-seeks to extend the allowances payable under the Act to include secondary students. Until this time, the Act has provided for post-graduate awards and for tertiary allowances payable to students in universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions. The Bill is only three pages long, and it establishes the principle of the extension to secondary students. Much of the debate so far-and to some extent I will be involved in this-is about the foreshadowed regulations that will bring in the provisions for Austudy that were announced at the time of the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition welcomes the extension of the Student Assistance Act to secondary students and welcomes the principle that seeks to remove the disincentives from study, whether at the tertiary or secondary level, that have arisen in recent years because of the higher rate of payment to those receiving unemployment benefit compared with those receiving student allowances. The Opposition recognises the findings of the Beswick Report on Studies of Tertiary Student Finances, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development review of youth policy in Australia and various papers from the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat, along with the work which has been done in various States and which has been put to our parties towards the concept of the youth allowances, towards the more sensible integration of education allowances, the family allowance, the unemployment benefit and training allowances; indeed any benefit that comes from the taxpayer in respect of young Australians after they have left school, including even at the interface when they are in the last couple of years of school.

We welcome the principle of removing disincentives for those students who would be inclined to apply for the unemployment benefit because there is a greater financial benefit for them by doing so. But we are not happy about several matters. Senator Peter Baume has referred to them and Senator Macklin has spoken along very similar lines. There is general agreement, as I see it, on the concepts that we are putting forward in urging the Government to accept our amendments, particularly the one in relation to the operation of secondary allowances under the Austudy scheme.

We see the goal of Austudy, as it relates to secondary students, as widening the participation of students in years 11 and 12. Our policies in opposition, as well as during the period of the Fraser Government, have sought to help the achievement of greater retention at the year 11 and year 12 level and every year that retention has increased. There has been a higher percentage every year for the last 12 years in the proportion of students who are in year 11 and year 12. We have noted that the introduction of secondary allowances has been a substantial help for parents who are paying for the education of their children or paying the costs of their accommodation while one or more of them undertakes year 11 and year 12 studies.
I make one other general reference, and that is that there ought to be a wider range of school curricula, of school structures and of training possibilities for year 11 and year 12 students.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did the Government abandon PEP, then?

—It is a great pity that the participation and equity program has been abandoned by the Government. I think it was ill-conceived in its abandonment but it was also not properly thought through in the way it was implemented, but it was certainly aimed at this important transition area. The whole idea of transition education remains an important one and it should not be seen as temporary. The interface between secondary and tertiary education should be seen as permanent. Six years ago the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts conducted a national inquiry into the relationship between unemployment and education. One of the matters that have strangled the innovation that ought to have been more developed in Australia is the concept that the comprehensive school is some kind of unassail- able god, that all schools must be comprehensive. I believe a range of options at year 11 and year 12 ought to be available to students, and certainly one of the options must be a comprehensive school. I do not wish to encourage 14- and 15-year-old students to cut off their options; they should keep them as open as they can. But many do not want an academic finish to their secondary schooling. One model is the Port Macquarie vocational school which was developed five or six years ago and which has a marvellous record. A former primary school, conducted by the Catholic church, became redundant because the population of Port Macquarie grew so much that a new primary school was built. The century old building was then refurbished and organised as a year 10 and year 11 vocational school with a different lifestyle and organisation of the way in which students conducted themselves in the school and, of course, a different curriculum for the school. It was very much geared to the employment opportunities that were in the district of Port Macquarie. There are similar schools in other cities. For instance, there are technical schools in Melbourne that have survived the comprehensive onslaught when all the other schools, many of which had real qualities, were submerged within a comprehensive structure. Thankfully one or two survived and one in Melbourne continues to serve very well those who take its courses.

SPEECH.PARA: In this achievement of higher retention rates at year 11 and year 12, I believe there ought to be encouragement from the Commonwealth towards more innovation, to a wider range of options that are mostly in the hands of the State governments, and for the way in which Year 11 and year 12 classes are structured. The Commonwealth training schemes are appropriately structured to take 16-, 17- and 18-year-olds and their training is geared directly towards employment. This range of options in the transition from secondary to tertiary education, I believe, can still be greatly extended. It is not only through the education allowances that we see under Austudy that we will gain that better outcome but also through innovation and extension of the working models that ought to be there beside the comprehensive schools.

I come to two or three matters that the Opposition is unhappy about in this legislation. The first concerns the shift from the status quo of giving secondary allowances on the basis of enrolment in the year of study, namely year 11 and year 12, to giving the allowance only on the basis of age, that is, to students aged 16 and 17 years. We believe that that is not the best way to go; it is over-simplified. We are still searching for a way in which we can achieve an outcome that involves both categories, year 11 and year 12 and students aged 16 and 17 years, in a coherent way but which does not, by our amendment, lead to further expenditure by the Government. The Opposition wishes to be seen-and we are-as responsible by not adding to the elected Government's Budget expenditure announced in the first week of our sittings. We saw that to add all 16-year-olds to those who are otherwise provided for in this Bill, the additional expenditure would apparently be some $35m. We do not believe that amending this Bill to include them is a responsible way for us to go.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break we were debating the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1986. The Opposition supports the principle of removing disincentives for young people who opt for employment rather than continuing with education or training. We have sought to put in place policies that would increase participation by Australia's young people in education and training, and in particular see an increase in retention at years 11 and 12 in our schools. I urge that we look not only to financial incentives to gain that greater participation and retention, but also to a wider range of school structures, training options, and curriculum contexts that will genuinely meet the needs of 16- 17- and 18-year-old young Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is not happy with several features of the Bill and with the foreshadowed regulations that will put in place Austudy, as it has been defined by the Government. I had just begun to refer to one feature before the dinner break, and that is the shift in the Government's policy for secondary educational allowances being determined on the basis of age rather than on the basis of a mixture of age and year of study. Until this time, secondary allowances have been paid to eligible students, on a means test basis, who are enrolled in years 11 and 12. As the Government proposes to give these allowances to all 16- and 17-year-old secondary students it will pick up a considerable number of year 11 and 12 students, but it will omit a large number of 15-year-olds undertaking year 11 study. It is the view of the Opposition, and of the Australian Democrats, as expressed by Senator Macklin in his speech on this measure, that the purpose for which these allowances have been put in place, is to provide the means for young Australians to continue to years 11 and 12, but this will in fact not be available for 15-year-olds in year 11. So the incentive for them will fail. In fact, it is a regressive measure because many cohorts of the 15-year-olds who are now going into years 11 and 12 will no longer receive the allowance that they have been receiving until this point. I also understand-the Minister can correct me if I am wrong-that any student who is now 15, or who will be 15 next year, and who is in receipt of a secondary allowance, will not have that allowance denied him. I am concerned about the cohorts of 15-year-olds who next year would have received an allowance had the present provisions continued.

The Opposition's reluctance to find an amendment to achieve our view of an appropriate mixture of year of enrolment and age in determining eligibility for secondary allowance is because we wish to be responsible in relation to the elected Government's Budget and we do not want to see any additional expenditure arise from an amendment we might move. The Opposition and the Democrats are concerned about this matter and at the Committee stage we will be asking specific questions of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) in order to see the dimensions of the problem. We hope that there may be some resolution by amendment even in the course of this debate. However, if there is not, and if there is not the time to think that through, certainly by the time we see the regulations under the Act, we will be applying the principles we have alluded to in this second reading debate at the Committee stage.

The Student Assistance Act has operated for 13 years. From the beginning the regulations have been voluminous and the Act rather slim because the operation of these allowances is as defined, very precisely, in the regulations.

I refer to an example in South Australia, the State I represent. I have a letter from the headmaster of St Michael's College who refers to the bad effect that this measure will have upon the students he has enrolled at Henley Beach. Mr Acting Deputy President, you are familiar with this college. Brother Paul Rogers, the headmaster, has written to set out the facts. These measures will clearly lead to many students, who are now receiving the secondary allowance in year 11 as 15-year-olds, losing the allowance. Of the cohorts who will go to year 11 next year there will be many who will not be receiving the secondary allowance. The letter states:
St Michael's College had 141 year 11 students at the commencement of this school year. Of that group 120 were 15 on 1st February (i.e. 85 per cent).
None of the 85 per cent would be eligible at that point for the secondary allowance under this new proposal. The letter continues:
. . . 87 were still only 15 on 1st July (62 per cent). I believe that these statistics are characteristic of South Australia.

I will not bore the Senate by referring to the many other letters I have from South Australians which set out very similar statistics to this. Senator Macklin in his speech this afternoon set out the proportion in the various States. In Victoria of all year 11 students only 2.5 per cent are still 15 years old; 3 per cent in the Australian Capital Territory; 4 per cent in New South Wales; and 9 per cent in Tasmania. In the Northern Territory the corresponding figure is 36 per cent; in Queensland and Western Australia it is 43 per cent; and in my State it is 45 per cent. That is the overall situation of which the Saint Michael's College case is an example. The headmaster then looks at those year 11 students who receive the secondary allowance and states:
Further, 25 students at the College receive the Secondary Allowance in Year 11. Under your proposal-
it is a letter addressed to the Minister-

22 (i.e. 88 per cent) would not be eligible on 1st February 1986, 18 (i.e. 72 per cent) would still be ineligible on 1st July, and 3 students would still be 15 when they commence Year 12 studies in 1987.

That is nearly three-quarters of the students who are in the cohort of year 11 students receiving the secondary allowance would be ineligible even in the middle of the year. This is a problem. I am speaking purely on the basis that resources that have been given to that cohort in the past, will be denied to South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. I am concerned about the disincentive effect on year 11, 15-year-olds to continue with their studies. If the financial assistance is of material benefit it must be of material benefit to these 15-year-olds. We in the Opposition-I know I speak for the Democrats in this matter-are concerned about the problem. A simple solution would be to add all year 11 enrolments to the provision for 16-year-olds, but the trouble is that that would cost $35m. Therefore, I have the problem that we cannot add to an expenditure item in the Government's Budget.

In considering the various reports that have led to the principle that we should take away the disincentive of the unemployment benefit being of more monetary value than the encouragement to stay on at school and gain the benefits of that education, a principle with which we agree, we have a dilemma that the first option of continuing with only year 11 and 12 students involves the problem that many 16-year-olds in year 10 would have the disincentive that the unemployment benefit which would be available to them would be greater than the benefit that would be denied them in year 10 and that they would receive only in year 11. Option 2, of giving the secondary allowance to everyone now receiving it but also to all 16-year-olds, would invoke an additional cost of $70m. It appears that the Government has said: `That is too much money. We cannot afford $70m. We will settle for $35m extra by giving the allowance only to 16-year-olds'.

In considering the options, I agree that there has to be some sensible borderline but I do not believe that the proposed borderline is sensible. There will still be disincentives for those 15-year-olds. We should look at the whole matter again and come up with an expenditure neutral alternative that nevertheless directly meets the situation that the Headmaster of St Michael's College, along with many others in South Australia, Northern Territory and Western Australia, are pointing to. The problem ought not to exclude the possibility that all 18-year-olds who are involved in full time education could be directly eligible for Austudy given all the other criteria for its award. That would pick up all adult enrolments in secondary school courses purely on an age basis. I am saying that we do not want to stay entirely with the status quo of the secondary allowance going only to those students enrolled in years 11 and 12. Particularly for those who are aged 18 and above it is right that they have the higher rate of allowance that is set out in the Austudy tables.

Before I move on to a second area of concern I need to refer to the disincentive in comparison with the unemployment benefit and the secondary allowance. About 45,000 16- and 17-year-olds receive unemployment benefit. When the present Government was first elected it was very concerned that the rate of unemployment benefit for 16- and 17-year-olds was only $40. Over the last three years this sum has been increased. The Government has increased the unemployment benefit for 16- and 17-year-olds to $50. In November 1983 it was increased to $45, in November 1984 to two levels, $45 and $50-the $50 a week being available to those who had been unemployed for more than six months-and in November last year the sum for all 15- and 16-year-olds receiving unemployment benefit was $50. This year there has been no change. Next year it is projected that this amount will be indexed. Perhaps it will be $53.50.

Part of the problem is that in trying to solve the problem of disincentives caused by the comparison of the unemployment benefit with the education allowance the Government has moved too quickly to increase that allowance. If there had not been such a rapid increase there would be less of a problem and we would not have, for example, the bottom line of the $35m to which I referred earlier. We could have had the same rates of allowance at a lower level and allowed both the education allowance and the unemployment benefit to rise together. The other aspect is that in overcoming this disincentive for the 40,000 Australians who are 16- and 17-years-old and receiving unemployment benefit we still overlook too much that we should make the unemployment option the last possible option for those young Australians. Clearly, the best three options are enrolment in education, work and training.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should make a choice.

—They should choose freely among those three options, but the system should be so well structured in providing education, work and training that no one should be left to languish in the fourth option of unemployment. We talk about working for the dole or the proposal by the Australian Council of Trade Unions that nobody aged 16 or 17 should receive unemployment benefit; they should receive only a training allowance, and unemployment benefit for those under 18 should be banned. I certainly agree with the principle that we should do everything possible to structure a free choice for anyone under 18 among the options of education, work and training.

SPEECH.PARA: I move very quickly to the second item which we will explore in the Committee stage. We will seek an amendment that the payment for secondary students be paid to parents who are responsible for providing education for their dependent children rather than its being paid directly to the students. We do not wish to see the Government intervening between a parent and a dependent student child. If a student is enrolled in tertiary education it is correct for the allowance to be paid directly to the student but the Opposition believes that it is appropriate to take the dividing line at age 18 or enrolment in tertiary education. The Minister in reply may refer to some tax disincentives but we wish to endorse the principle that family relationships ought to be protected and not weakened.

Finally, I refer to the incidentals allowance. In the half-minute available to me I note that there will be time when we discuss clause 11 of the Bill to point out that the incidentals allowance is being abolished by this Bill. To that extent there is a short-changing of students on allowances who have been promised that the Austudy allowance will rise to the level of the unemployment benefit with the assumption that the incidentals allowance would be paid on top of that. But the Government has chosen to abolish the incidentals allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their contributions. I will comment on two major concerns that have been raised during the debate. The first concerns the payment of the allowance to 16-year-olds rather than to 15-year-olds in year 11 as was the case under the previous secondary allowances scheme. There seems to be some confusion on the part of Opposition senators who have argued that this move to an age-related allowance will cause a disincentive for young people who wish to remain in the education system. I would like to make very clear that this is not the case because unemployment benefit, which is the competing payment for the age cohort, is not payable to 15-year-olds. So the 15-year-old who goes into year 11 and has to wait until he or she turns 16 to get Austudy will not accrue any benefit by dropping out and entering the labour market because that student will not get unemployment benefit.
—They may get employment.

—The opportunities for untrained 15-year-old school dropouts to get employment are very few. Where that opportunity arises, the award paid to a 15-year-old would still be greater than the 16-year-old Austudy benefit anyway, so it is an irrelevant point. What we are trying to do-I acknowledge that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have recognised this-is to bring all the opportunities for young persons at certain ages into alignment so that there is no financial incentive for them to opt for one or the other.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that we should continue to pay the new allowance to 15-year-olds who have gone into year 11 overlooks the fact that if those 15-year-olds opt to go out into the labour market they are not eligible for unemployment benefit. So there is no competition between Austudy and unemployment benefit for the student who has not turned 16. Neither is payable. I make that very clear to the Opposition because some of the comments made suggested that there was some assumption that 15-year-olds could get unemployment benefit. They cannot.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who made that suggestion?

—It was suggested during the remarks I heard when I came into the chamber. So there is no competition as far as 15-year-olds are concerned. They are eligible neither for Austudy nor for the unemployment benefit. The point was made-it is one that the Government acknowledges-that 15-year-olds in year 11 will be in different and poorer circumstances than will 16-year-olds in year 11. I certainly acknowledge that point. However, I remind honourable senators that the 15-year-old in that circumstance still attracts for his or her parent a number of benefits which disappear when that student turns 16. First, he or she is eligible for family allowance, which averages about $6.40 a week. Secondly-we are talking about low income students, the same group which will be eligible for Austudy-the students' parents are eligible for an additional $17 a week if they are pensioner beneficiaries or for the family income supplement if they are in the work force. So the same 15-year-old student who has gone into year 11 will attract for his or her parent in the vicinity of $24 a week which is not as much as the new Austudy benefit. But certainly the Commonwealth is not leaving unassisted that group of young persons.
—But they get that with or without the educational benefit.

—They would get it with or without the education allowance but they would not get it if they dropped out and went on to the labour market. They would get it only if they were dependent. So there is Commonwealth assistance for the 15-year-old who goes into year 11 which would amount to about $24 a week. It is not as much as Austudy, but there is still $24 which phases out, or disappears.
—That is the maximum.

—We are talking in maximum terms. The family allowance is the same. Austudy is also means tested and will be on a sliding scale. So not every student getting Austudy will get the maximum benefit. I am not arguing that the 15-year-old in year 11 is in the same circumstances as a 16-year-old in year 11 under our scheme--
—He is in a worse situation than the 16-year-old in year 10.

—That is true, because the 16-year-old in year 10 could opt out of education and get the unemployment benefit. The whole thrust of the new package is to ensure that there is no incentive to go into unemployment benefit. Whatever reservations honourable senators may have about the scheme they must accept that we have removed the incentive for young persons to go on to unemployment benefit. I have acknowledged that there is some difference between the 15-year-old and the 16-year-old in year 11. To overcome that would be a major problem. It would cost $35m in a year to overcome it. Not only that, there is the question of time constraints. If this legislation is held up by the insistence of Opposition senators on their amendment we will have to return it to the House of Representatives and so on and so forth. The ultimate effect will be that the new system of payment will be delayed at least until March. That is not a result which any honourable senator would like to see.

SPEECH.PARA: We are concerned to know what the effect of moving to an age-related allowance would be. I give honourable senators my assurance that we will be very closely monitoring what happens to 15-year-olds who go into year 11 and have to wait for some time before they are eligible for Austudy. If there are problems of the extent which Senator Macklin or Senator Teague have suggested, certainly we will attempt to take them up in next year's budgetary allocations. Overall, as a result of the scheme, all 16-year-olds and above will receive significantly increased benefits. In terms of total numbers, many more students in Western Australia, South Australia and Queensland will come into the scheme by virtue of its being age-related than would have been in the scheme if we had not moved to the age-related basis. So there are overall benefits for individual students and for students as a group. The 15-year-old in year 11 will certainly get less benefit than the 16-year-old in year 11, but that will change during the year.

I should also point out that in many States there is State assistance for students under the age of 15, such as bursaries, book allowances and things of that kind. I am currently negotiating with States to try to point out to them the benefits to students of rationalising their State assistance in a way that complements the age-related scheme. If there is a scheme under which there is a payment to all students from, say, 15 years and upwards, perhaps a State could consider concentrating that benefit on 15-year-olds so that poorer students would get a benefit from the State when they were 15 and, when they turned 16, pass on to the Commonwealth benefit. That would be the most rational arrangement. I am having discussions with the States to that effect. I remind honourable senators that we are talking about considerable increases targeted at the most vulnerable group, that is, 16-year-old school students who have the option of opting out and going on to the dole. I think we would all agree that that group of students is our major concern and that we have dealt with that disincentive to continue in school or technical and further education as a result of this scheme.

Another concern, which I understand very well, has been expressed during the debate, and that is that under the Austudy scheme the benefit will be paid directly to the student and not to the parent. Under the old secondary allowances scheme the benefit was paid to the parent. When the Government first contemplated moving to an age-related scheme we considered continuing to pay the benefit to the parent because there are arguments in favour of doing so. I accept that. There still are. But when we looked closely at the taxation effects of that benefit on the amount of the benefit and what the family as a whole would gain we realised that it was too much of an imposition to place on, for example, the supporting mother living on the pension. Under our arrangement that mother will not suffer any diminution of benefit, even though her son or daughter may receive $40 a week in allowance. If the benefit is payable to the parent, the supporting mother would lose considerably because that amount is taxable. We considered that the overall benefit to the family would be greater if we allowed the full amount to go to the mother-or to the father as it may be, but it is usually the mother-and the full amount to go to the student child. We were trying to maximise the government payment to that family. Our scheme certainly does that.

Of course, questions arise as to whether 16, 17 or 18-year-olds will use that money responsibly and whether there will be an appropriate relationship between parent and child so that the income is of proper benefit to the family. We did look very closely at that, but we believe that there is really almost an overwhelming case that that is the most rational way to do things. We have done that in many other schemes and have had no complaint as a result. For example, for many years it has been the case, and it still is the case, that the 16-year-old who undertakes a TAFE course and who receives a training allowance or receives a payment under the tertiary education assistance scheme, gets that payment himself or herself. That has been the case for a long time and we are not aware of any particular family difficulties that have arisen as a result of that.

It is also the case that if the 16-year-old drops out of education or training and goes on to the dole, that dole payment is also made to the young person. We have already had in place for a number of years direct payments by the Commonwealth to 16-year-olds, even when they are living in a family arrangement, and there does not seem to be any overwhelming evidence that that has been a negative arrangement for the family.

There are those, too, who would argue from a philosophical standpoint that a 16-year-old ought to be learning responsibility about his or her support, responsibilities to the family and so forth. That is a philosophy that has some attraction to me. But leaving aside the philosophical argument, first of all I remind honourable senators that the poorer parent, particularly a pensioner, would lose considerably if he or she received the benefit. Secondly, we really do not have any overwhelming body of evidence from TEAS payments to TAFE students or from unemployment benefit payments to 16-year-olds on the dole that suggests that this is a course we should not follow.

I thank honourable senators for their overall support of the scheme. Obviously, there is a very widespread understanding that what we are attempting to do with the scheme is the right course of action-namely, to assist students from poorer families to remain students and to remove any financial disincentive for them to go on to unemployment benefit. I think there is agreement about that. There is concern about the two matters I have raised. The Government will not accept the amendments proposed, for the reasons I have just set out, and I hope that honourable senators will bear in mind that we are now starting upon a major social reform and that any disruption of the legislation at this stage will really have a very unsatisfactory outcome for the recipients. I commend the Bill to the Senate and at this stage I also table an explanatory memorandum relating to the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1986.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first item I wish to raise is with regard to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in respect of clauses 4 (a), (c) and (e). With regard to the Student Assistance Act, I wonder whether the Minister might explain the type of undertaking or proposition she made to me on 9 October-in answer to a question in which I used the Bond university as an example-when she said that the Government's view was that it would not provide any funding for such institutions, including funding for students attending them. How does the Government propose that such an institution will be excluded when the definitions in this Bill are so broad? After all, that is the substance of what the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills is talking about. I quote from the Committee's report:

SPEECH.PARA: The term `educational institution' is defined to include any educational institution or any other educational institution, authority or body in Australia that, under the regulations, is to be treated as such.

What intrigues me is that if, for example, the proposed Bond university were established, I would imagine that it would probably be established under a Queensland law on a par with Queensland University, Griffith University or James Cook University. I presume that the Queensland Government would establish it under some type of statute. I would have thought that in any normal meaning of the term, the courts would find that this was a university. How is the Minister going to distinguish Commonwealth policy on that particular item?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Government has in mind any particular institutions that will be precluded from the definition of `university' or `any other educational institution'. Is it correct that the existing definition in the Student Assistance Act or the new definitions are a necessary but not sufficient description of an institution at which a student might be enrolled and in which there is eligibility for the allowance-that is, that the regulations, in any event, preclude certain universities, theological colleges or certain educational institutions? Whilst I am also concerned about the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills with regard to paragraphs 4 (a), (c) and (e), I understand that the regulations provide the power to exclude certain of these institutions anyway. But I ask the specific question first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both honourable senators have asked questions about the definition of `university' from the point of view of Commonwealth payment of allowances. The amendment of the definition of `university' will permit that term to be confined to those institutions specified as universities in the regulations. Of course, that will be a Commonwealth Act and will not have regard to any unilateral decisions the States may have made. In turn, the regulations will limit the definition to those universities listed in the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission Act. This will mean that assistance under Austudy will not be provided to students at universities that are not Commonwealth funded. We will have two tiers. We will have the regulations and we will have the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission list of universities.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague asked who will be excluded. Obviously, that will be a matter for Commonwealth decision, and our Government has already announced that it will not support private universities such as that proposed by Mr Bond. Senator Teague asked whether our exclusion would be merely necessary and not sufficient. It will be both, because in this respect we are talking about Commonwealth allowances paid to Commonwealth approved courses. The Commonwealth, on the advice of CTEC, will make those decisions. An institution may be called a university under State legislation but if it is not on the CTEC approved list, its courses cannot come up for approval for payment under Austudy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 3, clause 5, after proposed new section 10, insert the following section:
``Age of students to be disregarded

``10A. Where a person is undertaking, or proposes to undertake, a course of study or instruction, or a part of a course of study or instruction, that is a secondary course or a tertiary course, or part of a secondary course or of a tertiary course, for the purposes of section 10, the age of the person shall not be taken into account in determining whether the person is eligible for benefit under Education Assistance.''.

This amendment raises the issue of the age situation across Australia. I listened carefully to the points that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) raised and I understand the thrust the Government has in regard to this item. As I said during the second reading debate, I feel that the Government-it is a laudable objective-in bringing together the unemployment benefits and the education benefits, which is something I have been urging for a long time, has actually also brought together all of the other items. It seems to me that the only item that does need to be the same is the amount of money. The Government has chosen two other major items: One is the eligibility age and the other is the form of payment. They have both been canvassed already in this debate.

The difficulty I have with the explanation of the Minister is that the intent that the Government gave for this measure is directly to assist those people who are financially disadvantaged to continue their studies. If that is the educational objective and there is no overwhelming necessity to have everything exactly the same as with the unemployment benefit, under this proposal people who live in the Australian Capital Territory or in New South Wales or Victoria will probably, by and large, be better off. The difficulty is, as I stated, that the percentage of students in year 11 who are 15-year-olds in the middle of the year is 9 per cent in Tasmania, 36 per cent in the Northern Territory, 43 per cent in Queensland and Western Australia and 54 per cent in South Australia. According to the Australian Statistician, on 1 July 54 per cent of students in year 11 in South Australia are 15-year-olds. Senator Teague made the same point. I must say in response to what he said that on a number of occasions I have heard him say that this is a States House and presumably as a senator from South Australia he will not vote on party lines but vote in the best interests of his State. I will watch that in the later stages of the debate. This is a pertinent matter for this chamber because the different laws and regulations which have applied in the past have resulted in this disparity among the States and Territories. This has actively disadvantaged the Northern Territory, Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —It discriminates against the residents.

—That is right. Overall, the figure is about 20 per cent. At 1 July 20 per cent of students in year 11 are 15 years of age. As I said in my speech at the second reading stage, some students even in year 12 are 15-year-olds. They are precocious individuals; nevertheless, there they are. It seems to me that if the intent of the measure is an educational one-that is, to get children from the compulsory school years to the non-compulsory school years-we should not be putting any disincentives in the way. I think the Minister has hung her arguments on the fact that 15-year-olds are not eligible for unemployment benefit. I must admit that I did not hear all of the debate but I had not heard anybody mention that 15-year-olds get unemployment benefit. I am not sure where that notion came from. Everybody acknowledges that they do not.
—But they do not in any State.

—That is right. Statistics available to us show that considerable numbers of 15-year-olds leave school to seek work even though they are not eligible for unemployment benefit. The application of these payments will operate, I presume, with the same type of rigour as is currently applied to tertiary education assistance scheme payments. The Government has been at great pains, even in terms of legislation, in recent months to tighten conditions in such a way that people who are receiving unemployment benefit do not receive TEAS allowance or other payments, to try to make sure that there is no overlap. In cases of financially disadvantaged people seeking to leave school to go into employment, I would have thought we needed not to ensure that there is no disincentive but to provide an incentive. These are the people about whom we are concerned. Accepting the Government's educational argument concerning disadvantaged families, I think we need an incentive for students to stay on at school. I know there is already a massive incentive for them to leave, whether they receive unemployment benefit or not. There is an incentive for them to leave school to seek work because of the economic pressures on their families. Very large numbers of them succeed in finding work at 15 years of age. This is shown by the figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Presumably what we are about here-I think this is what the Minister is about too-is trying to even up in some way the opportunity for, the incentive for and the ability of those children who belong to disadvantaged families to go on in secondary schooling.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister used a number of arguments which I do not think are really plausible or all that pertinent. I wonder whether the Minister is able to provide the percentage coverage because we have not had those figures yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Percentage coverage of what?
—What percentage coverage is expected in terms of the secondary schooling population? What are we looking at?
—Eligibility.

—No, we know the eligibility criteria but the Government presumably has made some type of projection of the percentage coverage that it expects. We have had a variety of goes at it. The Government presumably has some figures on it. Once we know those figures we can probably get a better lever on what absolute numbers of people we will be looking at, the number of 15-year-olds in year 11. We have to give those kids in disadvantaged families the benefit of being able to continue in education. After all, the Government has been willing to give the benefit in the compulsory school years for 16-year-olds.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Minister that in Western Australia not only is there no disincentive but also the students legally cannot leave school if they turn 16 years in the final year of the compulsory school period. So in at least one State of the Commonwealth there is absolutely no reason why the Commonwealth should be paying any money to the 16-year-olds in year 10 because they cannot leave if they turn 16 years in year 10 anyhow. I readily admit that that situation does not occur in any other State. The Minister is saying that we will pick up the 16-year-olds because they happen to be 16 years but we will not pick up the 15-year-olds despite the fact that they are trying to make that transition to the non-compulsory school years, which is a very important transition. If we can provide the sorts of families about which we are talking with some money when they are hovering, under pressure, not very much above and possibly below the poverty line, when they need that advantage, we may influence their decision.

The Minister interposed that there may be a family allowance payment of $5.70 a week per child and if the family income is no more than $12,000 the family will get the supplement of $17 a week. As the Minister said, we are looking at $22 to $23 a week. For those types of families there is a lot of difference between that amount and $40 a week-an enormous difference. Children in such families, because the family needs to be able to live may-not through any ill will but through necessity-feel pressure to leave school to get work to try to bring some income into the family. I think it is the Minister's intention to assist those families to make sure that those kids have as good a chance as we can give them compared with other children in our society to make that transition between compulsory and non-compulsory schooling years.

I wonder whether the Minister might be able to look at even some medium way of picking up those 15-year-olds who are in the non-compulsory schooling years. I do not know whether that is possible under this Act. I looked at it, and I do not think it is. But the Minister may have some avenue of discretion in that regard. I could not see any under this Act, but there may be such a discretion for the Minister under another Act; I doubt it. In looking at the history of the various schemes, I noticed that there was absolutely no legislative base for the previous payments that were being made, anyhow. So presumably the Minister would be quite capable of continuing those payments because they did not have a legislative base to date, and this is the first time that they have had such a base. I suppose the Minister could carry that extra load. I realise that there are costs involved, although, of course, if one were looking only at the compulsory schooling years there would also be savings involved. I am not terribly interested in trying to cut it out for those 16-year-olds in year 10. But I am concerned about the 15-year-olds in years 11 and 12. I will be interested to hear, in the Minister's response, what type of incentives she sees that we might be able to give to kids who the Minister has said she wishes to assist to undertake additional schooling, so that they can be given the opportunity to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin, essentially, has reiterated the point he made during the second reading debate. I will respond to that point again. But he has asked some questions in support of his amendment, and I will attempt to answer those. He asked what proportion of 16-year-olds we expected to be eligible for the scheme. The answer is about 24 per cent. He also pointed to the fact that some 15-year-olds do get employment if they drop out of school and that there is support from the Australian Bureau of Statistics for that view. Of course, there is, but I think Senator Macklin should look at the proportion of 15-year-olds who are in part-time or casual employment, which is the most common form of employment for students in that age group. Of course, many such students are also full-time secondary students. In fact, when we are talking about 15-year-olds--
—Of those who are in any work, the majority are in permanent work; twice the number-11,000 to 5,200.
—My advice is that, in the case of 15-year-olds, a majority are in part-time work--
—The Statistician must be wrong, then?

—We will have to look carefully at his definitions. In any event, I remind Senator Macklin that part time and casual work is available and is taken up by many 15-year-olds from poorer families, and also by 15-year-olds from not such poor families. We are not looking here at the only source of available income to a 15-year-old. There is the possibility of part time casual work. Of course, there is the family allowance, the family income supplement, or an additional pensioner benefit. So we are not looking at leaving 15-year-olds without any form of support.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin asked: Is there a medium way? There could be medium ways but they all cost money. I remind Senator Macklin that we are trying to bring in a major social reform that redistributes public revenues very significantly to students from poorer families, at a time of enormous budgetary constraint. If one has more money, of course, it is possible to improve the scheme. But we do not have more money, and any suggestion either of continuing to pay the allowance under the secondary allowances scheme-of course, there would be administrative costs in running two schemes at the same time which would add to the cost of paying a benefit-or if we extended it to 15-year-olds in year 11, we would be up for major costs. In the case of the latter suggestion we would be up for $35m. The Government does not have $35m to add on to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did that come from? You have not given us the figures yet. How can you possibly get $35m in that particular exercise? What are you looking at-100 per cent, 20 per cent, or what?

—I did answer Senator Macklin's question. I think he was somewhat distracted at the time. I said that the proportion of 16-year-olds who would be eligible for the scheme is estimated to be in the vicinity of 24 per cent of all 16-year-olds. So I assure Senator Macklin that the figure of $35m has been very thoroughly investigated by the very competent officers of my Department, and that would be the cost of extending the scheme to 15-year-olds in year 11. That is a cost that the Government cannot take up at this stage and, in any event, if we did, although it would mean that some of those students would have additional income, it would not really reinforce the basic aim of the scheme, which is to remove the disincentive to drop out and go into the work force. I can only repeat that point.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally-I hope that Senator Teague will pay close attention to this-the amendment that has been moved by the Australian Democrats goes well beyond the kind of minor concern that has been expressed. I remind honourable senators of its wording:

Where a person is undertaking, or proposes to undertake, a course of study or instruction, or a part of a course of study or instruction, that is, a secondary course or a tertiary course, or part of a secondary course or of a tertiary course, for the purpose of section 10 . . .

This, of course, brings in all secondary education and the cost blow-out would be extraordinary. It would be well beyond the $35m mark. I do not think Senator Teague would really be in a position to support an amendment of such far reaching dimensions. It would extend the payment to anyone undertaking even a part of a secondary course. So the cost would be enormous. I think it would certainly be a gross change to the Budget, and therefore, I believe, it would be unacceptable not only to the Government, but also to the Liberal Party, which has already expressed an attitude of responsibility in regard to Budget Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the points she has raised. The $35m, I suppose, works on the basis of about 3,000 students, because overall in Australia, at least in terms of the latest figures I have, as at 1 July, there were 11,618 15-year-old students in year 11.
—No, it is much more.
—What figures is the Minister looking at? Can she give me the basis for that figure?
—There are currently 26,000 15-year-olds in years 11 and 12. So we are looking at a much larger group.

—That is an interesting figure. I am reading from table 8 which sets out the number of full time students in Government schools in Australia. The Minister is saying that there are twice that number in private schools. Only 25 per cent of the school population attend private schools and 75 per cent attend state schools--
—But private schools have a higher participation rate to year 11.

—They do, but they also have a far higher income, in which case we are looking at the percentage that will attend government schools. The Minister has argued on many occasions that the vast proportion of government school pupils come from the lower paid sections of our society, except in the Catholic school system--
—But the Catholic school system is the biggest system.
—I know that it is the biggest system, but it does not have the highest retention rate.
—They have a much higher rate than state schools.
—Not much higher; a bit higher. It is not as high as the private schools. So the total figure that the Minister is working on is--
—Twenty-six thousand would qualify.
—Twenty-six thousand 15-year-olds who would qualify?
—Yes, 26,270 would qualify under the income test in years 11 and 12.

—I find that an extraordinary figure. I would certainly like to see the calculations for that. But there does not seem to be the time in which one would be able to press it now, in considering the factor of the percentage in private schools and the percentage in government schools. I have no idea how we manage to arrive at a figure of 26,000, considering the fact that in the whole of Australia, in government schools there are only 58,000 in total in year 11.
—I was referring to years 11 and 12.
—In terms of 15-year-olds in year 12, there are 136 in the whole of Australia in government schools. So I hardly think they will increase the percentage in any way.
—I think you have problems with your statistics.

—We may well have. The Statistician probably does. I do not know what figures the Minister is working on. It would have been useful to have them at the second reading stage so that I could have made some calculations. Has the Minister or the Department had any advice with regard to the constitutionality of the exercise? I refer, in particular, to section 117 and discrimination between States as a result of this exercise?
—The Department of Education has not sought that advice because there is no discrimination. We are paying the allowance to students in each State on the same basis, namely, that they have turned 16.

—From listening to the Minister tonight, am I to understand that it is quite competent for a State government to legislate to establish a university in that State-such as the Queensland Government with the new Bond University-and that university would be free of Commonwealth subsidy for its establishment, staff or students? Would the university be free of all Commonwealth regulations regarding its facilities, its buildings and the contents of its buildings? Would it be free of Commonwealth control over its curricula, accreditation and recognition of terms, conditions or qualifications of staff? Would it be free of recognition of the qualifications of graduates?

—Senator Sheil shows an admirable grasp of State powers. A State can establish any body as a university, call it a university and, if the Commonwealth does not recognise it, the Commonwealth has no involvement along the lines suggested. Under those circumstances it would be regarded as a private university.

—The Opposition has carefully followed the answers given by the Minister with regard to the matters Senator Macklin raised. The matter most in our mind was coming to grips with the precise dimensions of the additional expenditure required to give secondary allowances to 15-year-olds in years 11 and 12. I understand from the facts that the Minister has given that 26,000 15-year-olds are in years 11 and 12, that 24 per cent of those could be expected to be eligible for the--
—That figure was the total who would qualify.

—That is already 24 per cent of the whole number. As the Minister has said, clarification has still to be reached on this matter. We understand that 26,000 15-year-olds in years 11 and 12 would be eligible for Austudy allowances, and that represents around 24 per cent of all 15-year-olds in years 11 and 12. So something like 100,000, 15-year-olds are in years 11 and 12. Is that correct, Minister?

—I just clarify these statistics because I think the Australian Democrats are under serious misapprehensions and I would like to assist them. We are talking about the estimated numbers of secondary students who will receive Austudy allowances in 1987. In 1987 the number of years 11 and 12 students who will qualify under the income test and who will receive an allowance for more than half a year-that is, they will not have turned 16 at the beginning of the year-is 15,870; the number who will receive an allowance for less than half a year is 7,500; and the number who will not receive an allowance at all, that is, those who do not turn 16 before the end of the year, is 2,900. So the total years 11 and 12 students who will qualify under the income test is 26,270, and that is about 24 per cent of the entire age cohort.

—Whatever the arithmetic, the bottom line, in terms of additional expenditure, is estimated by the Government to be $35m. That is the figure we understood when we began this debate and that relates to the reluctance I have already mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage as well as when I first spoke in the Committee stage. I have one further question to ask the Minister. In summing up the second reading debate she spoke of States making available allowances to 15-year-olds in year 11. Presumably this would be schemes especially in the Northern Territory, South Australia and Western Australia. I did not hear clearly what amount of money the Commonwealth might be providing to those two States and the Northern Territory in this respect.

—We would not be providing any money in respect of assistance to 15-year-olds. However, we are now paying this greatly increased amount to 16-year-olds on. For example, in Western Australia the total number who will receive a benefit under our scheme is much larger than the total number who would have received it under the old scheme. Western Australia as a State is receiving a substantial increase in terms of student allowances and it should look to targeting the allowance it gives-it gives an allowance in the vicinity of $100 a year per kid 15-year-old and on-to all 15-year-olds so that 15-year-olds who go to year 11 get a substantial benefit from the State and then phase into the Commonwealth benefit when they turn 16. In that way the two schemes would dovetail and the benefit to the 15-year-old would be larger because the amount of money the Western Australian Government would have would not have to be spread right up to 18-year-olds. It could concentrate on the 15-year-olds. I am not sure that at this stage the Western Australian Government will respond immediately to that suggestion, but this is the kind of step we are taking with the State governments. We are pointing out to them that their student population as a whole is benefiting and that we are really making a substantial improvement to the 16-year-old and upward age group. We are suggesting that the states should concentrate their benefit, regardless of what form it is in, on the 15-year-old. This is the type of dovetailing we are working towards. As I have said, we have not reached an outright agreement but in the case of Senator Teague's State I must say that we have always had most harmonious relationships with the State Government. We are hopeful that we will achieve a dovetailing of this kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In what I think will be the final time I rise on this matter, I welcome those marginal benefits that may be gained through discussions with the States. Of course there is a great discrepancy between the eastern States' advantage in this matter over Western Australia and South Australia. I also note that with family allowance and pensioner supplements in respect of dependent student children there is a maximum of $24 available to some 15-year-olds in year 11. I also acknowledge that 15-year-olds are not competing with an option of receiving the unemployment benefit. However, the Opposition is not convinced that the present approach to this solution by the Government is entirely satisfactory. The principles we set out in the second reading debate still hold. We will need to examine this matter between now and the time the regulations may be established and the Senate may look at disallowing any of those regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: The crunch of the question is this: The whole purpose of this measure is to remove a disincentive to those secondary students who have a $15 disadvantage per week against those receiving the unemployment benefit-that is, a $35 allowance as it now is as against a $50 unemployment benefit. This measure introduces a new disincentive of $40 in the case of a 15-year-old in year 11 as opposed to a 16-year-old in year 11, both students being in that quarter of students who are eligible for the Austudy allowance. I still believe that that amount is a substantial disincentive. That cohort of students of 15 years of age entering year 11 will not be eligible for the $40 that they have been receiving up until this year and will have the incentive to go and find work and not continue with years 11 and 12. In other words, the $40 a week benefit that has been available up to this point will not be available to them. They will not receive anything except the $24 maximum from the family allowance, pensioner benefit and maybe some payment from a State scheme. I still believe that this substantial penalty will drive 15-year-olds to undertake work.

I come now to the Australian Democrats' amendment. I am required, on behalf of the Opposition, to note-and this is my conscientious view-that this amendment is too general and sweeping in its terms. It refers to tertiary students as well as secondary students. I think the reference to `tertiary' is inappropriate. The amendment would place in the Act a requirement that there be no discrimination between students on the basis of age when all along the Opposition has argued that there ought to be a sensible mix that takes into account age and year of study. Because the amendment proposed by the Democrats is in those terms, the Opposition is unable to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education raised a number of questions in respect of Western Australia. I heard her say that $100 a year was given to someone. I am not quite sure what that is actually going to do for someone who is trying to look after a kid in Australia today. I suppose $2 a week is of some use to somebody or other, but I am not quite sure, given the--
—It is a one-off payment at the beginning of the year to buy books.
—It certainly will not feed anybody, Senator.
—It is not meant to.

—I am not quite sure why the Minister dragged this into the debate. I thought we were talking about some sort of support for low income families, not $100 to be used to feed and clothe somebody. I am just wondering what discussions the Minister has had with the South Australian Government in particular, because I would like to put to her an extreme case involving students in grade 11 attending government schools. As at 1 July 8,142 15-year-olds out of a total of 14,935 in government schools were in grade 11. What is proposed should be done in respect of South Australia in which as at July over half of the grade 11 students were 15 years of age? Will the Minister make any special arrangements in regard to South Australia, because it seems to me, as a result of previous State decisions, that that State will now be massively disadvantaged compared with other States, and certainly compared with the Australian Capital Territory which has a minute number of 15-year-olds in grade 11, as do Victoria and New South Wales. South Australia has a very large percentage of such students. It seems to me that those students are being actively discriminated against in terms of the decision that the Government has made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage we are having discussions with South Australia. We hope that that State will find some way of focusing assistance on 15-year-olds. We still have to sort that out with South Australia. However, we do not have any particular proposal at this stage to change the age-related nature of the structure. We are talking about amounts of money which, of course, are considerably increased for 1987. Of course, in 1988 we will be paying allowances up to the level of the youth unemployment benefit which will mean an overall increase in the amount of money going by way of education allowances to students in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Macklin's amendment) be inserted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:
