SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 5, proposed new section 10, leave out ``to a person'', insert ``in respect of a person''.
(2) Page 3, clause 5, proposed new section 11, leave out ``to a person'', insert ``in respect of a person''.
(3) Page 3, clause 5, after proposed new section 11, add the following section:
``12. Benefit under Education Assistance granted in respect of a person is payable-

(a) in the case of a person who is undertaking, or proposes to undertake, a course of study or instruction, or a part of a course of study or instruction, that is a secondary course, or a part of a secondary course, for the purposes of section 10-to a parent or guardian of the person, or, in circumstances prescribed by the regulations, to a person in accordance with the regulations; and

(b) in the case of a person who is undertaking, or proposes to undertake, a course of study or instruction, or a part of a course of study or instruction, that is a tertiary course, or a part of a tertiary course, for the purposes of section 10-to the person.''.

The amendments all relate to the recipient of the benefit for secondary student enrolments. The Student Assistance Amendment Bill provides that for the first time secondary education allowances will be paid to the student rather than to the parent who is responsible for that student's education. The Opposition does not support that change and accordingly has moved that the words `to a person' be changed to `in respect of a person'.

The substantial amendment is the third amendment. This provides that the benefit granted to an eligible student enrolled in a secondary course may be received by a parent or guardian. We believe that this benefit should assist parents who have the financial and other responsibilities to provide education for their dependent secondary school children. I do not believe the Government should come between parents and their children in these financial arrangements. Next year the allowance for a 16-year-old secondary school student will be $50 and in 1988 it will be $53.50. That arrangement has the potential to be a lever to give financial independence to students. If a disagreement developed between a student and his parents the Commonwealth's financial assistance, in the way it is proposed to be used, would act as a lever to disrupt and weaken the family. We believe that the appropriate division in terms of the receipt by a student as against his parents is enrolment in a tertiary education institution or reaching the age of 18 years. It is already acknowledged by everyone that there is a means test on the family, on the parent's income, that determines whether any allowance is payable in the first place. There is no provision for 16- and 17-year-olds living away from home as it is assumed that the allowances for them will be payable only in respect of secondary school students at home. There is provision in the Bill for tertiary enrolments and 18-year-olds. There is also a second rate of allowance for students living away from home. So that distinction, in terms of the living away from home allowance, is already in the Act and is extended by this Bill. Until now the parent has always received the benefit of the secondary education allowances and we believe that this situation should continue. It has never been suggested that education allowances of any kind should be received directly by students under 16 years instead of by parents. We do see a danger, at a time when we are trying to remove a disincentive arising from the unemployment benefit, in introducing a second and equally odious disincentive that would break down family relationships. We have therefore come to the view that the right point of demarcation is 18 years of age and enrolment in a tertiary institution. I therefore urge the Australian Democrats to support the Opposition's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in my speech during the second reading debate, the Australian Democrats have a great deal of sympathy with the Opposition's amendments on the payment of allowances to parents. As I suggested then, there are considerable differences between the secondary school and the tertiary sectors, despite the fact that many of those children are of the same age. The Minister for Education in fact referred to that when she spoke about technical and further education students who could be of identical age to those in secondary schools. In her reply to the second reading debate she raised a point that was very important to us, and I would like some clarification on it because it will certainly influence the way we are going to vote on this issue. She mentioned that many families-after all we are talking about low income families and trying to get support to them to enable their children to continue their education-would be much better off because the tax system is such that if the money were paid to the parents it would be counted in with their income for taxation purposes; whereas if it were paid to the student, the student would still come under the taxation threshold and hence it would not be taxed. I suppose one's immediate response to that is: `Why not make this non-taxable?'. If it is a means-tested operation we could hardly do that. Does the Minister have any figures on this? We would certainly be inclined not to support the Opposition's amendments if the Government were able to show that those low income families would be better off by allowing the money to be paid to the student. After all, I suggest that in the majority of homes the exercise is a nominal one, particularly in homes, in my opinion, that are working well. It would make no difference whether the allowance were paid to the parents or to the student because it would be considered by the student to be paid via the parent anyhow. It is probably only those families where there is tension that this type of thing might arise. What we are about is getting the maximum benefit to those low income families. I admit that the Minister's statement is very important.

—I have also taken careful note of the Minister's remarks about these allowances being taxable. But I can remember very well when such allowances were not taxable in the hands of the recipient. I believe that by a simple amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act-I understand that it may be section 6 of that Act-we may revert to the situation that obtained a few years ago when such allowances were not taxable in the hands of the recipient. An exemption could be made that is quite specific for allowances paid in respect of enrolments in a secondary school. So the receipt of post-graduate awards and tertiary allowances could still continue as they have in recent years. In that respect all of the principles and the advantages which the Minister has already referred to in summing up on the second reading debate would still flow on. The arguments that I have put forward would be put in place. The good arguments that Senator Macklin put forward would be achieved by simply amending the Income Tax Assessment Act to revert to the situation of some years ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to Senator Macklin's questions first. I place on record my appreciation of his recognition of what we are trying to do in this provision under discussion and that is to maximise benefit to the low income family. I also agree with Senator Macklin and we have worked out our calculations on this basis: In most families there is a harmonious relationship and the question of who actually receives the allowance is not a problem, but of course, there are some families in which it is a problem and we have addressed those circumstances very carefully over a long time to try to get the best possible result. We believe that what we are proposing is the best possible result. Senator Macklin asked for some specific figures on the effects of low income families should the benefit be paid to a parent rather than to the student. If the benefit were paid to a non-working mother in a low income family, the reduction of the dependent spouse rebate to the breadwinner-the father in that case-would be $449 per annum. If it were paid to the breadwinner, the father, it would be a larger reduction-over $600. But the circumstance of the type of family over which Senator Macklin has most concern, the pensioner family, would be even worse. We would be moving them into a poverty trap because the amount of the payment is such that the marginal rate of tax would be 80c in the dollar. The actual per annum income depends on what other income the pensioner has available to him or her. It is obviously a very severe poverty trap. I ask Senator Macklin to consider those effects. We certainly considered them and have arrived at this position.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague has attacked the problem laterally by suggesting that we could amend the tax Act to make the benefit non-taxable, regardless of who received it. That would be moving against the whole trend of our Government's taxation policy which is to try to introduce consistency in the treatment of income, to try to treat all income in a similar way. Although there might appear to be an immediate benefit in Senator Teague's eyes in excluding this particular part of income, many of the anomalies that have grown up in the taxation system over the years have arisen from governments having policies that allowed income from different sources to be treated differently. We have given very great consideration to all of the matters raised by Senator Macklin and Senator Teague. The matter is not straightforward. We did not leap immediately to this conclusion. In fact, earlier on in our consideration we looked at maintaining the practice whereby the payment was made to the parent. If one looks at what we are trying to do overall, and that is to increase the capacity of the poor family, to keep the students in education, one will see that we want to maximise the benefit and our proposal will do that. I recognise the seriousness of the matters raised by both honourable senators, but I hope that they will give consideration to supporting the provision as we have set it out and thus maximise the benefit to low income families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that there is substance in the arguments put, but a judgment has to be made. I still believe that the Opposition's amendments ought to be supported by the Committee. The Income Tax Assessment Act can be amended so as to revert to the situation of some years ago. I have taken fully into account what the Minister has just said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Australian Democrats, on the basis of the Minister's response, will not be supporting the Opposition's amendment. As the Minister pointed out, I am particularly concerned about pensioner families. The changes to the Income Tax Assessment Act would not assist those families because they do not pay tax. We would have to go into a rather complicated mechanism to change the pensions in regard to this. It would be an incredibly complicated problem to exclude this particular item. As we know, there are growing numbers of kids in schools from full pensioner families. That is something that could not be addressed by Senator Teague's lateral solution. Pensioner families are not in a tax bracket. They are outside the taxation system, yet they would actually meet and fall into that system by this very operation. It does not add to the taxable income. It, in fact, adds to their pension and takes them into the taxable income. Senator Teague would need a few more amendments than the one he is suggesting. We would have to go through a number of Acts. It is unfortunate in some ways that it has to be done this way, but if that harmony is not present there is not likely to be much incentive for the kid to go to secondary school. There has to be some support. If the rapport is there between the kids and the parents, paying the allowance to the child will not create massive family disruption as has been suggested by some people. The Democrats will be supporting the Government's clauses on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to page 3 of the Bill. Does not the Minister acknowledge that, in removing the 13-year standing incidentals allowance, there is a shortchanging of students in the expectations they have had? In lifting the educational allowance to the unemployment benefit level it was assumed all along that the incidentals allowance was on top of the rate of tertiary allowance or secondary allowance as is appropriate at each age level. I want to hear the Minister's acknowledgment that in removing the incidentals allowance to ease the financial burden of lifting the education allowance to the same level as the unemployment benefit up to 1989 there is a short-changing of students.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague is correct in pointing to the fact that the incidentals allowance will no longer be part of our students assistance scheme. It has been absorbed into the new allowances, but the increases for most students are such that they are well ahead in any event of where they would have been under the old TEAS plus incidentals allowance. There is still an overall benefit to students. I am not sure what individual student's expectations were of the outcome of the rationalisation process. It has been a very long, technical and complex process, but students will know when they receive their increased allowances that they are doing better than they were-and that is what we all want.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Ryan) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX RATES BILL 1986INCOME TAX BILL 1986TAXATION LAWS (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1986MEDICARE LEVY BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 October, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Income Tax Bill 1986, the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1986 and the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986. After more than 13 months since the announcement of the tax reform package by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) we have now come to the critical point of seeing what the Government intends to offer the people of Australia by way of tax cuts. Before we discuss the nature of these income tax arrangements that will apply from December this year, and further in July next year, it is important that we understand what people will have to face in taxes in the new year.

SPEECH.PARA: First, we have to recognise that since September 1985 we have seen the introduction of a new system whereby there has been a disallowance of legitimate business expenses incurred in the hospitality industry. We have seen the introduction of a fringe benefits tax, which has caused enormous concern and confusion in the community because of the Government's lack of understanding as to what it intends, and a new capital gains tax which is the most savage in the world and which imposes taxes at the highest marginal rates. It fails to meet the Treasurer's obligations when he committed the Government to saying that assets held before 19 September 1985 would not be taxable, when in certain circumstances they are taxable, and changes which occur in circumstances of transactions fundamentally change the taxation liability of taxpayers.

Collectively, those things are intended, together with other measures, to raise some $1,500m from the taxpayer over two years. The Government would have us believe that the so-called tax cuts, by virtue of the Bills before us now, are likely to occur in December and July of next year and that these new taxes, having come into force, consequently are of benefit in terms of equity and fairness to the average taxpayer. The truth is quite different. The extra $3 billion which is represented in terms of these Bills as being some kind of tax cut really comes only from inflation. Taxpayers will be getting back in their hands the money which they have already contributed to the Government through inflation and by the Government forcing them into a higher tax bracket.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is how they brought down the deficit.

—Yes, that is so. All the measures in this latest Budget, introduced just two months ago on 19 August, clearly were designated only to get over an immediate political hurdle which the Government saw before it, and clearly the Government had no long term goals in mind for the economy. An extra $1,500m was raised by taxation in the August Budget. It contributed to a reduction of some $2,200m in the Budget deficit to try to impress on the financial markets that this Government had the economy under control. The fact is that the Government does not, and the obvious extra taxation which has arisen from the Budget legislation will only just help to pay back to people what they have lost already through inflation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will return for a moment to the events of 1984, just prior to the election. We remember full well how our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised sincerely and solemnly that the people of Australia would have tax reform via the so-called tax summit which he intended to call after his election to office. Subsequently that happened. But the Prime Minister promised that we would have tax reform according to nine fundamental principles, which he laid down in the election campaign. Let us remember a few of those. First was the promise that during Labor's term of office there would be no increase in the overall tax burden as measured by the share of gross domestic product taken by the Government in tax revenue. That was the first promise to be given and the first to be broken, along with the other promises about how he would not have capital gains taxes, taxes on lump sum superannuation and assets tests on pension.

We were given the extra promise that there would be no increase in the tax burden. What happened in the 1986 Budget? We have the highest proportion of gross domestic product going to taxes of any government since Federation-25.5 per cent of taxes goes to the Federal Government through this Budget. That figure is greater than that in the previous year and represents a breach of the fundamental, very sincere and solemn promise given by the Prime Minister. Compared with 1985-86 there has been a substantial increase in the total tax revenue gained to gross domestic product.

Let us consider some of the other principles which were enunciated by the Prime Minister before the 1984 election. He said that any reform must simplify the tax system so that all Australians can understand it more easily, making avoidance and evasion more difficult. Everybody would agree with that. But what has this Government done? It has introduced the most complex legislation-625 pages of legislation in the last few months-for a new capital gains tax which absolutely defies interpretation. It has introduced a fringe benefits tax that has caused and is continuing to cause very difficult problems, not only for the practitioners in the industry, but even for the back bench members of the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Ministers.

—Senator Watson is wise to remind us of that. During the debate on the legislation some six months ago in this very chamber the points that are now being raised by Labor Party back benchers were raised by the Opposition senators on this side of the chamber. We could not get any answers at all from Ministers as to what the fringe benefits tax legislation was all about. Ministers did not know what they were doing and certainly Labor Party back benchers had no understanding whatsoever of the nature of the law that was passed in this House.
—You cannot even get answers now.

—They are only just waking up now. We can get no answers from Ministers as to what is intended by a review of the fringe benefits tax. We can get no answers at all as to what is meant by the unintended consequences of the Act. Government Ministers cannot tell us. Officers from the Australian Taxation Office tell us that they have not been told what the unintended consequences of the legislation are to which they are supposed to be reacting.
—We have 130 pages of rulings.

—Senator Watson is doing very well in reminding me that 130 pages of rulings have now come out of the Taxation Office about the fringe benefits tax on top of all the legislation, the video tapes featuring Richard Carleton that are hopeless and all the kind of nonsense which the Government is trying to tell us is a good thing.

SPEECH.PARA: Worst of all, the Government has now committed itself, apparently, to $2m worth of advertising to tell us how good the fringe benefits tax is for all Australians. This sum has been committed before the Government has even determined the outcome of the review it is supposed to be undertaking. So we have no idea what the original law is which it is trying to sell us. It has not yet determined it, yet it is prepared to commit an extra $2m of taxpayers' dollars to telling us how good the tax is for us. What kind of law is that? All of this comes under the heading of the Prime Minister's commitment to simplicity in the tax law, something he promised us before the 1984 election.

Let us try to understand a little more about this set of amendments. The failure of this Government to deliver the tax cuts that were promised on 1 September this year means that a person on average weekly earnings, which are currently $480, will pay $110 more in tax this year. That is the result of the Government's broken promise, and it is even after all these tax cuts are applied. That person will still be paying $110 more. On the same day as the delayed cuts are to become effective, 1 December, the Government is to raise the Medicare levy by 25 per cent. So instead of paying one per cent, we will now pay 1.25 per cent. Honourable senators might remember that the Prime Minister made us another promise during the 1984 election campaign that there would be no increase in the Medicare levy. So another broken promise is chalked up to the Prime Minister. The Medicare levy has been increased substantially, by 25 per cent.

A single breadwinner in a family with one income and two dependent children will be $23.50 worse off than he was before the 1984 election. He believed what the Prime Minister said during the election campaign. The Prime Minister promised us that there would be no assets test on pensions. He promised us that there would be no Medicare levy increase. He promised us reduced taxation, not higher taxation. But what do we find? We are $23.50 worse off. This comes on top of the increases in the petrol excise, which has already gone up from 6.1 cents to 19.7 cents-multiplied by 300 per cent since the 1984 election. That represents an extra cost of $6 per week to the average family.

Let us go back a little further to the commencement of the period in office of the Hawke Labor Government-March 1983. Let us again take the case of a person on average weekly earnings. In 1983 the marginal tax rate, that is, the rate of tax payable on the next dollar of income to a person on those earnings, was 30 per cent. 30 cents on the next dollar would be paid in tax. What is the rate after all these grand tax cuts this Government is to give us on 1 July next year? Instead of 30 per cent we will pay 40 per cent, an increase of one-third since this Government came to power. That is what the Hawke Labor Government is about. We have seen the highest taxes from this Government in the history of Federation. Contrary to the impression the Government is trying to create in the community that it is reducing taxes, taxes will be rising very substantially.

To make the point even clearer, let us consider the average amount of tax paid by a family on average weekly earnings. In March 1983 when the Fraser Government went out of office, the average amount of tax paid was 17.5 per cent. But even after the tax cuts in this legislation, the Government will be taking 20.5 per cent from the average weekly earner, an increase of something like 20 per cent. It would take an additional income tax cut of $8 a week on top of the two stages of tax cuts in this legislation to bring the average taxpayer back to the same level he was on in March 1983, three and a half years ago. Clearly, the Government has no answers and is not addressing the points which are of importance to the average Australian.

It is interesting to note that even after 1 July 1987, when the second stage of these tax cuts comes into play, two million taxpayers will have moved out of the 29 per cent tax bracket that is being provided by this legislation and into the new 40 per cent tax bracket as a result of the natural flow of wage increases and the consequent flow into higher tax brackets-a very substantial increase. The disincentive effects of that are tremendous. There will be enormous problems as people decide to drop out of the work force or not to work as hard or to work only four days a week instead of five, and give up working for the Hawke Labor Government on that extra day. It is a very substantial increase on the marginal rate of tax, and it will hit the economy hard when it finally comes to fruition.

Let us turn to the rate structure that will apply under the Government's new proposal. These rates are to apply from 1 December this year. The Government is trumpeting about how well it is doing by getting the top income tax rate down below 60 per cent. It talks about income earners earning more than $35,000 who were previously paying 60 per cent on the extra dollar. In the period up to June of next year, the rate is going to drop by a tremendous amount-down to 58.25 per cent; a colossal saving, by any standards, of 1.775 per cent! According to this Government, that is some great achievement. That rate is made up of a 57.08 per cent rate of income tax and a Medicare levy increase of 1.145 per cent. That is a tremendous effort. I congratulate the Government on trying to bring about what it claims is some great achievement. In reality, of course, it represents nothing more than some kind of mouse-like change in the community.

Let us look at those who earn between $28,000 and $35,000. The rate that will apply from 1 December until next June is 47.975 per cent and the rate that presently applies under the present legislation is 48 per cent. That is a drop of 0.25 per cent. This is absolutely absurd. This Government is trying to kid us that it is achieving some great tax reform by reducing tax rates by 0.25 per cent. Similarly, with the rate applying to salaries from $19,500 to $28,000, the rate which will apply from 1 December is 45.395 per cent, which compares with 46 per cent under the current arrangements. We are seeing a situation where there is a very minimal drop in the level of tax rates, and it is so on down the scales. Obviously, this Government has laboured mightily to produce a mouse. Clearly, it will not be able to achieve anything like the ambitions that it is now putting about.

Another issue on which the Government has paraded itself as being a great achiever is the great attack it has taken to the tax avoidance and evasion industry. Everybody understands the fundamental point that the major cause of tax evasion and tax avoidance in Australia is our very high marginal rates of tax. That is not an issue between us.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should be ashamed, really.

—That is what your Treasurer said, Senator Giles, and he has repeated it in the White Paper. It is clearly his understanding that it is a major incentive for tax avoidance. I agree with that. I believe that those very high and steep progressive rates of tax are a great problem for the tax avoidance industry and stimulate it. This Government has recognised that, but what it has sought to do is to say: `Okay, all the blame is with the John Howards and the Malcolm Frasers of the past'. The Government says that it has done more in three years to smash the tax avoidance industry than anybody else. But this Government has done nothing to smash the tax avoidance industry. The people who smashed the tax avoidance industry were the members of the Fraser Government, particularly Treasurer John Howard, now the Leader of the Opposition, by two very important strokes. The first stroke was the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act amendments back in 1980, and the second stroke was the amendment to the taxation Act which introduced Part IVa of that Act to deal with sham transactions in a way that they could not have been dealt with under section 260 of the former law. Those two changes absolutely destroyed the tax avoidance industry from 1980 onwards and anybody who has anything to do with the taxation industry will tell honourable senators the same thing. Practitioners know full well that the industry was stopped dead in its tracks in 1981 as a result of the actions of John Howard. The tax avoidance industry has not changed one iota under this Government. That is the truth of the matter, and that is where this Government is so dishonest in its approach to tax avoidance, because it claims that it is the paragon of virtue whereas the actual deeds were done under the stewardship of John Howard as the Treasurer in the Fraser Government. Senator Maguire knows that. He is fair enough to understand those things and he knows that from reading the law. He only has to look at the historical part of the Act which spells that out.
—When you believe your own propaganda, that is the worst possible situation of all.

—Senator Maguire knows it, Senator Robertson. Senator Robertson does not have to explain it to him. He knows the truth. Senator Robertson knows that all those canards that honourable senators on the other side come up with from time to time to blame us for tax avoidance are wrong. If he does not know that, Senator Maguire does, because he is intelligent. He has had experience in these things and he knows the situation precisely.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I make the point that in the last few days the Commissioner of Taxation has made some comments in connection with the fringe benefits tax. This has been a matter of great concern to many people, because on two occasions now the Commissioner of Taxation has entered into political areas. Back in May, in advance of the law on the fringe benefits tax being passed, a document was issued which sought to obtain information from taxpayers about their affairs, without the authority of the law. That created great concern in the community at that time. In the last day or so, the Commissioner of Taxation has made disparaging statements about unnamed people, but he has clearly made the point that the fringe benefits tax is somehow something which has been brought to people's attention but that no action has been taken. I believe that it is absolutely outrageous for the Commissioner of Taxation to take such action in the situation we face in this country. I believe that a political action is being taken by an officer of the Public Service entering the fray in a political matter and putting an interpretation on events and on current debate within this country which stems from his personal involvement and background in this area. I believe that the statements of the Commissioner of Taxation in the last few days require to be commented upon. They certainly bring concern to all of us in the community.

If the Commissioner's statements in his speech yesterday are being wrongly interpreted, I believe he ought to say so. I hope that he will do that. But the situation remains that it is unusual for a Commissioner of Taxation or any other public servant-it is certainly wrong in principle-to get involved in political debate, especially with an issue as hot as the fringe benefits tax, or matters of that kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you make clear what the Opposition will do on fringe benefits?
—Wait and see.
—We have been waiting a long time.
—Senator Siddons will have a very clear statement of that when our tax policy is released.
—When might that be?

—It will be made clear to everybody in Australia at the appropriate time. I hesitate to talk of those matters but they have been raised in the public arena and deserve comment from those in the Parliament representing the people, in light of our constitutional background and history. I believe it is a problem which needs to be addressed and which ought to be addressed by this Government. Finally, in relation to the Income Tax Rates Bill, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that-
(a) the Government's taxation policy, in particular its fringe benefits and capital gains taxes, is causing damage and confusion to business and farmers;
(b) the Government's failure to deliver tax cuts on 1 September 1986 as promised in 1985 has caused additional hardship to families; and
(c) this Government is the highest taxing Government in history, with tax receipts estimated to reach 25.5% of GDP''.
In relation to the Medicare Levy Bill, I move:
At the end of the motion add:
``, but the Senate-
(a) condemns the Prime Minister for breaking his promise that for the term of Labor's next Government, the Medicare levy would not be increased;

(b) notes with concern that the Government continues to perpetuate the myth that the levy pays for Medicare health services when in fact it only pays approximately 40% of the cost of Medicare with the balance being funded out of general revenue; and
(c) condemns the Government for its total failure to take action to contain the massive blow-out in Medicare health costs''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Income Tax Rates Bill, the Income Tax Bill, the Taxation Laws (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill and the Medicare Levy Bill cognately. The Bills introduce the cuts to the marginal rates of income tax in the Australian tax system and they increase the taxation threshold. These moves are the final element of the Hawke Government's tax reform package concerning income tax. It is the most far reaching reform of the Australian taxation system ever. The aim of the reform is to restore fairness and equity, to reduce the burden on the ordinary pay-as-you-earn personal income tax payer in the community-a burden which got greater and greater under the Fraser-Howard Liberal Administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to what Senator Messner claimed earlier this evening, the tax reform package will not raise the overall level of taxation in the community. It is a reform package. It redistributes. The revenue that is collected in the tax initiatives in the package are paid back again as personal income tax cuts and as reductions in other taxation. It is a redistributive package. It does not lift the overall level of taxation in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not reduce it either.

—It is a reform package, as I said. Unfortunately, in carrying on the debate on this package in the community the Opposition has tried to create the fiction that overall taxation is rising as a result of the package. That is the fiction that this Opposition has been attempting. It is absolute nonsense. The tax package will raise some $1,500m in revenue but will return to the community some $4,500m. I regret to say that under the old Australian taxation system which was operated by the Fraser- Howard Liberal Government high income earners were able to avoid or minimise their taxation liabilities. That was the name of the game. That is what happened repeatedly under the taxation system that was operated by the Fraser-Howard Liberal Government. That income tax system was full of loopholes and rorts. Some examples are the disguising of otherwise taxable income in the form of tax free capital gains. There were negative gearing arrangements. Although the Opposition has been crying crocodile tears about the change in negative gearing arrangements having an effect on the rental housing market, the fact is that negative gearing was not engaged in to help rental housing anyway; it was purely a taxation avoidance device. It has nothing to do with boosting the stock of rental housing in the community. Negative gearing arrangements were designed sheerly to shelter the taxpayer's principal income from personal exertion from taxation obligations. That is what it was all about.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to fringe benefits. The other day I referred to the misnomer of the `company car'. All of us paid for company cars as deductions from company tax. We paid for the purchase of those cars which were made available often exclusively for private use of employees because those motor vehicles were 100 per cent deductions from company tax. So they were subsidised by the general taxpayer for private use. There was a whole range of other so-called fringe benefits such as the payment of fees at private schools by employers. That is what was going on in the community. In some cases these so-called fringe benefits represented 40 per cent of the total remuneration of top executives in Australia. When so-called fringe benefits reach that level they are no longer remuneration at the margin. The concept of calling such things fringe benefits is absolutely nonsensical.

Under the Fraser-Howard Government there were free lunches at taxpayers' expense. At about this time last year we heard an incredible array of claims about the impact on the restaurant industry of our moves to disallow entertainment allowances as tax deductions. Senator Messner made claims. Various sections of the National Party and the Liberal Party made claims about the potential impact on that industry of our disallowing entertainment allowances as tax deductions. The system was abused. We had examples of people taking their families out to lunch in expensive restaurants on Sundays and booking it up to the taxpayer. That is what was going on under the Fraser-Howard Government and we cleaned it up. These rorts were costing the community tens of millions of dollars annually.

Pay-as-you-earn taxpayers, the ordinary personal income tax payers in the community, were forced to shoulder an ever-increasing share of the Australian taxation burden. Yet income tax essentially became an optional tax for the rich in Australia. It became a voluntary tax under the Liberals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tax avoidance was an industry.

—No responsible government could tolerate a tax system which forced low and average income earners to subsidise the lurks and perks of the rich. Before I was elected to the Senate I can recall hearing Liberal politicians going round the country saying that there was no such thing as a free lunch. That was the slogan of the day in the 1970s to con the community into making sacrifices to help Mr Howard's economic policies to work. We were told repeatedly that there was no such thing as a free lunch. The Liberals and the Nationals in this place 12 months ago fought tooth and nail to retain tax subsidised lunches for very well to do people in the community. Yet they operated under that slogan that there was no such thing as a free lunch.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Howard, as Treasurer of Australia, tolerated and perpetuated that very blatantly unfair and regressive taxation system. He had five years as Treasurer of this country, from 1978 to 1982. He did nothing to clean up those abuses. In fact tax evasion and tax avoidance were among the very few growth industries under the Fraser-Howard Government. As Senator Robertson pointed out a few moments ago by interjection, tax avoidance grew into a major industry in this country while Mr Howard was Treasurer of Australia.

One of the great growth industries of the 1970s was the tax avoidance industry. Mr Howard, as Treasurer, was prepared to license the great Australian tax rip-off. I heard Senator Messner claim this evening, in a Stalinist re-write of history, that the Liberals had acted to clean up tax avoidance in Australia, that it was their initiative under that wonderful, squeaky-clean government that we had in the 1970s under Mr Fraser and Mr Howard, that acted to clean up tax avoidance and tax evasion in Australia. I have been in this place for some three and a half years. I can remember on a number of occasions in that period being on the losing side when we tried to get tax evasion legislation passed in this place. Repeatedly the Liberals, in the three and a half years that I have been in this place, have voted to destroy tax evasion legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many Bills were put up by you lot? Which ones were they? Tell us about them. Give us the name of the Bills.

—That is the record. Senator Messner can try to perpetrate another fiction, but in that period, on every occasion the Liberals voted to destroy this Government's vital tax avoidance crack down legislation. The Opposition says that the tax system in Australia should encourage incentive. But we are entitled to ask: What incentive did the old system encourage? It was the incentive to cheat and to fraud. I think that they are the qualities that the Opposition still wants to foster in this community.

SPEECH.PARA: The tax reform package which is enabled by this legislation, I am pleased to say, will close loopholes and eliminate rorts. The fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the disallowance of entertainment expenses will ensure that for the first time in many years high income earners in this country will pay their fair share of taxation. I point out to Senator Messner that the capital gains tax was very strongly supported at the National Taxation Summit last year. For example, the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures-hardly an affiliate of the Australian Labor Party, hardly a socialist organisation-very strongly endorsed the capital gains tax. It was also endorsed by the chief executive of CSR Ltd. The investment manager of the AMP Society, the largest investor in this country, endorsed the concept of a capital gains tax. This evening Senator Messner said that Australia's capital gains tax was the most punitive in the world, the toughest capital gains tax in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sure is.

—I wish it were. But I point out that whilst Senator Messner claims that it is a very punitive tax, in fact it is about the only capital gains tax in the developed countries which fully adjusts the capital gain for inflation.
—You don't adjust good will. Your house can be taxed. Prior to 19 September property can be taxed. You just don't know your law.

—There is full indexation of the capital gain before taxation is applied, so there is no inflation element in the tax. The capital gains tax is a tax on real gains, and that is most unlike the capital gains taxes in the other developed countries. From that point of view, I hope that Senator Messner has learnt something this evening. I regret to say that our capital gains tax is not the toughest in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: The revenue raised by the disallowance of the tax-subsidised lunch, the taxation on fringe benefits and the introduction of the capital gains tax will finance this Government's income tax reductions for many Australians. That is the key point to be borne in mind. We could not have these income tax reductions for the vast majority of pay as you earn personal income tax payers in Australia if we did not have the fringe benefits tax, if we did not have the capital gains tax, and if we had not cracked down last year on the subsidised lunch. The revenues from those items-over $575m in a full year from the fringe benefits tax, over $330m in a full year from the crackdown on the tax subsidised business lunch, and the revenue over and above that from the capital gains tax-are vital components in the financing of this Government's taxation package. We cannot have cuts in personal income tax without the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the disallowance of entertainment expenses.

The Government's tax reforms are part of a package. The Opposition, day after day and week after week, chooses to ignore this. It seizes upon part of the package. It tries to create the impression that the Government is raising taxation. Of course, nothing is further from the truth. The Government is simply closing loopholes, eliminating rorts and redistributing revenue in the form of tax cuts. The Government is easing the tax burden on honest taxpayers by taxing the evaders, the avoiders and the cheats. The Liberals, by opposing the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, in effect, are trying to sabotage the personal income tax reductions for the ordinary Australian. That is what it comes down to. They are working with groups in the community to deny us revenue which we can pay back, as personal income tax reductions, to the great majority of ordinary Australian taxpayers. That is what it is all about.

The tax cuts which will occur in about six weeks' time, on 1 December, follow on from the income tax reductions which we introduced in November 1984. At that stage we introduced phase one of our reforms of income tax. At that time, in November 1984, taxpayers with taxable incomes of between $240 and $530 a week received an income tax reduction of $7.60 a week. At that time that $7.60 a week reduction in income tax partly reflected the changes in the tax rates. For example, the standard marginal tax rate at the time was reduced from 30c in the dollar to 25c in the dollar. That was of major benefit to low and middle income earners.

From 1 December this year we will raise the tax free threshold-that is, the exemption on the first dollars of taxable income-from $4,595 to $5,100, a tremendous increase in the tax free threshold. Members of the Liberal Party should eat their hearts out because they never achieved a tax free threshold of over $5,000. Under this Government it will be $5,100. The best that Mr Howard could do as Treasurer was to have a tax free threshold of $4,595.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they did index it for six months.

—Then they got rather sick of it. We are going beyond reductions in the tax free threshold. We will reduce marginal income tax rates as well, so there will be a two-fold effect in reducing the income tax burden on average Australians. Marginal tax rates will be reduced throughout the tax scale. In fact, we will compress the current five income tax brackets system to a tax system which has four brackets. For example, the current marginal rate of 48c will go down to 40c in the dollar, and the 46c rate will also go down to 40c in the dollar. The bottom marginal rate will go from 25c, which I referred to a moment ago, down to 24c. At the top of the income range, the highest income bracket, the marginal rate will be reduced from 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. Of course, the average tax rates are well below those marginal tax rates. That is one of the other great fictions that the Liberal Party tries to create in the community. It tries to con people into believing that marginal tax rates are synonymous with average tax rates-the rates which are paid on all dollars of income. Of course, the average tax rates are well below those marginal rates-the rates which apply to the last dollars of income.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the finance derived from the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the crack down on the free lunch, the tax cuts will be quite significant. For example, a taxpayer on a taxable income of $400 a week will receive a reduction of $5.10. So when one combines that with the $7.60 reduction in income tax that this Government introduced in November 1984, that gives a weekly reduction in personal income tax of $12.70. That is a $12.70 reduction in personal income tax in just two years. For a person on a taxable income of $300 a week, the reduction in income tax on 1 December will be $3.75, making a total of $11.35 a week in the two years since November 1984.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 17 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action, if any, was taken in each case and are any prosecutions being contemplated, in light of allegations made by Channel TVQ O on its program of 18 March 1986 and subsequent programs and during Australian Federal Police investigations in 1984 and subsequently, into allegations of an international crime ring engaged in importation of drugs through Brisbane, industrial espionage, disclosing silent telephone numbers for money, eavesdropping on the conversations of racing identities to sell tips, and deactivating phone connected burglar alarms to facilitate robberies.

(2) Have the Telecom technicians named in a police telex dated 10 August 1984 been employed in or had access to, at any time since March 1984, in Telecom local engineering, operations, processing, analysing (Leopard) centres or other Telecom positions which could facilitate such activities and, if applicable, did any of them cease working in such positions or have their access terminated, pending investigation; if so, for what reason.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) With regard to allegations of an international crime ring engaged in the importation of drugs through Brisbane, I am advised that the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and Queensland Police conducted a joint investigation in August 1984. Three people who were subjects of this investigation, were arrested by the NSW Police in September 1984. With regard to the other allegations, I am advised by the AFP that these matters are currently under investigation.

(2) The Minister for Communications has provided the following information in answer to this part of the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

One of the officers referred to in the alleged police telex dated 10 August 1984 was employed briefly in a Telecom local engineering, operations, processing, analysing (Leopard) Centre during the period referred to. Neither officer was employed in any other positions which could facilitate the activities alleged. Telecom has indicated that the circumstances in which the officer returned to the Leopard Centre temporarily resulted from the need to restrict the number of people who could be made aware of the investigations, and management changes. Consistent with the wishes of the Australian Federal Police, staffing changes involving officers were limited initially. Neither officer is employed with Telecom now.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What arrangements have been made for dispossessed former residents of Eastern Bloc nations to make compensation claims against the present governments of those nations in respect of the assets expropriated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Many hundreds of Australian citizens claim that they have had property nationalised or taken into State control by foreign governments since about 1939. Few have had any success in pursuing their claims on an individual basis. Many had only limited ties with Australia at the time the actions complained of were taken. In 1984 I asked that an interdepartmental working group consider what can be done to facilitate a proper settlement of these claims.

I expect that the ideal solution would include comprehensive official action to invite and assess the validity of claims made by Australian citizens. Compensation would then ultimately be paid out of funds provided following the negotiation of government-to-government agreements between Australia and the other countries concerned. However, achievement of this ideal solution requires the full cooperation of the latter countries, and this will need to be established.

The work of the interdepartmental group is proceeding as resources allow. The legal and administrative issues involved are complex and it is expected that final resolution of this matter will take some considerable time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 October 1986 (Hansard, page 1193), Senator Newman asked me a question without notice regarding removal costs for Government employees. I undertook to provide her with an answer to her question as soon as possible. I can now provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that no distinction is drawn on the basis of marital status in determining entitlements for servicemen and servicewomen when they are reposted. Different entitlements do of course apply to those serving members with family, and those without. Family is defined to include spouse or defacto spouse of the member, a child of either, under 21 years and normally resident with the family, a parent of either member or spouse or defacto spouse normally resident with the family.
